Unless the player has a good reason to make a shortsword (like not having very much Iron or for completionist purposes), they are advised to make the Iron Broadsword as it does more damage and can swing in an arc.

Before 1.3, the sprites of other ore shortswords are actually Iron Shortsword's sprite, recolored. This was changed in 1.3, where every shortsword now has its own texture. The same happened to other types of Pre-Hardmode ore tools, except Demonite, Crimtane and Hellstone ones.
Although the Seafood Dinner depicts a crab, it is only craftable using fish.
The Cooked Shrimp's tooltip, ' Barbecue it, boil it, broil it, bake it...' is a reference to the 1994 American comedy-drama film Forrest Gump.
The Cooked Fish's tooltip, ' Where's the chips!?' refers to fish and chips.

All fish that can be made into Sashimi are caught in the Ocean. This is consistent with traditional practice, as freshwater fish are considered unsafe to eat as sashimi. Although Trout is also caught in the Ocean, not all types of trout are suitable for raw consumption, which is the likely reason why Trout cannot be made into Sashimi. Sashimi is also the only food item that can be crafted at a Work Bench. Sashimi is also the only food item that can be crafted at a Work Bench.
Geysers are highlighted by the Dangersense buff.

If a Geyser is blocked by less than 29 other solid blocks, of at least 4 vertical blocks and 2 horizontal blocks, including liquids, it will pass through them signaled by puffs of smoke moving through the blocks, beginning the wall of fire at the first opening. The smoke will still inflict damage on players if touched. However, this can only happen when the geyser and the solid blocks have less than 4 blocks of space between them to pass through the blocks. However, this can only happen when the geyser and the solid blocks have less than 4 blocks of space between them to pass through the blocks.
Activated Geysers will not free any placed objects, including Torches.

Meteor Shots are available early, cheap to make, and good for dealing with large crowds of enemies, due to their ability to hit two enemies per shot. This makes them useful for surviving early events such as a Blood Moon or a Goblin Army.
Like all piercing projectiles, Meteor Shots are strong against worm-type enemies and large bosses because they can potentially hit two body sections with each bullet, dealing double damage.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) This ammunition has the drawback of dealing only some bullet's damage when used with rapid-fire or spread-shot weapons due to the invincibility frames granted by most piercing projectiles. Multiple Meteor Shots may overlap a single enemy during these frames and deal no damage, reducing single-target damage output. However, these Meteor Shots are not wasted and can still damage enemies beyond the first target.

Meteor Shots are useful for locating Floating Islands : a bullet fired upward will bounce off the bottom of one, back towards the ground. The Water Bolt spell can be used in a similar fashion. Both projectiles make sounds on impact with blocks, so if a player misses their visual cue, the audio cue of the bullet or bolt hitting nearby ground may be heard instead.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) While no other bullets have both bouncing and piercing capabilities, in Hardmode players have other options for just piercing (by crafting High Velocity Bullets ) or just bouncing (by crafting Nano Bullets ). After defeating the Moon Lord, Luminite Bullets become available which also have piercing capabilities.
Meteor Shots are the slowest bullets in the game.
Similarly to Baby Slimes and Black Slimes, the Mother Slime blends slightly with dark the background of the Cavern layer, making it difficult to detect. As such, it can often catch players off-guard.
Once Hardmode begins, the spawn rate of Mother Slimes will drop drastically; they will usually fail to spawn at all.
Explosive weapons, especially Grenades, work well when fighting the Mother Slime. The explosion will almost certainly damage or kill the Baby Slimes it spawns upon death.
The Bestiary entry for the Mother Slime: " Critical to the lifecycle of the slime species, these oversized jiggling masses are often found carrying their young deep underground. "
The mana cost is for the initial casting only. Maintaining and directing the missile does not cost additional mana, and the player will regenerate mana while controlling it.
The Rainbow Rod, when fired in lava or water, can travel at 82 mph.
The projectile is a fixed size, but the trail effect may make the projectile appear larger or brighter when moving at low speeds.
The Rainbow Rod can be used to light areas remotely.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Rainbow Rod can be used in conjunction with Binoculars to increase the range of the projectile.

Hovering over any slots in the inventory (should it be open) will cause the loss of control of any controlled projectile, flinging it forwards in the direction the cursor was last moving. Opening the inventory (and then closing it in singleplayer) will make it fling in the direction the player's finger was moving. Opening the inventory (and then closing it in singleplayer) will make it fling in the direction the player's finger was moving.

Unlike the Magic Missile and Flamelash, the projectile will not dissipate if it hits a surface while being controlled. Only when it is out of the player's control will it explode upon hitting a surface. This means the player does not need to be as precise when directing the projectile through caves or tight enclosures in worry of accidentally destroying the projectile.
Due to the projectile's sharp homing, it is possible for it to turn around after piercing an enemy and hit it again.
Due to the Rainbow Rod's high damage output and homing effect, it can be quite useful when fighting many Hardmode bosses including Plantera and Golem.

Tied with Shroomite Bars, Spectre Bars are the second most expensive bars in the game, selling for 1 GC (the most expensive are Luminite Bars, at 1 GC 20 SC ). Unlike Shroomite, the ingredients for Spectre Bars sell for more than the bars do.

Although the topmost corridors of the Dungeon may be accessible prior to defeating Skeletron, the Mechanic will only be found at Cavern height. Therefore, encountering her always requires defeating Skeletron, because the Dungeon Guardians spawning below zero depth will override all Dungeon spawns. In a drunk world (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the level at which Dungeon Guardians spawn is lower, allowing for Dungeon enemies to spawn, but the Mechanic will not spawn until Skeletron is defeated. [2] In a drunk world (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the level at which Dungeon Guardians spawn is lower, allowing for Dungeon enemies to spawn, but the Mechanic will not spawn until Skeletron is defeated. [2]
Since the Ice biome overrides Underground when calculating Happiness, the Mechanic can be put in an Ice biome without receiving Happiness penalty.

There appears to be a conflict between the Mechanic and Nurse during a Blood Moon. During this time, the Merchant has a chance of saying, " Oh, great. I can hear <name of Mechanic> and <name of Nurse> arguing from here. "

The Mechanic has a crush on the Goblin Tinkerer, as referenced by her quotes, and judging by some of the Goblin Tinkerer's quotes, he has a crush right back. This is also proven by her happiness quote, " Umm... <Name of Goblin Tinkerer> makes my heart flutter, I need to get that checked! " This is also proven by her happiness quote, " Umm... <Name of Goblin Tinkerer> makes my heart flutter, I need to get that checked! "

Rarely, the Nurse and Mechanic can both have the same name, either Kayla or Amy. This can cause the Merchant to say on a Blood Moon, " Oh, great. I can hear Kayla/Amy and Kayla/Amy arguing from here. "

The quote " <name of Arms Dealer > keeps talking about pressing my pressure plate. I told him it was for stepping on. " is a vague sexual reference. The Arms Dealer is apparently hitting on the Mechanic, using innuendo, but she does not get the euphemism and takes his comment literally. This is further supported by the Mechanic's dislike of the Arms Dealer due to him constantly bothering the Mechanic, referenced in the quote, " I don't really like that <name of Arms Dealer> won't leave me alone! " This might be the reason of the conflict between the Nurse and the Mechanic, since the Nurse has a crush on the Arms Dealer. This is further supported by the Mechanic's dislike of the Arms Dealer due to him constantly bothering the Mechanic, referenced in the quote, " I don't really like that <name of Arms Dealer> won't leave me alone! " This might be the reason of the conflict between the Nurse and the Mechanic, since the Nurse has a crush on the Arms Dealer.

The quote " Did you make sure your device was plugged in? " is possibly a reference to the British sitcom The IT Crowd, or a general statement made by many people in IT about "malfunctioning" devices.

The quote " <Name of Tavernkeep> offered me a Root Beer, I told him to give it to me in a square cup. " is a reference to a math joke; mathematical squares and square roots cancel each other out, therefore the result is simply beer.
The quote " DON'T MOVE. I DROPPED MY CONTACT. " makes a pun on " electrical contact ", a device that an electrical current passes through, and " contact lens ".
The quote " Just-could you just... Please? Ok? Ok. Ugh. " is possibly a reference to the American sitcom How I Met Your Mother.

During a party, when the Mechanic dons a party hat, her hairstyle is different: she wears it down instead of up in a bun. This makes sense as wearing a party hat while having hair in a bun would be cumbersome.

The Mechanic's ability to throw her wrench like a boomerang to defend herself may be a reference to a similar move that can be performed by Ratchet from the action-adventure platforming game series Ratchet & Clank.
Some of her names, "Autumn", "Dawn" and "Ginger" are references to the color orange and thus to her red hair.

– According to the Terraria lore pages, the Mechanic was being forced to rebuild Cthulhu piece by piece by the Cultists, which explains the creation and presence of the mechanical bosses. Additionally, she never finished Cthulhu's mechanical brain, which would account for the Brain of Cthulhu's lack of a mechanized counterpart.

The Mechanic hates the Clothier, most likely because he was the one who tied her up and left her in the Dungeon, as referenced by one of his quotes. Although she and the Clothier have a mutual hatred for each other, they do not appear to know why, as she only vaguely mentions that he "doesn't know how to treat a woman", while the Clothier only has vague recollections of throwing her in the Dungeon while possessed by Skeletron. Her dislike of the Caverns due to "a traumatic experience" likely refers to this incident as well. Although she and the Clothier have a mutual hatred for each other, they do not appear to know why, as she only vaguely mentions that he "doesn't know how to treat a woman", while the Clothier only has vague recollections of throwing her in the Dungeon while possessed by Skeletron. Her dislike of the Caverns due to "a traumatic experience" likely refers to this incident as well.

The Mechanic's Shimmered form transforms her into a Goblin. This is most likely a reference to the fact the Mechanic and Goblin Tinkerer have feelings for each other which can be seen in their Living preferences and quotes.

The Blizzard in a Balloon can stack with separate double-jump items, such as the Sandstorm in a Balloon and Fart in a Jar. Stacking multiple items that give the same type of double-jump (in this case, Blizzard) will not increase the effects of the jump.
The double jump can be used to negate fall damage if timed correctly.
The double jump can be stopped midway by releasing the ↷ Jump button.
The Blizzard jump provides a speed boost when used, which can be used to quickly turn around while retaining some speed.

The Clockwork Assault Rifle fires three shots, each one with a delay of 4 ticks, [1] for a total of 12 ticks. The delay between one burst and the next is 14 ticks. One complete use of the weapon (including the delay) takes 26 ticks.
On the Nintendo 3DS version, the Clockwork Assault Rifle has a knockback stat of Very Weak.
This weapon performs decently in early Hardmode, but its low damage makes it unreliable against most Hardmode enemies. Using Ichor Bullets or some other form of Ichor support is recommended.

Due to using only one ammo per burst, this weapon can be compared to the Shotgun. It performs better than the Shotgun against most targets but performs much worse than the Onyx Blaster (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Having the Rapid modifier will reduce both the per-bullet cooldown and the reload cooldown, making the benefit disproportionately large. This lets it fire as fast as an Agile Minishark on average, though against enemies with 30 or more defense, Demonic is still better.
On the Nintendo 3DS version, the Clockwork Assault Rifle does not have the delay between bursts, making it very viable far into Hardmode.
The Clockwork Assault Rifle, the Minishark, (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) the Star Cannon, and the Flintlock Pistol are some of the only guns that cannot inflict knockback.

The Clockwork Assault Rifle is potentially a reference to the Heckler & Koch G11 assault rifle, a real-world prototype rifle from the 1960s–1980s that fired in three-round bursts and had a clockwork feeding system.

Boreal Wood armor and Rich Mahogany armor share identical stats. Because the player will encounter the Jungle or the Snow biome depending on which direction they travel, these armors are more readily available.
The set bonus is still given if Shadow armor and Ancient Shadow armor are mixed. However, the visual after-image effect that comes with either set will not be given.
The set bonus gives the exact same movement speed bonuses as Magiluminescence (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), but also being active in mid-air.
Unlike other sources of movement speed, Shadow armor's set bonus affects the top speed of sprinting accessories and wings.
Despite requiring the fewest resources to craft, the Shadow Helmet sells for the most.
The Dangersense buff will highlight pressure plates.
Teal Pressure Pads do not have to be shot for them to activate. As long as the projectile passes through the tile containing the pressure plate, it will activate.
Golf Balls count as projectiles for purposes of triggering Teal Pressure Pads.
Pressure plates will work in reversed gravity if placed on top of a block and then flown into.

Pressure plates allow the player to see laid wires when held, which can help avoiding traps. This is not the case in For the worthy or Get fixed boi worlds. This is not the case in For the worthy or Get fixed boi worlds.
Pressure plates that can be triggered by non-players can also be triggered by Boulders. This can be used as a delay, or to trigger a row of traps as it rolls down a hallway.

They can also be used for opening and closing doors without having to manually open or close them, although care should be taken that they are not unintentionally triggered by NPCs or enemies. This can be avoided by using the right kinds of the pressure plate.
Paint can be applied to pressure plates to make them nearly invisible, e.g. for PvP purposes.
Since they are regular projectiles, Falling Stars can activate Teal Pressure Pads.
It is based on a real-life fish of the same name, which lives in the Amazon basin of South America.
Like the Death Sickle, the range of the projectile produced by the weapon increases with melee speed.

The weapon is very effective for close-range area control, as most enemies will be knocked back and take high damage by trying to pass through the hovering projectile. It is also potent against worm enemies (like the The Destroyer, Dune Splicer, Digger or World Feeder ) that take multiple hits from each projectile.
The Ice Sickle is extremely useful in early Hardmode, because it can be obtained just after defeating the Wall of Flesh and can kill groups of enemies in just a few hits.
This weapon is good for dealing with monsters that can travel through blocks (especially while farming).
The name Ice Sickle is a play on the word icicle.
The Ice Sickle is improperly named; it more resembles a real-life scythe than a sickle, as it is much larger than sickles and lacks their short handle and circular blade.
The horizontal projectile range is about 64 tiles from the sprite, if angled correctly.
The Aqua Scepter is unable to extinguish enemies who are lit On Fire!.

The Aqua Scepter's attack consists of two separate streams of water superimposed on top of each other, similar to the Golden Shower which has 3. Thus, it will actually pierce 9 enemies per use and will damage the fifth enemy twice.

In Don't dig up (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) seeds, the Aqua Scepter receives the following changes: Switched place with Bubble Gun. As a result, it is dropped by the Duke Fishron instead of found in Locked Gold Chests in Dungeon and Golden Lock Boxes. Damage increased from 27 to 90. Use time decreased from 8 to 5. Value increased from 8 GC 75 SC to 25 GC. Now uses local immunity frames and applies 12 ticks of local immunity frames per hit. This makes Mythical the uncontested best modifier in the seed. Switched place with Bubble Gun. As a result, it is dropped by the Duke Fishron instead of found in Locked Gold Chests in Dungeon and Golden Lock Boxes. Damage increased from 27 to 90. Use time decreased from 8 to 5. Value increased from 8 GC 75 SC to 25 GC. Now uses local immunity frames and applies 12 ticks of local immunity frames per hit. This makes Mythical the uncontested best modifier in the seed. This makes Mythical the uncontested best modifier in the seed.
Its particles emit light, so the Aqua Scepter can be useful in scouting out caverns.
Due to its high pierce count and solid damage, the Aqua Scepter is a good weapon against the Wall of Flesh.
The normal Aqua Scepter applies 10 global immunity frames on hit, which can potentially prevent minions from dealing damage.
The Golden Shower can be considered a Hardmode upgrade of the Aqua Scepter.
It makes the same sound effect as the Rocket Boots.
Certain vanity items also serve as hairstyles. Some vanity items that can be equipped on the head slot still show the player's hair, such as a Witch Hat.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) When using the randomize option during character creation, the chosen hairstyle determines the player's gender. 69 hairstyles will set the gender to female, while the remaining 81 will set it to male. [1]
Hairstyles 109 and 125 through 132 resemble alien-themed hairstyles.
Hairstyle 124 resembles Mary Sanderson from the 1993 fantasy comedy film Hocus Pocus.
Hairstyle 7 resembles the hairstyle that the Dryad has.
Hairstyle 4 resembles the signature wide flat-top hairstyle of Guile from the Street Fighter series.
Hairstyles 24 and 132 resemble the Super Saiyan hairstyles from the Japanese anime and manga series Dragon Ball Z, as Saiyans are considered a different species.
Hairstyles 26 and 20 resemble Princess Leia and Luke Skywalker respectively from the American epic space-opera media franchise Star Wars.
Hairstyles 126 and 127 resemble Floran hairstyles from the 2016 action-adventure sandbox game Starbound.
Hairstyles 82 and 84 resemble Sailor Moon and Chibiusa from the Japanese shōjo manga series Sailor Moon.
Hairstyle 52, 53, and 54 respectively resemble the White Mage, Black Mage, and Fighter's hair from the NES and MSX version of the 1987 fantasy role-playing video game Final Fantasy.
Hairstyle 78 resembles Filius Flitwick from the fantasy novel series Harry Potter.
Hairstyle 107 resembles Madeline from the 2018 platforming game Celeste.
Hairstyle 44 resembles Jin Kazama 's hair from the fighting game series Tekken.
Hairstyle 163 resembles the hairstyle that the Princess has.
Hairstyle 135 resembles Rosalina 's hair from the 2007 3D–platforming game Super Mario Galaxy, evidenced further by the existence of the Star Princess set which references the same character.
Hairstyles 53, 77, and 110 give the player visible eyebrows.
Hairstyles 164 and 165 resemble the hairstyles of Wilson and Willow, characters from the survival game Don't Starve.
The increase in tile/wall placement speed additively stacks with the bonus from either the Brick Layer, Portable Cement Mixer, or the Architect Gizmo Pack for a total increase of 75%, respectively.
The Builder buff's placement range increase stacks with the effects of both the Toolbelt and Toolbox for a total increase of 3 tiles.
The different colors can be used to differentiate teams in PvP games.
Despite all Phaseblades having identical stats, the Purple Phaseblade is usually the easiest and fastest to acquire, as Amethysts are the most common gems.

Both the weapon's visual appearance and its sound effect bear a striking resemblance to the fictional energy sword lightsaber featured in the American epic space opera media franchise Star Wars. This reference is further reinforced by the requirement of crystals and gems in the crafting of Phaseblades and Phasesabers, alluding to the colored kyber crystals which are used in the construction of lightsabers.
The Phaseblade can be considered the Meteorite -tier ore sword, due to there being no other designated "Meteorite sword", and the fact that it requires Meteorite Bars to craft.
The " Power Glove " was originally a somewhat experimental controller for the NES as well as a staple in the Legend of Zelda series.

Dying from starvation will display one of the following unique death messages : " <Player name> starved to death. " " <Player name> couldn't find food. " " <Player name> forgot to eat. " " <Player name> starved to death. " " <Player name> couldn't find food. " " <Player name> forgot to eat. "
The icons of these debuffs are based on the Hunger icon from Don't Starve.
All characters spawn with Peckish upon world generation, but the debuff is removed instantly if not in a Constant or Get fixed boi world. [4]
It must be equipped to work in the Old-gen console version. It will not display the time if it is in the inventory.
The FPV Goggles do not lose their functionality when equipped in a social slot.
FPV stands for first-person view.
The item's tooltip is in reference to Fat Shark, a manufacturer of FPV headsets for drone racing.
The item is referred to internally as JimsDroneVisor, likely after Jimmarn.
Spiky Balls will not harm the player who threw them, nor will they damage NPCs. They will, however, damage other players in PvP.
Once thrown, a Spiky Ball cannot be picked up again.
Spiky Balls will not fall through platforms.

Spiky Balls are useful against groups of enemies or bosses (e.g., the Eater of Worlds or King Slime ), especially because they can be set up in advance. Ironically, they are very good for fighting the Goblin Army, the event Spiky Balls are obtained from in the first place. Ironically, they are very good for fighting the Goblin Army, the event Spiky Balls are obtained from in the first place.
When wearing Frost armor, Spiky Balls will glow from the Frostburn effect and can serve as makeshift Glowsticks.
When thrown on the ground, they can serve as an immobilizer to any enemy that does not have knockback resistance.
As Spiky Balls are a very common drop during the Goblin Army event, with each Spiky Ball selling for 16 CC, they are a decent money source early on.

In the Tutorial (Console, Old-gen console, Mobile and 3DS versions), there is a Chest containing a Bomb with the Large modifier. This is the only way to legitimately obtain a reforged Bomb. However, because Bombs are not melee weapons, the modifier Large only has an aesthetic effect on them. However, because Bombs are not melee weapons, the modifier Large only has an aesthetic effect on them.
The tooltip quote is a reference to a plot point from the 1990 platform game ActRaiser, where a loaf of bread is used to convince a child named Teddy to go back home. [1]
A Golf Ball will always be placed on the tee when using it, even if the player has no Golf Ball item equipped.
Using a Golf Tee causes all of the player's Golf Ball projectiles in the world to despawn. [1]

If the player has multiple differently colored Golf Ball items in the inventory, the priority is as follows: accessory social slots bottom to top, accessory slots bottom to top, main inventory top/left to bottom/right. For instance, having a Red Golf Ball in the bottom social slot and a Green Golf Ball in the top accessory slot will result in a Red Golf Ball being placed on the Golf Tee.

The Baby Finch will always be summoned at the player's cursor; it will have to fly to the player's head before nesting. However, the nest sprite appears instantly when the first Baby Finch is summoned.
Unlike other summoning weapons, a Baby Finch is summoned when the player spawns without needing to use the staff if it is in the inventory.
Baby Finches do not target enemies without a clear line-of-sight, even if they are targeted with ⚷ Open / Activate.

The Baby Finch minion applies 15 ticks of local immunity frames upon hitting an enemy, meaning it can potentially hit up to four times per second. Due to using local immunity frames, the damage output of Baby Finch minions will scale linearly with player's minion slots. This is unlike most other pre-Hardmode minions. Due to using local immunity frames, the damage output of Baby Finch minions will scale linearly with player's minion slots. This is unlike most other pre-Hardmode minions.
Despite reaching relatively high speeds, the Baby Finch has difficulty turning, and may often fly in circles while trying to charge targets.

If the player is attempting to use only summon weapons, it is usually a good idea to use the Finch Staff to farm for the Leather Whip (which will increase the damage both the player and Baby Finch do), before attempting to fight bosses or explore more challenging areas, such as The Crimson / The Corruption or Underground Jungle. Alternatively, the player could replace the Finch Staff completely with the Slime Staff, although it is incredibly unlikely to drop and relies heavily on luck.
Rapidly summoning Baby Finches onto an enemy can be helpful if the Baby Finch is not actively targeting it.
Cornering an enemy with a Baby Finch will result in very high DPS.
The Baby Finch's sprite is most likely based on a common chaffinch.

Since it is only a mini-biome, the usual NPC spawning rules do not apply to the Granite Cave. Instead, Granite Elementals and Granite Golems require one Granite Block on which they can spawn, inside the player's spawn range ; or any Granite Block between 30 and 60 tiles away from the player. A single Granite Block is sufficient (although the chance increases with the number of Granite Blocks) and Granite Walls do not have any impact. However, if the player is standing on a Granite Block, the chance for Granite Elementals and Granite Golems to spawn gets a significant boost. In that case, no further Granite Blocks in the vicinity are required. [1]
In drunk worlds, the generation structure of Granite Caves is swapped with Marble Caves.
Granite biomes usually have at least a standalone chest in them, so once a player is powerful enough to repel Granite Elementals, they should explore the biome.
When a Truffle Worm is the first bait to be used, the Fisherman's Pocket Guide (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and its upgrades simply display " Warning! " instead of listing Fishing Power.

The Truffle Worm is internally considered an enemy rather than a critter, despite not posing any threat. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It will not take any damage from enemies. However, the Hunter Potion will highlight it in green, like other critters, instead of red. Furthermore, the Guide to Critter Companionship (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and its upgrades will prevent the player from killing it accidentally. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It will not take any damage from enemies. However, the Hunter Potion will highlight it in green, like other critters, instead of red. Furthermore, the Guide to Critter Companionship (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and its upgrades will prevent the player from killing it accidentally.
Truffle Worms follow the Worm AI even in their passive state on 3DS.

100 tiles of Mushroom blocks are not necessary for Truffle Worms to spawn. Mushroom enemies and Truffle Worms will spawn wherever there is Mushroom grass, without requiring that the area is actually considered a Glowing Mushroom biome. On Mushroom grass, each enemy spawn has a 2/3 chance of being a mushroom-themed enemy or critter. Each time this happens, there is a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/5 (20%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/7 (14.29%) chance that the mushroom-themed character is a Truffle Worm. Considering the maximum spawn rate (1/60 per tick [1] ), the approximately of maximum expected Truffle Worm spawns is (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 480 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 342 per hour. On Mushroom grass, each enemy spawn has a 2/3 chance of being a mushroom-themed enemy or critter. Each time this happens, there is a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/5 (20%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/7 (14.29%) chance that the mushroom-themed character is a Truffle Worm. Considering the maximum spawn rate (1/60 per tick [1] ), the approximately of maximum expected Truffle Worm spawns is (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 480 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 342 per hour.

Since the Truffle Worm is not considered a critter, NPCs should not be used as a means to increase the proportion of critters in the total number of creatures spawned. Each existing enemy may reduce the spawn rate of the next. Getting rid of excess enemies will give the Truffle Worm more opportunities to spawn. Water Candles and/or Battle Potions will increase its spawn rate. Each existing enemy may reduce the spawn rate of the next. Getting rid of excess enemies will give the Truffle Worm more opportunities to spawn. Water Candles and/or Battle Potions will increase its spawn rate.

One way to increase the chances of finding Truffle Worms is to convert a large section of the Underground Jungle into an Underground Glowing Mushroom biome, using the Clentaminator with Dark Blue Solution. A slower alternative would be to use Mushroom Grass Seeds on plain Mud Blocks.

A simple (but perhaps slow) way to farm them is to move away from and back to a Glowing Mushroom biome repeatedly, causing new enemies to spawn and potentially a Truffle Worm. Teleporters (with hoiks ) or the Portal Gun (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) can be used to make an infinite falling loop. If it is high enough, going in can cause other enemies to despawn, allowing the Truffle Worm to have more chances to spawn. Teleporters (with hoiks ) or the Portal Gun (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) can be used to make an infinite falling loop. If it is high enough, going in can cause other enemies to despawn, allowing the Truffle Worm to have more chances to spawn.
The number 666 in the Truffle Worm's "666% bait power" is a reference to the number of the beast, commonly associated with Satan. This alludes to its ability to spawn Duke Fishron.

The combination of truffle and worm represented by the Truffle Worm ties in with the combined pig-and-fish-like nature of Duke Fishron. Traditionally, pigs have been utilized for the extraction of edible truffles, a highly prized food. This is also referenced by the Truffle 's quote, " You haven't seen any pigs around here have you? My brother lost his leg to one. ", as well as how the Pigron and Cute Fishron mounts' summoning items are all Truffles. My brother lost his leg to one. ", as well as how the Pigron and Cute Fishron mounts' summoning items are all Truffles.

The Windy Balloon (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Lunatic Devotee, Truffle Worm, and Prismatic Lacewing (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are the only entities classified as an "enemy" that otherwise deal absolutely no damage to the player.
The Item Frame can also be used to place a weapon, similar to the Weapon Rack.
Unlike the Weapon Rack, objects in an Item Frame always have the same orientation regardless of the direction used to place the Item Frame.
Item Frames can be painted. Only the frame itself can be painted, however, not the item inside.
Favorited items cannot be placed on Item Frames. The player must unfavorite the item first in order to display it on an Item Frame.

Some items may interact unexpectedly with Item Frames: Gel is always displayed as blue, regardless of its color when placed. Hovering over the Item Frame shows an unobtainable gray-colored Gel:. If retrieved, said Gel will be blue. The Shark Fin is always displayed as, regardless of its color when placed. Hovering over the Item Frame shows an unobtainable white-colored Shark Fin. If retrieved, it will drop with the default color. The Shellphone displays as, regardless of its state when placed. However, hovering over the Item Frame shows its actual state and, if the Shellphone is retrieved, it will drop in that state. The Rubblemaker only displays the shovel itself, omitting the bar seen in the inventory :. The Torch God's Favor uniquely appears illuminated in the Item Frame, a property not displayed in other light-related items such as Torches. The Item Frame can be hidden by using Echo Coating, making it seem as if the item is hanging freely on the wall. The Item Frame can also be concealed with Shadow Paint in combination with Shadow-painted background walls. The Item Frame can also be concealed with Shadow Paint in combination with Shadow-painted background walls.
Smooth Marble strongly resembles either the real-life Carrara marble, found in Tuscany, Italy, or Volakas marble, found in Volakas, Greece.
Ash Grass Seeds are easy to obtain in Don't dig up worlds, as the player starts in the Underworld.

Smoke Blocks can have multiple decorative purposes: In adventure maps, they can be paired with Living Fire Blocks to create a realistic fire. When painted with Negative Paint, it creates a foamy effect which can be used to make waterfalls. Making Smoke Blocks half-blocks or lower slopes by using a hammer allows banner placement. With Echo Coating, Smoke Blocks may be preferred over blocks, platforms, or Planter Boxes, since the player can freely pass through Smoke Blocks. Note that the War Table Banner will immediately be broken once the player places it. In adventure maps, they can be paired with Living Fire Blocks to create a realistic fire. With Echo Coating, Smoke Blocks may be preferred over blocks, platforms, or Planter Boxes, since the player can freely pass through Smoke Blocks. The Aegis Fruit's defense bonus completely negates the defense decrease of the Tipsy debuff, making it beneficial to the player.
In Greek mythology, the aegis is a circular shield carried by the Olympian gods Athena and Zeus.
The Vortexian, Selenian, Predictor, and Stargazer all share very similar sprites.
They seem to resemble the Moon Lord with legs but without the eyes or the spine. The teardrop design on its chest, combined with the exposed brain further supports this.
It is necessary to fight if the player is looking to craft Master Ninja Gear, since it drops two of the three ingredients required in crafting it.

In order to counter its high speed, grappling to the ceiling and attacking it with long-ranged weapons proves effective. Using a Megashark or similar weapons with a high fire rate can stun-lock it, immobilizing and killing the Bone Lee.
Bone Lee's name, appearance, and attacks are references to the real-life Hong Kong-American actor, director, martial artist, and philosopher Bruce Lee.

While at the first look seeming like a rather weak debuff, the randomly occurring debuffs can cause major damage to a player. The Confused and Cursed debuffs can easily catch players on the wrong foot, especially when they are not aware of being under the influence of Feral Bite.
Having an Ankh Charm or Ankh Shield can eliminate all other debuffs generated by Feral Bite, making it technically a pseudo- buff.

Despite being Expert-exclusive, the debuffs Feral Bite inflicts have durations for Classic Mode. It is possible to achieve these shorter durations in Journey Mode by changing the difficulty from Expert/Master Mode to Classic Mode after being inflicted with Feral Bite. It is possible to achieve these shorter durations in Journey Mode by changing the difficulty from Expert/Master Mode to Classic Mode after being inflicted with Feral Bite.
Internally, Feral Bite is named Rabies, a real disease which affects animals and humans.
Nanite is an informal term for a nanorobot, a microscopic mechanism that could hypothetically be injected into living organisms to mend or control them.
It is recommended to quickly upgrade it to Mana Regeneration Band as it gives extra mana regeneration and extra max mana.
Like the Angry Dandelion, Windy Balloons can only spawn upwind of the player.
Windy Balloons' movement always follows the direction of the wind.
The slime attached to the Windy Balloon holds any items on the drop table, appearing inside the slime like bonus drops. Destroying the balloon does not give the player the item.

The Windy Balloon has no banner and kill count; killing the slime it carries only progresses the banner and kill count for said slime itself. Popping the balloon does not cause the Tally Counter to change. However, "killing" the Windy Balloon is required in order to progress the Bestiary 's information, as the Bestiary uses a separate kill counter. However, "killing" the Windy Balloon is required in order to progress the Bestiary 's information, as the Bestiary uses a separate kill counter.

If the player kills the slime tied to the Windy Balloon, the balloon will proceed to rapidly zip upwards and out of view. If followed, the balloon will keep on flying up into Space and disappear outside the screen once the player hits the map borders. If followed, the balloon will keep on flying up into Space and disappear outside the screen once the player hits the map borders.
The Windy Balloon, Lunatic Devotee, Truffle Worm, and Prismatic Lacewing are the only entities classified as an "enemy" that otherwise deal absolutely no damage to the player.
A mushroom's pileus (or top) is commonly referred to as a mushroom cap, hence this item's name.

The Mushroom Cap may be a reference to the hat worn by Toads, a mushroom-like species from the Mario franchise. Toads are also referenced in a full set of vanity equipment (See Mushroom set ). Toads are also referenced in a full set of vanity equipment (See Mushroom set ).
While one is able to craft it out of Gold or Platinum, it will always have a golden appearance.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) A player can sit on the Throne while NPCs cannot.
Despite their names, the Adamantite Beam and Palladium Column do not count as beams. Instead, they are types of blocks.

Prior to 1.2, Wooden Beams presented the only method of placing suspended Torches without foreground blocks for them to attach to. As Torches can be placed directly on background walls in 1.2, Wooden Beams are far less functional within houses. They can still be helpful in other places where background walls are not present.

Some high speeds are not fully maintained. A character that built up full speed on Asphalt Blocks will slide slightly slower on Frozen Slime Blocks. The high speeds that result from dash attacks ( Tabi, Shield of Cthulhu, Solar Flare armor, etc.) are not maintained. A character that built up full speed on Asphalt Blocks will slide slightly slower on Frozen Slime Blocks. The high speeds that result from dash attacks ( Tabi, Shield of Cthulhu, Solar Flare armor, etc.) are not maintained.

Similar to Asphalt Blocks, single-block gaps do not affect speed. Every second block can be air, and still maintain total sliding speed. If gaps are filled with a different block type, movement will be slowed or stopped.
Ice Skates and accessories crafted with them have no effect on sliding speed, but they do improve the player's movement control.
Minecarts are not affected by the frictionless properties of Frozen Slime Blocks, and will slide to a stop normally.
An effective sky road can be made by placing Frozen Slime Blocks every other block with doors at points of interest along the road which can be grappled and opened to reach top speed.
An effective underground road can be constructed with Asphalt Blocks to start the road and Frozen Slime Blocks to maintain a high constant speed.
When using Hooks, they can accelerate themselves to a sustained high speed by grappling forward and then disengaging the hook before it reels them in completely.
Although using ice as a material, it does not cause the Snow Biome to take over the actual biome the player is in, and still acts as ice.
The projectile has a 5/6 (83.33%) chance to inflict the On Fire! debuff for 1–2 seconds, and a 1/6 (16.67%) chance to inflict it for 2–4 seconds. On average, the debuff is inflicted for 1.75 seconds.

In Don't dig up and Get fixed boi seeds, the Wand of Sparking receives the following changes: Switched place with Magic Dagger. As a result, it is dropped by Mimics during Hardmode instead of found in Chests and sold by the Skeleton Merchant during Third Quarter. Damage increased from 14 to 40. Use time decreased from 26 to 10. Mana cost increased from 2 to 6. Velocity increased from 7 to 12. Inflicts Hellfire instead of On Fire!. Value increased from 1 GC to 25 GC. Value increased from 1 GC to 25 GC.

The Wand of Sparking's lack of knockback and short range can make it difficult to use. Furthermore, if the player has not yet increased their maximum mana, their mana regeneration speed may be too low to consistently use the weapon immediately after getting it. Nonetheless, its mana efficiency (7 damage/mana), Average speed, 14% critical strike chance, and medium chance to inflict On Fire! render it better than some early-tier gem staves if the player can close the distance. Nonetheless, its mana efficiency (7 damage/mana), Average speed, 14% critical strike chance, and medium chance to inflict On Fire! render it better than some early-tier gem staves if the player can close the distance.
It can be used to temporarily light up dark spaces at a distance while exploring during the first few days of a character's existence.

The Wand of Sparking's piercing properties and ability to inflict a damaging debuff makes it useful against early worm -type enemies, as it can both damage and inflict a debuff on multiple segments in one strike.
The Wand of Sparking can be used through one- or two-tile wide holes in a wall, allowing to safely kill Zombies and other enemies in the first few nights.
Using its range, it can be used in the first stages of the game to remove thorny bushes in the Corruption, Crimson, or Jungle biomes.

This weapon and the Wand of Frosting are tied for having the lowest mana usage of any magic weapon in the game; not considering the Space Gun or the Gray / Orange Zapinator coupled with Meteor armor (which costs 0 mana).
This weapon and the Wand of Frosting are the only "wands" which are magic weapons; aside from the cosmetic Bubble Wand, the other items with "wand" in their name all place blocks.
The Yoyo Bag accessory is highly recommended.

If the player wants to obtain the Amarok, King Slime is an excellent enemy to spawn, as each slime spawned can drop it. By Hardmode, the player should have little trouble handling the boss, as well as an abundant supply of Gold / Platinum for crafting the Slime Crown. Another good way to get the Amarok is to craft a Goblin Battle Standard and use it in a Snow biome. This provides a lot of enemies to kill, and as most of them are very weak pre-Hardmode enemies (minus the Goblin Warlock ). Another good way to get the Amarok is to craft a Goblin Battle Standard and use it in a Snow biome. This provides a lot of enemies to kill, and as most of them are very weak pre-Hardmode enemies (minus the Goblin Warlock ).
In Inuit mythology, the Amarok is a gigantic wolf god, a lone hunter that attacks those hunting alone at night.

In addition to regular Chests and Gold Chests, Hermes Boots can also be found in Rich Mahogany, Granite (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Marble Chests (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Slow debuff only affects the player's regular acceleration, not their maximum movement speed. Therefore, when running with the Hermes Boots while affected by the debuff, the final speed will be unaffected, although it will take longer to get there.
Accessory dyes will change the color of both the boots and the dust trail they leave behind.
Hermes Boots, as well as Flurry Boots and Sailfish Boots, are particularly useful for speedruns, as they can greatly shorten running time.

The player can engage the speed ability of the boots immediately on a flat or relatively flat surface by shooting a single-lined grappling hook in front of them at the ground in the desired direction (while simultaneously using the movement keys to move that direction) and immediately pressing ↷ Jump to disengage the hook, using the speed of the hook as a jump start for the boots. The player gets a faster jump start by shooting it nearly parallel to the ground, as the farther the hook lands from the player, the faster they are pulled. The same effect can be accomplished by dashing (e.g. with the Shield of Cthulhu (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or Tabi ). The same effect can be accomplished by dashing (e.g. with the Shield of Cthulhu (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or Tabi ).
The Hermes Boots can be a very helpful item in early pre-Hardmode, and if the player is lucky, they can obtain the upgraded versions before fighting the Wall of Flesh.
In the early game, the Hermes Boots work well with the Aglet and Anklet of the Wind, which will further increase speed.

The Hermes Boots are very likely a reference to the Pegasus Boots obtainable in many of the games of The Legend of Zelda series, as the two share many similar traits: Both pairs of boots greatly increase the running speed of the player. Both items are named after a figure in Greek Mythology attributed with speed in some way. The running sound and dust effects of both items are unmistakably similar. Additionally, the pre-1.2 Hermes Boots sprite is nearly identical to the Pegasus Boots sprite from The Minish Cap, with only a slight pixel difference. Both pairs of boots greatly increase the running speed of the player. Both items are named after a figure in Greek Mythology attributed with speed in some way. The running sound and dust effects of both items are unmistakably similar. Additionally, the pre-1.2 Hermes Boots sprite is nearly identical to the Pegasus Boots sprite from The Minish Cap, with only a slight pixel difference.
The Terraformer can be paired with a Sniper Scope or Rifle Scope to achieve a longer range of view.

The Terraformer can be used with the Ammo Box and/or the Ammo Reservation buff to further reduce the chance of consuming solution when used. The same applies to any Accessories and Armor pieces that reduce ammo consumption.
Terraforming is the process of transforming a planet so as to resemble Earth, especially so that it can support human life.
Seeds are dropped even if the grass is not cut by the player, but instead e.g. by a Fallen Star.
Falling Shell Pile blocks will not land on platforms, like most other falling blocks. The only exception are Sand Blocks.
Since Shell Piles are affected by gravity, they can Block Swap Sand and other gravity-affected blocks.
Because Shell Piles randomly generate near oceans, they have a much lower value to NPCs than the shells they are composed of ( shells have a value between 5 SC to 1 GC ).
Shell Pile is considered a soft tile by the Gravedigger's Shovel.
Oiled cannot be inflicted on the player, hence the lack of a buff icon, as it would never be displayed.
The Mace stays out on the ground if ⚒ Use / Attack is held after it is thrown, making it a good weapon to farm early enemies.
The Mace is a powerful early-game weapon, as it excels in keeping enemies away.
Even though the weapon is called mace, its design is more representative of a flail. It was most likely named this way due to the confusing fact that it is a part of the flail weapon family.

When the player uses an item that makes melee weapons catch on fire like the Flask of Fire or the Magma Stone, the Mace does not get the sprite of a Flaming Mace and it only leaves fire particles behind. It also does not go out in water.

Like all thrown flails, the Mace's displayed damage is twice its damage internally, which is normally 9. This means that damage modifiers will always round to even numbers, and the Mace's normal internal damage, half of what is displayed, is used after it bounces off of a wall or ⚒ Use / Attack is pressed again after use.
He cannot be teleported by the Portal Gun or King Statue.
He can sometimes spawn in pools of water. However, he is immune to drowning.

The Skeleton Merchant does not attack other skeletons listed below, nor will they harm him via contact damage. [1] The Skeleton Merchant can still inadvertently damage other skeletons if they are hit by the bones from the Skeleton Merchant, and he can still be harmed by certain non-contact attacks like Skeleton Archer 's arrows.
Using the Hunter Potion helps finding the Skeleton Merchant.
Selling items to the Skeleton Merchant can help a player clear out their inventory in the middle of a long caving session.
If a player notices a suspiciously low number of enemies on their Radar, it could be a sign that the Skeleton Merchant has spawned.
If the Skeleton Merchant spawns in front of a Detonator explosive trap,interacting with him may unwillingly hit the plunger on the detonator trap, killing both him and the player.
The names Jack Sellington and Skellington are references to Jack Skellington from the 1993 American animated fantasy Halloween-Christmas film The Nightmare Before Christmas.
He can be seen retrieving a Slap Hand from a pile of bones in the credits.
The name "Bones McGee" is a reference to Leonard H. "Bones" McCoy, a character in the American science fiction franchise Star Trek.
The name "No-Eyed Wiley" is a reference to One-Eyed Willy from the 1985 American adventure comedy film The Goonies.
The name "Mandible Calavera" is a reference to Manuel "Manny" Calavera from the adventure game Grim Fandango.
The names "Billy Marrows" and "Gloomy Mays" are a reference to the late American television salesperson Billy Mays.

The name "Tom" may be a reference to Tom "Bones" Malone, member of the American blues and soul revivalist band The Blues Brothers. "Tom" may also be a reference to the enemy Tim. "Tom" may also be a reference to the enemy Tim.
The quote about Slime Oil is a reference to the " miracle medicine " peddlers of the 1800s, who were commonly called Snake Oil Salesmen.

The quote " The only things constant in this world are death and taxes, I've got both! " is a reference to Benjamin Franklin 's famous quote "In this world, nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes."

The quote " You would not believe some of the things people throw at me... Wanna buy some of it? " is a reference to a young scavenger named "Squirt the Peddler" in the action role-playing game Diablo III. Squirt periodically asks the player a near-exact variation of this question, but refers to "things people throw away" instead of "things people throw at me".
The quote " Stay away from the spiders. They'll suck out your insides and leave you a hollow shell of a man. Trust me on this one. " suggests that he came to be after being killed by a Spider.
Even though he is not a town NPC, he will throw confetti during a Party.
He is one of two NPCs that does not have a map icon, the other being the Old Man.
He is the only NPC that always despawns once off-screen. The Traveling Merchant also despawns when off-screen, but only after 6:00 PM.
Despite the fact one of his quotes [2] makes a joke on the idea, the Skeleton Merchant does not sell Maggots.
If the Skeleton Merchant is slain, no message pops up to announce his death, unlike most NPCs.

The counterweights he sells resemble dice used in Dungeons and Dragons. This is a possible reference to weighted dies used for cheating, which may be provided by a disreputable merchant such as the Skeleton Merchant.
The Skeleton Merchant's Shimmered form transforms him into a Zombie. This is most likely a reference to the fact that Zombies turn into Skeletons in shimmer.
Even though the Wood Greaves grant 0 defense and may seem useless, wearing the full set grants 1 bonus defense, making it worth using.

If the player spawns in an area with a sparse amount of trees, it may be worth considering to use the Wood for other, more useful items. Nearby Desert, Snow, and Jungle biomes offer their own early-game armors which are all better than Wood armor.
The Wood Greaves are one of the three armor items which do not grant any defense. The other two are the Amethyst Robe and the Djinn's Curse (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Enemies that are immune to the On Fire! and Hellfire debuffs are also immune to damage from the Inferno Potion's ring of fire.
Crafting this potion requires a Hotline Fishing Hook, a Lavaproof Fishing Hook, or lava critters, as its two fish ingredients can only be caught in lava.
On the Nintendo 3DS version, the inferno keeps damaging enemies when going to the armor section in the player's inventory. However, the buff's duration will still decrease.

While the ring deals minimal damage to most Hardmode enemies, it is very useful against enemies that throw destructible projectiles, as these are easily destroyed by the ring. Examples include Duke Fishron with his Detonating Bubbles and Plantera with her spores.
If a player dies from the Inferno buff's ring of fire while PvP is active, the following unique death message will be displayed: " <Player name> was consumed by the inferno. "
The Psycho Knife only receives 33% of any melee speed bonus.

At a base level, the Psycho Knife is tied with the Fetid Baghnakhs as the fastest melee weapon in the game. However, given the Baghnakhs' 75% melee speed bonus reduction compared to the Psycho Knife's 66% melee speed bonus reduction, the Psycho Knife is capable of reaching higher speeds overall, thus making it functionally the fastest melee weapon in the game.

The stealth mode that is activated by the Psycho Knife is somewhat similar to that of the Shroomite armor 's set bonus, in that both stealth bonuses activate while remaining still for a period of time. However, more akin to Vortex armor, moving will not deactivate it. However, more akin to Vortex armor, moving will not deactivate it.
The stealth-mode horizontal speed reduction even applies when using wings to fly. Vertical flight speed, notably, remains unaffected.
All melee weapons are affected by the increased stats from stealth mode; however, this effect cannot be seen in-game, as switching weapons cancels the stealth bonus.
The dash attacks that can be used with the Solar Flare armor 's set bonus and the Shield of Cthulhu gain the damage bonus from the Psycho Knife's stealth.
Other players can see a player that is using Psycho Knife's stealth if they are missing health, as the health bar will be shown above their head.

If the player enters stealth, holds the attack button to autoswing their Psycho Knife, and uses the Quick Mount function, they will retain stealth while using their mount until an enemy is hit by the weapon or they stop swinging.

Enemies which fire projectiles and certain flying enemies will target through stealth. Projectile firing enemies will not, however, chase the stealthed player. Projectile firing enemies will not, however, chase the stealthed player.

By gaining the Striking Moment buff from the Brand of the Inferno (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) before switching to the Psycho Knife, one can easily deal over 2,000 damage in a single hit if it is a critical hit. This damage can be drastically increased to well over 7,000 in a single hit when utilizing banners in Expert Mode alongside damage boosting gear such as armor and accessories, making it one of the highest damaging setups in the game. This damage can be drastically increased to well over 7,000 in a single hit when utilizing banners in Expert Mode alongside damage boosting gear such as armor and accessories, making it one of the highest damaging setups in the game.

Dash accessories or armor (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (e.g. Shield of Cthulhu, Master Ninja Gear, or Crystal Assassin armor (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) ) can be used to great effect to move faster while in stealth mode. A hook can be used to achieve similar effect. Grappling the floor in front of the player and quickly jumping will boost the player's movement speed significantly. A hook can be used to achieve similar effect. Grappling the floor in front of the player and quickly jumping will boost the player's movement speed significantly.
If buffed correctly, the Psycho Knife can achieve more damage than the Zenith.
Even though Musket Balls have the lowest base damage of all bullets, they are adequate even against Hardmode enemies. Hardmode bosses, however, should be dealt with using better ammo.

Despite being called " Musket Balls", they can be used as ammunition for any weapon that requires bullets to fire. This is because they were introduced along with the Musket, which was one of the only guns in the game.
Acorns can be planted in any type of grass except Mushroom grass.
Grass seeds can only be planted on Dirt/Mud/Ash Blocks. They cannot be planted over other types of grass.
The Staff of Regrowth increases the number of seeds gathered when used on blooming herb plants, and has a chance to harvest an extra herb as well.
The Acorn is the only seed that can produce different species when planted on different blocks.

Mushroom grass can also be created by using the Clentaminator with Dark Blue Solution on Jungle grass. However, the seeds are available long before the Clentaminator, and Dark Blue Solution is not available until Truffle has appeared.

If the Mushroom grass can spread to enough blocks, it will create a Glowing Mushroom biome. Creating such a biome above surface level (and a house within it) is necessary to allow the Truffle NPC to spawn.
The Flying Knife has a tendency to fly through walls at times, usually when in small spaces.

The long returning arc can be ignored if the player leave the cursor between the knife and a wall. The knife will try to follow the cursor and keep bouncing off the wall, granting a much higher DPS than it would in open space. This is extremely useful against The Destroyer.
The Flying Knife can be useful for damaging both of The Twins at once; though this can cause them to go into their second phases both at the same time, which can be inconvenient.
If the player is Stoned by Medusa and already has the Flying Knife thrown-out, it can still be controlled to kill the Medusa or other enemies that approach.
It is possible to swap loadouts while continuing to control the Flying Knife.

The Flying Knife also emits a good deal of light during use, but it may be difficult to use considering its erratic movement. Like most piercing weapons, it is very effective against crowds and enemies with multiple segments, such as worms.

Due to the infinite flight nature of this throwing weapon, it can be used indefinitely even while sleeping in a Bed. This can be exploited to great effect in early Hardmode when defending against nocturnal enemies such as Werewolves that can open doors while still progressing time at 5 times its usual speed.
Selling the Bat Wings instead of the individual components will be more profitable. The wings sell for 8 GC, whereas the components sell for a collective 2 GC 90 SC.
An easier/faster way to get the Broken Bat Wing is by placing a Water Candle or consuming the Battle Potion because the Blood Moon and Solar Eclipse do not have a set spawn rate.

The Broken Bat Wing can technically be obtained before any Hardmode bosses have been defeated, as Jungle Temple enemies can spawn before the player gets inside the Temple, allowing the player to get Solar Tablet Fragments and, by extension, summon a Solar Eclipse before defeating any Hardmode boss. This makes the Bat Wings the second best pre- mech boss wings, after Fishron Wings.
The Sailor Hat is worn by the Pirate Corsair and the Sailor Shirt is worn by the Pirate Deckhand.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It is possible to re-use many arrows, especially Wooden Arrows and Flaming Arrows which have a high drop rate after being fired, as they have a chance to break, regardless of what they hit (arrows break as much against slimes as they do against bricks ).

Certain bows/repeaters such as Chlorophyte Shotbow and Tsunami shoot several arrows at once, consuming only one arrow when fired. All arrows fired from these bows will always break upon impact. All arrows fired from these bows will always break upon impact.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Wooden Arrows fired from the Molten Fury are considered to be Flaming Arrows and have a chance to be recoverable as such. The Sharanga's (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) arrows can be recovered as Spectral Arrows. The Sharanga's (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) arrows can be recovered as Spectral Arrows.

Jester's Arrows, Hellfire Arrows, Venom Arrows, and Vulcan Bolts (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) are always consumed and cannot be re-used. For this reason, it is impossible to have Vulcan Bolts in the inventory without hacking, because they only appear when the player fires the Vulcan Repeater (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), and are always destroyed on impact. For this reason, it is impossible to have Vulcan Bolts in the inventory without hacking, because they only appear when the player fires the Vulcan Repeater (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), and are always destroyed on impact.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Flaming Arrows, Frostburn Arrows, Cursed Arrows and Ichor Arrows, if they did not break, have a 2/3 chance to downgrade back to Wooden Arrow after being shot.
The Endless Quiver (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) provides an infinite supply of Wooden Arrows, and is therefore affected by arrow-converting effects.
Arrows are particularly powerful early game, where even a Copper Bow with simple Wooden Arrows will deal double the damage a sword can.
Wooden Arrows should be upgraded to Flaming Arrows or Frostburn Arrows, as that does not require a lot of resources yet greatly increases their usefulness.
The Magic Quiver substantially boosts the effectiveness of arrows, boosting damage, velocity, and knockback, and granting a chance not to consume them upon use.

In Journey Mode only 99 arrows are needed for Research and infinite duplication, rendering the Endless Quiver useless, as it needs 3996 Wooden Arrows to be used, only giving infinite Wooden Arrows. However, it does not need to be duplicated mid-combat like arrows do. However, it does not need to be duplicated mid-combat like arrows do.

The Apricot, Cherry, Grapefruit, Plum, Pomegranate, and Spicy Pepper are the only fruits that do not have unique recipes of their own. They can only be used to make Fruit Juice, Fruit Salad, and Ambrosia ; recipes that allow any fruit to be used.
The Band of Regeneration is useful for countering the Bleeding debuff, which is caused by e.g. Werewolves, Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Skeletron, and Angler Fish.
Magic users may want three Bands of Regeneration, in order to make two Mana Regeneration Bands and upgrade one to Celestial Cuffs.
Similar to Mother and Baby Slimes, the Black Slime blends slightly with the background of the Cavern layer, making it difficult to detect. As such, it can often catch players off-guard.
A Hunter Potion can be used to detect Black Slimes, as the slime will turn red in the dark.
Using a Night Owl Potion can counter the Darkness debuff Black Slimes inflict.
It is the only slime that does not drop its own color of Gel.
Despite Black Slimes inflicting the Darkness debuff, they do not drop the Blindfold.

A stack of 99 Jungle Spores sells for only 19 SC 80 CC, but crafting these into 12 Jungle Hats will instead net 10 GC 80 SC (about 54× the original). However, after defeating Skeletron, another craft can yield more than twice the money: combining the same amount of spores with Bones and Tissue Samples or Shadow Scales to craft Void Vaults (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Despite having 5% less mining power than the Laser Drill, the extra mining power is not needed to harvest any blocks currently in the game.
The Shroomite Digging Claw pairs well with Luminite pickaxes, as the claw mines faster, but the pickaxes have a greater range. Additionally, the pickaxes can mine Lihzahrd Bricks.
Luminite pickaxes are useful when paired with The Axe or Luminite Hamaxes.

The combination of their very fast attack speed and high damage (nearly double the next highest pickaxe's damage) allows them to kill most enemies with ease, reducing the need to switch to a dedicated weapon while mining.
Although their ore is in the loot-table, Oasis Crates never contain Copper and Tin Bars.
The crate resembles the sprites of Ancient set.
Although the crate contains the same primary items as a Sandstone Chest, it will not contain a Desert Minecart or an Encumbering Stone.
If utilizing Autopause, the Hallowed Mimic will not spawn until the game is unfrozen again. On Console, the Hallowed Mimic will not spawn unless Autopause is disabled.
Placing a Key of Light in a storage item other than a Chest (such as a Barrel ) will not spawn the Mimic.
The Hallowed Mimic does not have to be spawned in The Hallow; it can be summoned anywhere.

Placing a Key of Light in a Chest without closing it and directly opening another inventory interface (which is only possible if Autopause is disabled), such as that of another Chest, will not spawn the Mimic.

Unlike most accessories, informational accessories such as the Radar do not need to be equipped in an accessory slot. The Radar may be carried in the player's inventory without loss of functionality, unless equipped to a social slot. Additionally, the info it provides will be shared with players of the same team in multiplayer that are within 50 tiles. Keep in mind modifiers will no longer apply to the player when not equipped.

Real-life radar is a detection system that uses radio waves to determine the range, angle, or velocity of objects. It can be used to detect aircraft, ships, spacecraft, guided missiles, motor vehicles, weather formations, and terrain.
The Radar is the only item in Terraria that has a palindromic name.
Although representing different gem types, they all sell for 10 SC.
During Parties, most Gem Bunnies will be replaced by the party variant of normal Bunnies.
The best way to spawn any Gem Bunny is to make a town in the cavern layer. Same as other critters, they will spawn more frequently around NPCs.
The Bestiary entry for  Gem Bunnies: " These colorful rabbits made their way so deep, their reaction to magicked gems resulted in a coveted sparkling appearance. "
Destroying a Tesla Turret does not add any progress to the completion of the Martian Madness event. [2]
Dealing damage to the Tesla Turret delays its next attack by 1.5 seconds. [1]

The Tesla Turret's aiming is somewhat inaccurate; while it roughly targets the player, its projectiles shoot randomly within a certain spread. It is less accurate the closer the player is. For instance, if the player is less than 5 tiles away, the projectiles may be shot within a spread of more than 200°, meaning that they possibly shoot in the opposite direction of the player. Furthermore, the Tesla Turret is the most accurate when the player is aligned horizontally or vertically with it; it is the least accurate when the player is positioned diagonally to it. [1]
It takes two seconds for a Tesla Turret to spawn and begin operation. It is invulnerable during this period, but will deal contact damage. [1]

Over the course of the event, a large number of Tesla Turrets can appear if Martian Engineers are not properly dealt with. To avoid getting overwhelmed by their attacks, the player should focus on defeating Martian Engineers first before anything else.
It appears to be a weaponized Tesla coil, hence the name.
None of the Horseshoe Balloons can be crafted with an Obsidian Horseshoe. The original Lucky Horseshoe must be used.

Multiple double-jump items be worn at once for up to five extra jumps. However, equipping multiple balloons will not stack the jump height bonus, nor will stacking additional Horseshoes have any extra effect.
The Tsunami in a Bottle and Sharkron Balloon will not grant any additional bonuses when equipped alongside the Pink Horseshoe Balloon.
Spores home in on enemies within 15 tiles of their position.
Spores will not actively home in on destructible enemy projectiles or critters, but will explode and cause damage if they happen to make contact with them.
A maximum of 10 spores can be on-screen at any given time. Spores will also not spawn within 2 tiles of each other.
Spores cannot spawn from within liquids, but spores spawned elsewhere can home in on enemies that are in liquids.
Spores spawn slowly and move slowly, but are useful while the player stands still or remains in a small area, and can intercept incoming enemies easily. They are less useful while moving.

Like most weapons that travel through blocks, spores are especially useful when dealing with enemies that move through blocks, since spores can engage enemies before those enemies can reach the player. This can be especially useful in more confined cave systems, like the Dungeon and Underground Jungle, where players are often attacked through blocks.
Spores do not seem to trigger the teleportation effect of Hardmode Dark Casters in the Dungeon, thus being an efficient way of killing them.
Spores can be useful for automatically fending off minor attacks while building, or for AFK farms, as the spores will automatically damage enemies and are not hindered by blocks.
Ice blocks created by the Ice Rod can be used to spawn clusters of spores when in the air without any other blocks or walls.

The Herb Bag can appear in Surface Chests in stacks of 1–4, but higher amounts are rarer. If a chest contains any amount of Herb Bags, the chance it has just one is 84%, the chance of two is 12.33%, the chance of three is 3.33%, and the chance of four is just 0.33%.

Upon opening a Herb Bag, [1] a certain number of rolls will be performed, with each roll selecting a type of item and a stack size. The number of rolls is initially between 2 and 4, but has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to be additionally incremented by 1:
The Herb Bag is the best way to obtain herbs in early pre-Hardmode, especially in Expert / Master Mode, as some seeds are in biomes where enemies are stronger.
If two Herb Bags are found, they can be researched in Journey Mode to provide an infinite amount of herbs and seeds without having to grow and research them manually.
The bag's sprite shows a Daybloom, Moonglow, Waterleaf, and what appears to be a Fireblossom at the rear.
Kites can pass through solid blocks.
Kites can be used on non-Windy Days if the user maintains enough speed, but are more difficult to keep afloat.
Kites can be used while riding a mount, or while flying. However, the player will appear backwards while the kite is in use.
The Pigron Kite will be a random color based on the biomes in the world.
Kites can be used in reversed gravity, but will retain their normal orientation.
The three Hardmode jellyfish ( Green Jellyfish, Blood Jelly, and Fungo Fish ) do not have kite variants, unlike the pre-Hardmode Blue and Pink Jellyfish.
Fountains work in priority from right to left. The furthest fountain to the right of a group of fountains will take priority over the water color of the overlapping affected areas.
Water fountains will change the color of water when the player is within about 100 blocks of the fountain.
Water fountains alter the color of the rain produced by the Eyebrella, the eye color of Cute Fishron when the bonus is active, and the player's hair color while Biome Hair Dye is used.
The effects of fountains are purely cosmetic. They have no effect on fishing, etc.
Water Fountains will not color Waterfall Blocks, or their respective wall.
The tile sprites for the Cavern Water Fountain were included in the files along with the rest of the water fountains since 1.3.0.1, but were not properly utilized until 1.4.0.1.
Despite any given world only having one type of world evil, the Witch Doctor will still sell both types.
Despite the Hallow being a Hardmode feature, the Witch Doctor will sell the Hallowed Fountain at any time, even in pre-Hardmode.
After the fountains were re-sprited in 1.3.0.1, the Icy Water Fountain became the only fountain to have a colored part in its deactivated sprite.
Weapons will be oriented against the grain of the wood in the Weapon Rack. If the wood grain is diagonal to the left, the weapon placed will be diagonal to the right.
Pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on a Weapon Rack that has a weapon placed will swap the weapon with an item selected in the player's hotbar.
(Old-gen console version) If a Weapon Rack displaying a weapon is destroyed by an explosive, the weapon will disappear.
An item's size modifier will affect the size of the item on the Weapon Rack. A weapon with a Tiny modifier will be displayed at a considerably smaller size compared to a Massive one.
Favorited items cannot be placed on Weapon Racks. The player must unfavorite the item first in order to display it on a Weapon Rack.
(Old-gen console version) Crafting Weapon Racks can be a good way to make money. They require only Wood, which is abundant and usually worthless, but the Weapon Rack sells for 10 SC.
The Weapon Rack uses the same texture as the background of trophies.

Despite the Weapon Rack's tile ID having been changed in 1.4.0.1, its previous tile ID and function still remain in the source code. Its function still updates via adding item IDs, but both tiles' functions are different. [3]

Technically, when the Phantasm is being used, it spawns a bow projectile which can deal 100% of the weapon's damage (50 base damage) on contact. The bow projectile then spawns arrows (based on built-in fire rates) and Phantasm Arrows (when landing successful hits). [3]

The Phantasm will fire 2 volleys at each lower speed stage before reaching its maximum speed of once per 18 ticks. These 6 volleys will take a total of 24 ticks more than the Phantasm would have if it were permanently at max speed; thus, the Phantasm incurs a 0.4 second DPS penalty when it stops and restarts firing.

The Phantasm has great accuracy at range and fires projectiles extremely quickly. This makes it a great option against the Celestial Pillars from a distance; thanks to their low Defense, the Phantasm can destroy a single pillar within a few seconds.
The Phantasm is most effective against single targets, as the extra arrows do not have any piercing ability.
Try not to use piercing arrows, as they will give enemies brief periods of invincibility frames and many arrows will pass through without causing damage. The one exception is Luminite Arrows.

Due to the high rate of fire and low base damage of Phantasm Arrows, stacking extra armor penetration through Ichor and Betsy's Wrath is highly recommended. Ichor Arrows allow the player to apply Ichor without swapping weapons and recharging the Phantasm, as well as having good base damage. Ichor Arrows allow the player to apply Ichor without swapping weapons and recharging the Phantasm, as well as having good base damage.
Venom Arrows can theoretically improve the low damage of Phantasm Arrows, but are generally worse due to not inflicting Ichor.

With its natural ammo conservation, the Phantasm is the most ammo-efficient bow by a wide margin. Post- Moon Lord, Luminite Arrows are a fantastic option with the Phantasm. With its ammo conservation bonus, one Moon Lord kill can provide enough Luminite Arrows for more than two hours of continuous firing. Post- Moon Lord, Luminite Arrows are a fantastic option with the Phantasm. With its ammo conservation bonus, one Moon Lord kill can provide enough Luminite Arrows for more than two hours of continuous firing.
The Phantasm is the only arrow-consuming weapon in the game that has an inherent chance of ammo conservation.
The Phantasm is the only weapon made from Lunar Fragments that does not have a special tooltip.
The Phantasm and the Daybreak are the only weapons made from Lunar Fragments to not have a pillar's name in their name.
A "phantasm" is another name for a phantom.
Its male and female variants look identical.
In the release candidate version of 1.3, Skiphs' set and wings appear to be brown.
It is a common misconception that Skiphs' Paws are supposed to resemble the wings of Lugia, a Pokémon species, but Lugia does not have any claws and has more fingers.

In don't dig up and get fixed boi seeds, the Ash Wood Bow receives the following changes: Damage decreased from 10 to 6. Use time increased from 25 to 29. Damage decreased from 10 to 6. Use time increased from 25 to 29.

The Solar Blaze, Beetle Endurance, Warmth, and Paladin's Shield buffs calculate damage multiplicative with each other, while all other effects calculate additive. So firstly the raw damage is decreased by the banner 's effect (25% / 50% reduction) and Warmth Potion (30% reduction from cold sources), then the remaining damage is reduced by defense (50% / 75% / 100% ), the remaining damage is then reduced by all additive damage reduction, then by Beetle and Solar Flare armor's buff, and finally by Paladin's Shield. (Also, each step will round down the damage value, but the value cannot be less than 1.) [1] For example, in a Master (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) world, a cold-themed enemy somehow will deal 2000 damage to a player, the player wears a full set of Solar Flare armor (with its buff), a Worm Scarf, a Frozen Turtle Shell (with its buff on), with buff of Endurance, Warmth, a banner of that enemy, a teammate with Paladin's Shield and 140 defense. The banner reduces the damage by half to 1000. The Warmth buff reduces it by 30% to 700. The defense reduces it by 140 to 560. The Worm Scarf (17%), Endurance (10%), Solar Flare armor (12%) and Frozen Turtle Shell (25%) reduce damage additively, so they reduce it by 64% to 201.6, rounded down to 201. Solar Flare armor's buff reduces it by 20% to 160.8, rounded down to 160. A teammate's Paladin's Shield reduces it by 25%, so the player will take 120 damage. The teammate will take 40 damage, and it will be further reduced by that player's status (banner and Warmth will not take effect, though).
