The Guide's crafting tips for weapons show adjusted damage and critical strike chance based on any bonuses the player currently has equipped, such as the Molten armor 's set bonus. Unequip items that adjust damage/critical strike chance while speaking to the Guide to see the base values.

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the Guide does not have many useful tips after unlocking Hardmode, except hinting about destroying Altars and finding Souls of Light and Night underground.
Killing the Guide grants the player a minor luck (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) boost (see Luck § Ladybugs for details).

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Considering there are no downsides to having the Guide unhappy, the player could simply put the Guide anywhere in the world without any consequences. The best place for the Guide is the Glowing Mushroom biome with the Truffle, as he loves the Guide.

The Guide is replaced by various NPCs in secret world seeds (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) : The Demolitionist will be the starting NPC in for the worthy (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. The Party Girl will be the starting NPC in drunk worlds (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Merchant will be the starting NPC in not the bees (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. The Tax Collector (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) will be the starting NPC in don't dig up (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. The Demolitionist will be the starting NPC in for the worthy (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. The Party Girl will be the starting NPC in drunk worlds (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Merchant will be the starting NPC in not the bees (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. The Tax Collector (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) will be the starting NPC in don't dig up (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds.
For those who do use help from other sources rather than the Guide, his role is usually minimal. Otherwise, he lives up to his name, as a primary source of in-game hints and information.

One of the Guide's names is Andrew, named for Andrew Spinks (aka Redigit ), the lead developer of Terraria. The Green Cap is dropped if a Guide with that name ( or any name) is killed. The Guide’s Shimmered form is a reference to Redigit’s avatar. [10] The Green Cap is dropped if a Guide with that name ( or any name) is killed. The Guide’s Shimmered form is a reference to Redigit’s avatar. [10]
Redigit said during an AMA on Reddit that he created the Guide Voodoo Doll so players could get revenge on him for always opening the door. [11]
The Guide is depicted in two paintings, "Guide Picasso" and "The Creation of the Guide".

– According to the Terraria lore pages, there is an organization called "Order of the Guide", whose purpose is to preserve old legends and knowledge. It is likely that the Guide is a member of this order. This is referenced in-game after beating the Wall of Flesh, with any new Guides that spawn in afterward referencing their predecessor suddenly bursting into flames. This is referenced in-game after beating the Wall of Flesh, with any new Guides that spawn in afterward referencing their predecessor suddenly bursting into flames.
In the Nintendo 3DS version, the Guide mentions the St. Patrick's Day event, even though it is not implemented there.

In the past Redigit has said the Guide is the Wall of Flesh [12], the brother of the ninja inside King Slime [13], the great-grandson of the Nymph [14], and the son of the Moon Lord [15]. These statements were most likely jokes [16] and are not considered official lore. [17]

The Guide says that he has much in common with the Zoologist and the Clothier. This may be referring to the fact that they are all cursed with some sort of transformation that is out of their control (if the Guide is indeed the Wall of Flesh).
According to the Voodoo Demon's Bestiary entry, the Guide is said to be the "chosen one whose soul is linked with the world's guardian himself", most likely referring to the Wall of Flesh.
The Guide has the first Bestiary entry.
Palladium, being cobalt's counterpart, is more medieval Europe based, with knight-like helmets, weapons, and armor.
Real-life palladium is actually a lustrous white metal, and is nowhere near the color in Terraria. However, many palladium salts have a bright orange color.
Clay can be a natural blocker of the Corruption, Crimson or Hallow. All 3 biomes cannot spread through Clay and it can thus make a natural barrier against spreading.

Clay can be painted with Brown Paint to give it a similar appearance to dirt. This can prove useful for builders who want to protect their biome without having different colored dirt, or to create patches of "dirt" that grass will not grow on.
On the Old-gen console version, Chests will gain a yellow outline upon getting close to them to signify they are within range to be opened.
On the Wii U version, when renaming a Chest, the text box will resemble the options on the last NPC spoken to.

Before opening a Chest outside of a Dungeon in a Hardmode world, it would be advisable to shoot it with a ranged weapon or summon a minion, because the Chest might really be a Mimic. If it is, it will take damage and start chasing the player. As Chests are placed furniture items, while Mimics are spawned entities, the player may also view how the Chest is placed in order to distinguish one from the other. If it appears to be positioned off-grid, or partly suspended above the ground, it is in fact a Mimic, as its spawn does not snap it into the grid like placed Chests are. As Chests are placed furniture items, while Mimics are spawned entities, the player may also view how the Chest is placed in order to distinguish one from the other. If it appears to be positioned off-grid, or partly suspended above the ground, it is in fact a Mimic, as its spawn does not snap it into the grid like placed Chests are.
The pirates' Golden Chest and Golden Dresser, along with the Money Trough (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), are the only storage items dropped by an enemy.
The Golf Chest (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is the only natural Chest in the game that can be bought (aside from portable storage items).

Due to the mechanics of random number generators, it is possible for a world to generate without a specific loot. However, this is very rare, because there are many Chests in a world, and even if treasure is not generated naturally, it can still be obtained by fishing for crates.

On low quality video settings, only 25 Rain Clouds will produce rain in an area. On medium quality, 112 Rain Clouds will produce rain. Additionally, the rain starts fading sooner on lower quality settings.
If the block is made inactive via an Actuator, the rain animation will still be there.
A solid block underneath a Rain Cloud stops the rain from falling, while a hammered block does not.
Small pools of water usually generate around these blocks.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) If Echo Coating is applied on a Rain Cloud, only the block itself is affected. The rainfall effect will still be visible.
The rain effect helps locating Floating Islands and Floating Lakes.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Rain Clouds can be used at the bottom of hellevators to avoid dying from fall damage.
This item can be greatly helpful in making money early on in the game, as it is very easy to craft and sells for a sizeable amount, totaling 1 GC per 5 Bunnies.
Cobalt ore spawns at any depth in the Underground and Cavern layers.

Actual Cobalt is a poisonous, magnetic metal (though it is actually a key part of vitamin B12, which is necessary for living beings and has extremely low toxicity). It is named after the Kobold, at that time thought of as a mischievous spirit; this is because smelting its ores were difficult and would often release toxic fumes. Pure cobalt is an element found on the periodic table just after iron, and is actually silver-like in color, however it is never found pure in nature. Its primary historic use was as a pigment used especially in glass or porcelain, as it turns a rich "cobalt blue" when in the compound form of smaltite, made of cobalt, iron, and nickel combined with arsenic. This made cobalt, along with lapis lazuli, one of the few mineral blue pigments, and therefore was an extremely valuable commodity.
Several Cobalt items in the game are Japanese-themed, namely the Cobalt Naginata, Cobalt Armor and the Cobalt Sword which resembles a katana.
Despite being named after (and resembling) the material, the Cobalt Shield cannot be made from ore/bars.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Cobalt Ore's inventory sprite is the same as the one for Adamantite Ore, except rotated and colored blue.

The defeat of a pillar is announced in a status message : " Your mind goes numb... " – first pillar defeated " You are overwhelmed with pain... " – second pillar defeated " Otherworldly voices linger around you... " – third pillar defeated " Impending doom approaches... " – fourth pillar defeated " Your mind goes numb... " – first pillar defeated " You are overwhelmed with pain... " – second pillar defeated " Otherworldly voices linger around you... " – third pillar defeated " Impending doom approaches... " – fourth pillar defeated
Celestial creatures do not drop coins, even with the Lucky Coin (or its derivatives) equipped. They also do not drop Presents during Christmas, Goodie Bags during Halloween, or Biome Keys.

In a singleplayer world, the Celestial Pillars will not disappear when the player dies or exits Terraria completely. The pillars must be destroyed in the world, otherwise they will stay in the world indefinitely.
The Moon Lord may not be summoned via the Celestial Sigil while the pillars are still active.
Exiting the world after the " Impending doom approaches... " status message has appeared will cancel the event and prevent the Moon Lord from spawning.

Most other in-game events cannot naturally occur while the Lunar Events are active. This includes the Blood Moon, Goblin Invasion, Pirate Invasion, and Solar Eclipse. However, Slime Rain can still occur, and the Traveling Merchant and other NPCs can spawn as usual.
Like with all other events, sleeping is disabled while the Lunar Events are active.
It is a good idea to defeat the pillar of the player's preferred class first, as that pillar will provide the most effective weaponry for the rest.

It can be helpful to launch the Lunar Events even if the player does not have the means to survive them fully yet as gradually defeating pillars grants access to stronger equipment. Even if the fight against the Moon Lord is lost, the player will be much better prepared than before.

Because neither sentries nor the pillars despawn or leave when the player dies or leaves, as enemies do, sentries can continue attacking a pillar with no players nearby, as long as the shield is already gone.

Flying in and out of the celestial area, letting only a limited number of enemies spawn at a time, can prevent getting overwhelmed. The shield will still be shattered eventually. Once it is broken, the pillar can be attacked from safe distance, e.g., from above (with any suitable ranged weapon or melee projectile ) or from the side (with a long-lasting, gravity-unaffected projectile such as the Terra Blade 's Terra Beam). Flying mounts or the Static Hook can be useful for hovering mid-air.

Setting up Teleporters or acquiring the Magic Conch before starting can immensely speed up the fight. Though it is very difficult to determine exactly where the pillars will spawn, the two closest ones will be around one-fifth of the map away from the center, and the furthest about three-fifths. On subsequent fights, the pillars will spawn in approximately the same locations as before, though which pillar is where may be randomized. Unlike during other events, the pylon network is enabled, allowing for quick travel across the map.
The music played during the Lunar Events was made available as part of the second Terraria Soundtrack volume under the title "Lunar Boss" despite not being implemented in the game.
This is one of the only two events in the game whose enemies do not drop coins, along with the Old One's Army.
The Lunar Events are also known as Lunar Apocalypse [1] and Lunar Invasion [2].
The Bestiary page for the Town Dog depicts the Labrador dog breed by default.

Early in development, it was planned for all hooks to grapple to trees normally. However, this feature was later scrapped, due to Redigit finding that it "interfered with gameplay in an annoying way". [1] This feature has since been added as the Squirrel Hook's unique feature.

The Squirrel Hook's tooltip, ' In the tree, part of the tree', is a reference to the fourth episode of the fifth season of the American fantasy animated television series Adventure Time, " Up a Tree," in which the phrase is chanted repeatedly by a squirrel.
Some parts of bent palm trees do not align with the tile grid; these parts do not allow the Squirrel Hook to attach to them. This is likely to avoid visual issues.
Unlike many other flying enemies, Gastropods will enter water to chase the player and will continue firing per usual.
Gastropod lasers will keep traveling as long as they are in sight.

Gastropods have a short firing animation in which they open their shell before firing a laser from their mouth. If they are hit during this period, it is canceled, and their laser attack does not occur.
Gastropods' lasers ignore the Shroomite / Vortex armor 's set bonus, able to target players when they are invisible, despite not moving to them while doing so.
Gastropods, unlike most slimes, cannot drop the Slime Staff.
Despite being a slime, killing a Gastropod does not contribute to the Gelatin World Tour achievement.

Newer Hardmode players may want to avoid the Hallow's surface at night entirely, as Gastropods fire frequently, spawn often, and their lasers are high-speed and difficult to dodge, especially since multiple can appear in the vicinity. In Expert (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), this is mostly dismissed by the Royal Gel 's availability.
Gastropods drop much more Gel than any other non- boss slime, making them useful for gathering Flamethrower or Elf Melter ammo.
Weapons with high rates of fire like the Bee Gun can constantly hit Gastropods, leaving them near-defenseless.
Real-life gastropoda are a class of mollusk that includes snails and slugs.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Sometimes Gastropods can be seen flying in the Hallow background at night as ambiance.

The Hotdog's tooltip ' Hot diggity!' may be a reference to the 1956 pop song " Hot Diggity " by Perry Como, or lyrics from "Hot Dog!", the ending theme for the animated preschool television series Mickey Mouse Clubhouse, sung by alternative rock band They Might Be Giants.
Explosives cannot be placed on top of each other. However, other blocks can be placed on them, and more Explosives can be placed on those.
Due to invincibility frame, multiple Explosives triggered at once can only deal damage to the same enemy once.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) If a player is killed by Explosives detonated by them, they will not lose their coins.

An Explosives block within the blast radius of another will not be activated, therefore chain reactions cannot be created with Explosives. Rather, the second Explosives will simply drop, as with other blocks.
Explosives which have been actuated will still explode when triggered.
Explosives, despite their name and crafting recipe, do not fulfill the Demolitionist 's requirement to move in.
The death message that appears when the player is killed by naturally spawned explosives will read that they were killed by their own explosives.

Even though it is based on a real-life flintlock pistol, it more closely resembles a revolver ( comparison ). In reality, the single-shot rate of fire of flintlock pistols and muskets are very similar; however, in Terraria, the Flintlock Pistol's speed is 16 (Very fast), compared to the Musket 's speed of 32 (Slow).
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The Flintlock Pistol is one of the only guns with no knockback, along with the Clockwork Assault Rifle, Star Cannon, and Minishark.

The Flintlock Pistol is one of the 11 guns in Terraria based on a real gun, the others being the Chain Gun, Handgun, Musket, Quad-Barrel Shotgun (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Red Ryder (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Revolver (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Shotgun, Sniper Rifle, Tactical Shotgun, and Uzi.
An apparition is a name for a supernatural phenomenon, such as a ghost or phantom.
Most demonstration animations on this wiki use the Stone Slab and Stone Slab Wall as a neutral background.
Items crafted from Vortex Fragments have a similar color scheme to the Moon Lord and the Luminite Bars.
The item name used in most spoilers prior to its introduction was Blackhole Fragment.
The Eyeball Spring appears to be the Eyezor's detached eye.
Shroomite Plating is tied with the Living Demon Fire Block for having the longest block crafting tree.
The Night Vision Helmet's effect on lighting will not trigger if it is placed in the social helmet slot. It must be worn in place of a helmet armor piece.
The effect has the same strength as that of the Night Owl buff, granted by the Night Owl Potion. The Night Vision Helmet does not stack with Night Owl.
Dark Mummies and Blood Mummies can drop the Megaphone and Blindfold at the same time. The chance of these two 1/100 events happening is 1/10000 (0.01%).
Mummies only require a respective sand block (regular Sand, Ebonsand, Crimsand, or Pearlsand Block ) to spawn, it does not necessarily have to be in a Desert biome. [1]

Dark, Blood and Light Mummies can easily be farmed for their shards by making a section of Desert evil or Hallow, or making an artificial Desert. All that is necessary is a one-wide flat surface of Pearlsand, Ebonsand, or Crimsand.
The head of the Shadow Mummy looks like a Skeleton 's Skull.

The mummies in Terraria are bound incorrectly: In Ancient Egypt, the feet of the mummies were bound together and their hands were bound on their sides. However, in Terraria (and almost every other fictional work), the hands and feet of the mummies are unbound so that they can move freely.
Paints and coatings on the existing block will be removed upon block swapping.
Block swapping an inactive block (e.g. produced with Actuators ) will make the newly placed block to remain inactive.

Block Swap can be used to extract ore veins that are hanging over a cliff and would cause the player to fall when broken. This does not grant the Ooo! Shiny! achievement. This does not grant the Ooo! Shiny! achievement.

Chlorophyte Ore can be swapped for Mud Blocks to collect the Chlorophyte while allowing it to grow back. This does not grant the Photosynthesis achievement. This does not grant the Photosynthesis achievement.
Blocks beneath a Demon Altar or Crimson Altar can be swapped without destroying the Altar.
All Tombstones within a rectangular area of 170×125 [3] tiles centered on the player are considered when determining whether the area is a Graveyard biome.

A large amount of Ecto Mist coats surfaces in Graveyard biomes, which can obscure items like Pressure Plates. This could previously be toggled on and off with the "Blood and Gore" setting, but this appears to have been patched.
While night -only enemies can spawn at daytime through the graveyard, nocturnal bosses still cannot be spawned during the day.
NPCs in worlds with Hardcore characters will drop tombstones when they are killed, making it possible to build a Graveyard without sacrificing a character.

Although NPCs will complain when in a Graveyard, it does not actually affect their happiness at all. As a Graveyard is always in combination with a different biome, their happiness value will be based on the other present biome. However, the Painter will not sell the paintings Daylight, First Encounter, Good Morning, Underground Reward, Through the Window, Place Above the Clouds, and Sky Guardian if he is spoken to in a Graveyard. However, the Painter will not sell the paintings Daylight, First Encounter, Good Morning, Underground Reward, Through the Window, Place Above the Clouds, and Sky Guardian if he is spoken to in a Graveyard.

Normally, certain enemies with the Fighter AI cannot open doors and Tall Gates unless during a Blood Moon. In a Graveyard, these enemies have a 1/60 (1.67%) chance to open a door or Tall Gate even outside of a Blood Moon. [4]
The Happy! buff is revoked in a Graveyard.
An underground Graveyard will generate Ecto Mist, but not spawn its enemies.

Avoid letting Tombstones accumulate around one's base/spawn point during the early game due to the large number of enemies spawning in a Graveyard, including the particularly powerful Ghosts. This is especially true for Mediumcore players, as generating Tombstones over and over on the same spawnpoint can lead to a softlock situation, where it becomes almost impossible to retrieve items without being attacked. This is especially true for Mediumcore players, as generating Tombstones over and over on the same spawnpoint can lead to a softlock situation, where it becomes almost impossible to retrieve items without being attacked.
Making a flat spread-out tree-free graveyard easily accessible early on is a simple way to farm Abigail's Flower which is a powerful early summon.

Using Sunflowers around common death spots such as arenas can help to prevent a Graveyard from being created without the need to constantly mine Tombstones. Another option is to mine one-tile gaps in the ground and platforms such that Tombstones cannot be placed when they drop.

The Dryad sells Crimson Seeds in a Corrupt world and Corrupt Seeds in a Crimson world during Hardmode when housed in a Graveyard biome, meaning one can get both evil biomes in one world without bringing some items from other worlds.
This accessory's effects are identical to that of the Magma Skull.

The Lava Charm, Magma Skull, Molten Skull Rose, Lava Waders, and Terraspark Boots all stack with the Molten Charm to increase lava immunity by 7 seconds each. The Demonic Hellcart also gives an additional 7 seconds. This leads to a maximum total of 49 seconds. Of these, only the Demonic Hellcart is not itself a Lava Charm upgrade.
The Titan Potion can help deal with large crowds of enemies, pushing them away for a while.
The added knockback is helpful against the Wall of Flesh as it makes it easier to keep the high-damage The Hungry at bay.
The Titan Potion's buff icon could be a reference to the Titans of Greek mythology, and how they possessed great power.
Due to having Bones in its recipe, the Titan Potion cannot be transmuted in shimmer before defeating Skeletron.

The chance for a Grasshopper to spawn is 1/100 (1%) when destroying short grass plants, and 1/50 (2%) when destroying tall grass plants. It can only spawn if there are no more than 4 other Grasshoppers currently nearby. [1]
Because they follow the Slime AI, they can float in water.
In the Old-gen console version, Grasshoppers are completely immune to damage from players.

The falling star effects from the Star Cloak, Mana Cloak (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Bee Cloak, and Star Veil do not stack with each other. The quantity and damage of falling stars from the effect will not be affected by having multiple equipped.
The Star Veil's invincibility frame-increasing effect does not stack with the Cross Necklace.

The increase of the invincibility frame is different under different conditions: By default, it increases the invincibility frame from 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second) to 1.33 seconds (4/3 seconds). If taking exactly 1 damage, the invincibility frame is increased from 0.33 seconds (1/3 of a second) to 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second). When stacked with the Black Belt, Master Ninja Gear, Brain of Confusion (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and the Shadow Dodge (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) / Holy Protection (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) buff, it extends the dodge invincibility period by 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second) to a full 2 seconds. See Invincibility frames § Invincibility frame length for the full list. By default, it increases the invincibility frame from 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second) to 1.33 seconds (4/3 seconds). If taking exactly 1 damage, the invincibility frame is increased from 0.33 seconds (1/3 of a second) to 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second). If taking exactly 1 damage, the invincibility frame is increased from 0.33 seconds (1/3 of a second) to 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second). When stacked with the Black Belt, Master Ninja Gear, Brain of Confusion (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and the Shadow Dodge (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) / Holy Protection (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) buff, it extends the dodge invincibility period by 0.67 seconds (2/3 of a second) to a full 2 seconds. See Invincibility frames § Invincibility frame length for the full list.
Both of its constituent parts are unique drops from Mimics.
The Star Veil is recommended for melee players, who are more likely to take damage than ranged or magic classes.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The Star Cloak 's, Bee Cloak 's, and Star Veil's projectiles are called "Hallow Stars".

At every dusk (7:30 PM), or each time the world is loaded, the spawn rate of Butterflies /Ladybugs and Stinkbugs are set to a random value. Below is the detailed info: [2] For Butterflies/Ladybugs and Stinkbugs, there are two parameters: butterflyChance and stinkBugChance, the spawn rate of Butterflies/Ladybugs and Stinkbugs, respectively. For Butterflies/Ladybugs and Stinkbugs, there are two parameters: butterflyChance and stinkBugChance, the spawn rate of Butterflies/Ladybugs and Stinkbugs, respectively.

Ladybugs have a bait power of 17%. In Italian culture, the number 17 is considered unlucky. When viewed as the Roman numeral, XVII, it is then changed anagrammatically to VIXI, which in the Latin language translates to "I lived", the perfect implying "My life is over".
Real life ladybugs being associated with good luck is a commonly-held superstition throughout many world cultures, in tandem with the belief that killing one will bring misfortune.
The Mud Bud is stated to be Redigit 's favorite pet item in the game. [1]
The pet was introduced following a suggestion by a player. [2]
The pet appears similar to both of Plantera's map icons.

The name Plantero could be a portmanteau of Plantera and sombrero, referencing the pet's hat. Alternatively, it could be seen as a masculine equivalent of Plantera, given that the vowel at the end of a word usually indicates its grammatical gender in languages such as Italian or Spanish.

When compared to Titanium armor, Adamantite armor grants higher offensive stats overall: The magic set for Adamantite provides less damage boosts than Titanium, but does offer more critical strike chance and mana boosts when the set bonus is considered. It also provides 2 more defense. The melee set for Adamantite provides more damage bonuses, (melee speed, and movement speed with set bonus) and critical strike bonuses when compared to Titanium. It also provides 1 more defense. The ranger set for Adamantite provides less damage boosts over Titanium, but has higher critical strike chance, and has a 25% chance not to consume ammo (set bonus). It also provides 2 more defense. The magic set for Adamantite provides less damage boosts than Titanium, but does offer more critical strike chance and mana boosts when the set bonus is considered. It also provides 2 more defense. The melee set for Adamantite provides more damage bonuses, (melee speed, and movement speed with set bonus) and critical strike bonuses when compared to Titanium. It also provides 1 more defense. The ranger set for Adamantite provides less damage boosts over Titanium, but has higher critical strike chance, and has a 25% chance not to consume ammo (set bonus). It also provides 2 more defense.

While Adamantite armor might be chosen because it provides higher offensive stats than Titanium armor, it does not provide the highest offensive stats available. If the goal is simply to maximize damage output, there are better options: Mythril armor is significantly stronger for melee users, though it has lower defense. Ranged users (and melee users who do not wish to use Mythril armor) can maximize their offensive bonuses by equipping a Frost Breastplate and Mythril Greaves while keeping the Adamantite Mask or Helmet in the head slot. Adamantite armor is a decent choice for magic users, who might appreciate the full set's defense and mana cost reduction. Those who are more confident in their dodging skills can maximize their offense with a set consisting of Adamantite Headgear, Mystic Robe, and Forbidden Treads (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Mythril armor is significantly stronger for melee users, though it has lower defense. Ranged users (and melee users who do not wish to use Mythril armor) can maximize their offensive bonuses by equipping a Frost Breastplate and Mythril Greaves while keeping the Adamantite Mask or Helmet in the head slot. Adamantite armor is a decent choice for magic users, who might appreciate the full set's defense and mana cost reduction. Those who are more confident in their dodging skills can maximize their offense with a set consisting of Adamantite Headgear, Mystic Robe, and Forbidden Treads (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

In Expert Mode, Crystal Assassin armor (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is effectively stronger than Adamantite armor because it frees up an accessory slot that would normally be occupied by the Shield of Cthulhu, allowing an extra offensive accessory (such as an emblem or any other class-specific accessory) to be worn instead.

Melee players may not find it worth it to upgrade to Hallowed armor, as Adamantite armor has the same amount of defense (50) and higher raw damage increase. However, it could be worth crafting the Hallowed armor for the Holy Protection buff, if the player is going for a "tank style" of play.
Both the headgear and helmet armor sets have more defense than the equivalent sets of Titanium armor, which makes it the only original armor to have more defense than its alternative.

While the Adamantite Mask appears to provide the greatest face protection and looks similar to many other melee-specialized masks, it has lower defense than the Adamantite Helmet and provides ranged bonuses.
The full Adamantite set equipped with the helmet looks similar to Crimson armor.
Any liquid triggers the boost, including lava and honey.

While Cute Fishron is boosted, its eyes display a glowing effect that fades as the boost expires. The color of the glow matches the water color in the present biome. If the water color in the area is changed via a Water Fountain, Cute Fishron's eyes will become that color. During a Blood Moon, Cute Fishron's eyes glow red everywhere, regardless of the biome.
Cute Fishron has a comparatively slow turning speed compared to other mounts when its speed bonus is not activated.

In addition to the standard intended methods, Cute Fishron's boost can be triggered in other creative ways: Use a Water Bucket (or a Bottomless Water Bucket ) to pour water over the character while on this mount in midair. The more immersed Cute Fishron is kept, the higher the boost, up to the maximum 80 mph. The water must be used on the player's own body; pouring it over the head or tail of the mount will not work. Note that the water will settle on the surface, creating many small pools. Place Bubbles filled with liquid in the world. Ideally, place honey in these bubbles, as flying through honey with a Cute Fishron mount not only increases the player's speed and damage but also health regeneration. Have another player use the Water Gun on the character, inflicting the Wet debuff. Repeatedly use a Rod of Discord to keep the character's health below 50%. Waiting for rain to start falling before fighting difficult bosses or events. Use a Water Bucket (or a Bottomless Water Bucket ) to pour water over the character while on this mount in midair. The more immersed Cute Fishron is kept, the higher the boost, up to the maximum 80 mph. The water must be used on the player's own body; pouring it over the head or tail of the mount will not work. Note that the water will settle on the surface, creating many small pools. Place Bubbles filled with liquid in the world. Ideally, place honey in these bubbles, as flying through honey with a Cute Fishron mount not only increases the player's speed and damage but also health regeneration. Have another player use the Water Gun on the character, inflicting the Wet debuff. Repeatedly use a Rod of Discord to keep the character's health below 50%. Waiting for rain to start falling before fighting difficult bosses or events.
Due to its outstanding mobility and combat increases while boosted, the mount is highly effective for boss fights. An underwater arena with a Neptune's Shell is a solid setup for many fights.

While it has the ability of infinite flight, Cute Fishron has sluggish mobility as an aerial mount, as it takes a long time to turn when its speed bonus is not active. If air mobility is preferred (such as during a boss fight), it is recommended to use wings, the UFO Mount, or the Expert Mode -exclusive Witch's Broom instead. If the player has an equipped accessory or full armor gear that enables dashing, quick and sharp turns can be done by dismounting mid-air, dashing to the opposite direction, and re-equipping the mount. If the player has an equipped accessory or full armor gear that enables dashing, quick and sharp turns can be done by dismounting mid-air, dashing to the opposite direction, and re-equipping the mount.
Although the UFO Mount is slightly faster ( 41 mph vs. 40 mph ), it cannot be used in liquids, whereas Cute Fishron has an advantage in them.
Because of the speed penalty for touching blocks, Cute Fishron is not suited for confined spaces.
Its speed while touching blocks is well-suited for placing a line of blocks in front of the player.
This mount works well with the Frozen Turtle Shell and the Frozen Shield, as they allow the player to stay at or below 50% life for the damage and speed boost much more safely.
The tooltip of the Cute Fishron Mount buff, "Just don't make it crawl.", refers to the extreme decrease of mobility on land.
When activated while standing on platforms, Cute Fishron will crawl on them, however, it cannot "land" on them and start crawling, as it will phase through them like any infinite flight mount.
Unlike its Javelin counterpart, it does not stick to enemies or inflict the Penetrated debuff.
Crafting and selling Bone Throwing Knives is the most efficient way to get money from Sturdy Fossils.
Spawning the cloud directly above a one-block thick floor will allow the rain to pass through the block, hitting enemies below it.
The cloud spawns 5.45 raindrops per second. [1]
The raindrops dissipate after 5 seconds, [1] giving them a maximum range of 96.5 tiles.
The Crimson Rod can be good at taking out large groups of enemies, especially during events, such as the Goblin Army or Blood Moon.
The Crimson Rod alone can take out most pre-Hardmode bosses faster than most magic weapons.
The Crimson Rod is the counterpart to the Corruption 's Vilethorn, as the Vilethorn is the magic weapon drop from Shadow Orbs.
Moon Leech Clots take 1.5 seconds to reach the Moon Lord's mouth.

Moon Leech Clots will always reach the Moon Lord's mouth in the same amount of time. They travel toward it at a variable rate, remaining almost stationary if the Moon Lord is in its default position behind the player. As a result of this, though it may seem counterintuitive, it is actually beneficial to be closer to the mouth to destroy Moon Leech Clots, as they will not move away as quickly.
They look identical to the Living Ultrabright Fire Block 's inventory sprite.
Snatchers do not require a Jungle biome to spawn; they can spawn on any surface Jungle grass block.

The Snatcher differs from the Man Eater in the following ways: The Snatcher's body color is a green vine, as opposed to the brown/pinkish vine of the Man Eater's. The "head" of a Man Eater also has a red tinge along the jaw. Snatchers do not drop Vines or Ancient Cobalt armor, whereas Man Eaters do. Snatchers can extend their stems only about half as far as Man Eaters. Snatchers spawn in the surface Jungle, while Man Eaters spawn in the Underground Jungle. The Snatcher's body color is a green vine, as opposed to the brown/pinkish vine of the Man Eater's. The "head" of a Man Eater also has a red tinge along the jaw. Snatchers do not drop Vines or Ancient Cobalt armor, whereas Man Eaters do. Snatchers can extend their stems only about half as far as Man Eaters. Snatchers spawn in the surface Jungle, while Man Eaters spawn in the Underground Jungle.
When lit on fire with weapons such as the Sunfury, their erratic movement patterns may cause them to reveal hidden caves with their light.
Players should be cautious in the Jungle, as a hidden Snatcher can catch them by surprise. Although they are weaker than Man Eaters, they should not be underestimated.
Caution should be advised even when the player seems to be out of the Snatcher's reach, as they can extend their stems and thus improve their reach rapidly.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Mining the block that a Snatcher is rooted on kills it instantly; however, this method of dispatching a Snatcher never yields any dropped items.
The Bestiary entry for the Snatcher: " A sharp-toothed plant with a taste for human flesh. It has the ability to hide inside the mud and reach over great distances. "
The number of projectiles that can exist at the same time is capped at 1000. [1]
If a player dies from a projectile, its name will be included in the death message, e.g.: " <Player name> was slain by Flaming Scythe. "

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Some projectiles fired by the player, e.g. bullets, arrows, and darts, can be reflected by certain enemies and will then deal damage to the player. See List of reflected projectiles for the complete list.

Teal Pressure Pads (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are activated by all projectiles that "belong" to the player (like those from weapons, as well as minions, sentries, pets, and light pets) and cannot go through blocks, in addition to certain other projectiles (like Falling Stars ).
Relics, like trophies, are purely vanity items and have no effect on the bosses they are dropped from.
The Skeletron, Skeletron Prime, Lunatic Cultist, and Ogre Relics all appear to be off-center due to their relics having an odd number of pixels and the relic base itself having an even number.
The fluorescent behavior can be observed when placing a Torch near an unlit relic, such as during the night.
Like Stone and Mud, relics must be painted with Deep Paint in order to show any noticeable color.
When painted, only the base is affected by the paint, the floating statue of the boss is not.
The Dark Mage and Ogre only drop their relics during Tier 3 of the Old One's Army event.
All relics are referred to as MasterTrophy in their internal names.
When a Nail is fired in the air with the Archery buff in velocity, it actually takes 60% of the buff's modifier longer to fall instead of speeding up.
If an enemy dies (or one of the Moon Lord 's eyes closes) while Nails are still stuck into it, these Nails will pop out, sticking to other surfaces or enemies and exploding like usual.
The Nail Gun receives the specialized boosts from the Shroomite Helmet.
In real life, a nail gun is a type of hammer used to drive nails into a surface by firing it using compressed air, electromagnetism, flammable gas, or explosive charges in some cases.

Technically, the Enchanted Moondial's cooldown is set to 8 days right after activation, and is reduced by 1 day at 7:30 PM each day. [2] This means that: Since the Enchanted Moondial accelerates time to 7:30 PM the following day, this cooldown is reduced to 7 days after its effect ends. The cooldown can be sped up by time-accelerating methods. Since the Enchanted Moondial accelerates time to 7:30 PM the following day, this cooldown is reduced to 7 days after its effect ends. The cooldown can be sped up by time-accelerating methods.
Alternative methods to accelerate time are sleeping in a Bed and the Power Menu in Journey Mode.
Skipping to dusk after defeating a boss will immediately start a Lantern Night.
The low-health shield does not stack with the Frozen Turtle Shell, and the team damage redirection effect does not stack with the Paladin's Shield or the Hero Shield.
When the player's health is between 25% and 50%, they both give the Paladin's Shield buff to nearby teammates and get the Ice Barrier buff at the same time.

Although technically available later in the game than the Ankh Shield, the Frozen Shield is a great alternative because of its defensive abilities and much simpler crafting tree, especially if debuff resistance is not necessary.

The Frozen Shield can be considered more effective than the Ankh Shield during single-player boss fights, given that most boss encounters do not cause debuffs that can be prevented by the Ankh Shield, and the Paladin's Shield effect will not cause the player to take increased damage.
With the Warding modifier, the Frozen Shield has 10 defense and a 25% damage reduction when the player is below 50% health, making it an extraordinarily strong defense accessory in single-player.
If obtainable, these would have the second highest listed damage of any tool, beaten only by the Butcher's Chainsaw.

With current methods, it is impossible to hack these items into a character's inventory using external editors, as they will disappear from that character's inventory as soon as they load into a world.

Fire explosions have a base damage of 150 and deal a base knockback of 15 (Insane) (which is only affected by melee damage bonuses). The dash attack also has a base damage of 150 and deals a base knockback of 9 (Very strong) (which is affected by melee damage bonuses, melee critical strike bonuses, and knockback bonuses from Titan Glove and Titan Potion ). [1] Both of these cannot receive debuff bonuses from Flasks or Hellfire bonus from the Magma Stone or its upgrades. Both of these cannot receive debuff bonuses from Flasks or Hellfire bonus from the Magma Stone or its upgrades.
Holding the Psycho Knife will increase the damage of fire explosions and dash attack, and also increase the critical strike chance of the dash attack.
Taking fall damage also triggers the explosion discharge and consumes one charge.

The dash causes the player to move at 52 mph. This dash will cause the player to move 11 mph faster than the Dungeon Guardian and 1 mph faster than the dash of Biome Mimics when the player is too far away. This dash will cause the player to move 11 mph faster than the Dungeon Guardian and 1 mph faster than the dash of Biome Mimics when the player is too far away.
The dash effect of the armor overrides the dash effect of the Tabi, Master Ninja Gear, and Shield of Cthulhu accessories.
The Endurance Potion, Frozen Turtle Shell, and Worm Scarf 's damage reduction can stack with this armor.
The Solar Blaze buff tooltip still displays "Damage taken reduced by 30%" even though the actual effect is 20%.
The shield can also be dyed using the chest dye slot.
Like all armors made from Luminite, equipping Solar Flare armor makes the player emit light, in this case, red. Light radius increases with the number of pieces equipped.

In comparison to Beetle armor, Solar Flare armor provides slightly more defense than Beetle armor with the Beetle Shell. While the damage reduction of Beetle armor is higher, the 12% damage reduction from Solar Flare armor's set bonus stacks with some other buffs. It can almost reach the damage reduction levels of Beetle armor this way: With Endurance, Ice Barrier, and the Worm Scarf, Beetle armor offers at most 73.6% damage reduction, while Solar Flare armor offers 71.2%, which is only 2.4 percentage points less.
The shield acts somewhat like the Shield of Cthulhu, but does more damage, dashes further, and does not knock the player backward on hit.
Solar Flare armor essentially combines the effects of Turtle armor (damage reflection), Beetle armor (damage reduction), and the Shield of Cthulhu (dash).
A solar flare is a sudden increase of brightness on the Sun. More powerful flares are then followed by a coronal mass ejection, which is a significant release of plasma from the Sun's surface.
Despite inflicting Weak on players, it does not drop Vitamins.
Two of the scarecrows appear to be wearing a Guy Fawkes Mask. These variants seem to be the ones pictured in its banner. These variants seem to be the ones pictured in its banner.
Both the potion and buff icon resemble the High Velocity Bullet.
A pure Underground biome is required for fishing in Underground, otherwise no Underground-exclusive fishing catches can be obtained.
Spooky Wood and Dynasty Wood are the only two types of wood that cannot be harvested from trees.
The Golf Ball has to be struck with a Golf Club at least once to activate the Golf Cup. Simply throwing Golf Balls at the cup will not work.

The Eye of Cthulhu drop explicitly requires that Plantera and all three mechanical bosses have been defeated. [1] This is always the case in regular gameplay, since it is a prerequisite to fighting Mothron, but if Mothron is encountered earlier because of mods or other third-party tools, then it will not drop The Eye of Cthulhu.
A greater damage output can be achieved by using the Yoyo Bag accessory.
If this yoyo is obtained pre- Golem, it can be a useful weapon when fighting Golem due to its high DPS.

Modifier prefixes are added in front of the "The" in its name, which can result in a grammatically incorrect name such as "Keen The Eye of Cthulhu". It shares this trait with all other items that can obtain modifiers and whose names begin with "The".
Despite being named the same as the Eye of Cthulhu, it is not dropped by it.
Unlike other flower-displaying items, Hanging Pots do not spontaneously grow wildflowers.

In Don't dig up (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds, the Unholy Trident receives the following changes: Switched place with Flower of Fire. As a result, it is found in Shadow Chests and Obsidian Lock Boxes instead of dropped by Red Devils. Damage decreased from 88 to 42. Mana cost decreased from 19 to 9. Value decreased from 50 GC to 12 GC 50 SC. Switched place with Flower of Fire. As a result, it is found in Shadow Chests and Obsidian Lock Boxes instead of dropped by Red Devils. Damage decreased from 88 to 42. Mana cost decreased from 19 to 9. Value decreased from 50 GC to 12 GC 50 SC.
It can be considered a Hardmode version of the Gem staves, due to both weapons firing a projectile that pierces a limited amount of enemies in a straight line.
A Small world contains 6–13 Lihzahrd Chests, a Medium world contains 9–20 Lihzahrd Chests, and a Large World contains 12–26 Lihzahrd Chests. [1]
The Skeleton Merchant (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) will use Bones to defend himself if needed. The bones thrown by him are not retrievable.
In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Skeletons can throw bones at the player, making them far more dangerous.

Since 1.4.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Bones cannot be stored in ammo slots because the Bone Glove changed from a ranged weapon to an accessory. Any Bones placed in the ammo slots prior to the update will still be located there.
On the Nintendo 3DS version, the player can craft the Necro armor before entering the Dungeon due to Bones being dropped by Skeletons.

With the Hive Pack (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) equipped, all Bee projectiles have a 1/2 (50%) chance to be converted into Giant Bee projectiles that deal 1-3 extra damage, have a knockback of 0.5 (Extremely weak), can pierce enemies or ricochet off solid blocks four times in total, fly noticeably faster, and last for 11 seconds. Both kinds of bee projectiles dissipate immediately upon contact with water or lava. [1]

With the Hive Pack (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) equipped, the Bee Gun also gains an extra 1/3 (33.33%) chance to spawn another bee. The average amount of bees summoned is 2.32, or 2.66 with the Hive Pack equipped.
The Bee Gun is not affected by the Bee armor, despite the achievement.
Like all homing weapons, the bees will not attack players in PvP but will knock them back if they are hit directly.
Despite having a base damage of only 9, the Bee Gun can easily overwhelm enemies if using the appropriate gear.
The Bee Gun provides excellent crowd control especially when focusing the bees against enemies in a confined space, such as the Dungeon.
It is effective for making money when combined with the Lucky Coin.
The Hive Pack (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) slightly increases the damage and knockback of the bees, possibly keeping the Bee Gun viable until Hardmode.
The Bee Gun can be convenient in the Underground Jungle because the bees clear vines when bouncing around, aiding player vision. Note that they will likely also break Bee Hives.
Because of the large number of projectiles and their ability to bounce off walls, the Bee Gun is great for clearing out Cracked Dungeon Bricks (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Due to the relatively low base damage of the Bee Gun, items that grant extra armor penetration, such as the Shark Tooth Necklace (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or its upgrade, the Stinger Necklace (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) can be extremely useful in conjunction with it.
On Desktop, Console, and Mobile, wearing a Fish Bowl will activate the Merfolk appearance but no buff when the Neptune's Shell is equipped; on Old-gen console and 3DS, it will not.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) When placed, attempting to destroy a Fish Bowl with a pickaxe or drill will not drop it, so it cannot be recovered once placed. However, it is possible to retrieve it by breaking the blocks beneath it.
The Fish Bowl sells for 20 SC, while its components only net 7 SC 54 CC in total when sold ( 12 SC 46 CC / 62.3% less).
Fish Bowls will not turn red during a Blood Moon.
The Gold Fish Bowl's tooltip, " 'Is it a gold bowl? Or a gold fish?' ", is a reference to the ambiguous name which could either mean a fish bowl which is gold, or a bowl containing a gold fish.

The Lava Serpent seems to be the alive form of Bone Serpents, as it is mentioned in their Bestiary entry that they had obsidian scales: " Mighty serpentine dragons once ruled hell, but long ago shed their obsidian scales. A skeletal husk is all that remains. "

The Lava Serpent Bowl's tooltip, " 'No, you can't wear it on your head' ", is referencing the fact that the Fish Bowl and the Gold Fish Bowl are wearable as a helmet. These water-filled bowls are also dangerous to wear as they can cause the player to drown, but wearing a lava-filled bowl would be much more dangerous.
The name Code 2 comes from one of the many different yoyos sold by One Drop YoYos. CODE2's design was created by Jason Rodriguez. CODE2's design was created by Jason Rodriguez.
The Code 2 is currently the weakest of 6 yoyos that can remain in the air indefinitely.
The Code 2 can be purchased on a pre-Hardmode world if a mechanical boss summoning item is brought from another world.
It seems to be made from Luminite or Titanium based on both having similar colors.
The colorway on the Code 2 sprite seems to be the same as One Drop’s Hairband colorway.
The effects of the Celestial Shell do not stack with the effects of any of its constituent parts.
Hiding the accessory hides the Werewolf and Merfolk transformations while still applying the boosts.

Wearing the Celestial Shell in a vanity slot will instantly change the character's appearance into a Werewolf – even during daytime, though the character will still change into a Merfolk underwater. Since it is only vanity, no boosts are given.

Despite being equipped in the accessory slot, dyes will only modify the transformations if placed in the armor dye slots. The helmet slot dyes the head, the chestplate slot dyes the body, and the leggings slot dyes the legs.
Despite the Celestial Shell adding 2% less damage than the Avenger Emblem, it adds 2% critical strike chance, making the difference in damage increase minimal.
Even though all items involved in crafting the Celestial Shell are available in all versions, it is only craftable on Desktop, Console, and Mobile.
Every other part of the Celestial Shell are pre- Plantera except the Sun Stone, which is post- Golem.
Summon weapons do not benefit from this potion as they are unaffected by the player's critical strike chance.
It can be considered the Crimson equivalent to the Wrath Potion.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) This potion can only be crafted in worlds with Crimson due to it requiring the Hemopiranha, although it is possible to make an artificial Crimson biome in a Corruption world by importing either Crimson blocks, Red Solution, or Crimson Seeds.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) As of version 1.4.0.1, it is possible to naturally acquire a Rage Potion in a Corruption world by purchasing Crimson Seeds from the Dryad in a Hardmode Graveyard biome, and using the Crimson Seeds to make an artificial Crimson biome to fish in.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) When attacking with the Umbrella midair, the player's fall will no longer be slowed for the duration of the attack.
It is not necessary to hold out the Umbrella for the entirety of the fall. It can be pulled out in the last seconds before touching the ground and still instantly prevents fall damage.

Although the Umbrella's effect is similar to the Featherfall 's effect, they are not the same effect and thus can be stacked with each other. [1] However, the Umbrella only slightly changes the fall speed when paired with the Featherfall effect.
The Umbrella is very useful when paired with an accessory that provides extra jumps (e.g. Cloud in a Bottle ) and other accessories that increase jump height.
Keeping the Umbrella in the hotbar for quick access can be life-saving for unexpectedly long falls.

The Umbrella is highly effective when falling with a high horizontal speed, e.g. with the maximum speed of a Minecart. Riding off the edge of a suspended Minecart Track while holding an Umbrella facilitates traveling very long horizontal distances. If the rail is high enough, distances reaching even halfway across the map can be traveled.
With the Shield of Cthulhu (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), enemies can be attacked while floating down.

If one wants to further speed up the fall, they can switch to another item, and then switch back to the Umbrella before touching the ground. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Attacking in midair is another option to achieve this.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Umbrella may prove quite helpful in combat during the early game due to its large hitbox. However, its weak knockback should be kept in mind.
Use of an Umbrella in place of a parachute to slow a fall from a great height is a common comedic trope.
Despite being an umbrella, it has no effect against the Angry Nimbus.

The Spore Bat and the Spore Skeleton are different from all other Glowing Mushroom biome enemies in that they require the player to be in the biome, i.e., there need to be at least 100 related tiles nearby. In contrast, the other enemies only require a single block of Mushroom grass to spawn on. [1]

Spore Bats, as well as Jungle Bats, Cave Bats, and Hellbats have an unused frame in the animation that seems to depict a Spore Bat hanging upside down. This may mean that bats were originally planned to be able to hang on ceilings but was later decided against.
The Spore Bat may be a reference to white-nose syndrome, a disease caused by an invasive, psychrophilic fungus that has devastated many North American bat populations.
While riding the Flamingo, the player gains +5 Fishing Power while touching the liquid.
The top running speed of the Flamingo is 31 mph. [1]
The Flamingo raises the player's height from 3 to 4 blocks.
It reduces fall damage by 80%. [1]
The buff tooltip is a portmanteau of the words flamingo and go, repeated multiple times to form a command.
The horses' top running speed is 46 mph, reachable in 3.2 seconds. [1]

When surpassing 38 mph, they will start dealing damage to enemies and critters they run into, similarly to the Unicorn and Goat Mounts. They will deal 30 base summon damage and inflict a knockback of 7 (Strong). [2]
There is no jump fatigue while riding a horse mount.
When using a saddle, the respective horse mount will appear in a puff of gray smoke.
A horse mount is best used on a large platform without obstacles, extending across the map. This facilitates maintaining maximum speed without having to worry about slowing down.
With a slightly faster use time than its alternate ore counterpart, the Titanium Sword is the best of the six Hardmode ore swords until the player is able to mine Chlorophyte.
The Titanium Sword slightly resembles the Zenith.

In Hardmode, Hardened Sand Block is a "corruptible" block, and can be converted to its corrupted version of Hardened Ebonsand, Hardened Crimsand, and Hardened Pearlsand, and spread the corrupted biome to nearby corruptible blocks.
A player equipped with Dunerider Boots will be able to run faster while standing on any type of Hardened Sand Block.
Until 1.4.0.1, Hardened Sand Blocks did not have a tooltip containing the Material tag and therefore could not be slotted in the Guide 's menu to show in which crafting recipes it could be used.

Although they look and act like critters, the released Doves are projectiles. Therefore, they do not count towards the Bestiary and can neither be caught nor hurt. For the same reason, the Doves use a different type of AI from the Bird AI. This is most clearly shown if one releases both some Birds and the Doves in a closed room. For the same reason, the Doves use a different type of AI from the Bird AI. This is most clearly shown if one releases both some Birds and the Doves in a closed room.

Doves are a prominent Judeo-Christian symbol associated with funerals, remembrance, and rebirth. They are featured prominently in the Genesis flood narrative, in which doves are sent out from Noah's Ark to survey the aftermath of the flood.
Releasing doves is a trick sometimes performed by magicians at parties, which is likely referenced by the item being sold by the Party Girl.

The Apple Pie Slice is missing the "Consumable" and "Increases life regeneration" texts, as well as the duration text, all of which are usually included in the tooltips of food items. The Apple Pie Slice cannot be consumed, but it can be displayed in the player's hand by only selecting it.

Light-producing animations become more active in the Retro and Trippy modes. Torches and other spark-releasing light sources produce sparks more actively. The same is true for the sparkle effect from Gold Chests and other sparkling items, as well as the bubbles released by Lava. This is most likely due to the difference in load.
The set bonus will provide +1 sentry capacity in addition to the Hood's +2 sentries, increasing the total sentries to 4.

This set is a powerful hybrid between ranged and summoning styles. It offers higher offensive ranged bonuses than Chlorophyte armor and Hallowed armor, though not as high as those provided by Shroomite armor. However, it also significantly boosts the damage output of both sentries and minions. When combined with the Necromantic Scroll and Papyrus Scarab, a player can have significant ranged damage boosts combined with, for instance, 3 boosted Xeno Staff summons. By the time the player obtains the Stardust Cell Staff or Stardust Dragon Staff, Red Riding armor can begin to significantly outperform Shroomite armor due to its summon damage. As neither Shroomite armor nor Red Riding armor provides a very useful set bonus for a pure ranger, one can combine Red Riding armor with a headpiece from Shroomite armor to gain the highest bonuses. The Red Riding Dress is slightly weaker for pure ranged than the Shroomite Breastplate, but its large bonus to summon damage outweighs this disadvantage when using minions. The Explosive Trap sentry summons, ordinarily a poor choice due to being stationary and slow, becomes far more powerful when using the full set. They attack much more rapidly, dealing damage faster than any other sentries within the same tier. Placing four of them around the player (or below, if flying) during moon events can help soar through the early waves. However, it also significantly boosts the damage output of both sentries and minions. When combined with the Necromantic Scroll and Papyrus Scarab, a player can have significant ranged damage boosts combined with, for instance, 3 boosted Xeno Staff summons. By the time the player obtains the Stardust Cell Staff or Stardust Dragon Staff, Red Riding armor can begin to significantly outperform Shroomite armor due to its summon damage. As neither Shroomite armor nor Red Riding armor provides a very useful set bonus for a pure ranger, one can combine Red Riding armor with a headpiece from Shroomite armor to gain the highest bonuses. The Red Riding Dress is slightly weaker for pure ranged than the Shroomite Breastplate, but its large bonus to summon damage outweighs this disadvantage when using minions. The Explosive Trap sentry summons, ordinarily a poor choice due to being stationary and slow, becomes far more powerful when using the full set. They attack much more rapidly, dealing damage faster than any other sentries within the same tier. Placing four of them around the player (or below, if flying) during moon events can help soar through the early waves.

The Red Riding Leggings' summon damage bonus is 3% higher than the Stardust Leggings '. However, the Stardust Leggings add two minion capacities in addition to the damage bonuses, which would lead to higher DPS for a minion summoner. The Red Riding Leggings provide ranged bonuses in addition to the minion bonus, which would likely be preferred for a mixed playstyle.

The Red Riding Dress provides the highest ranged damage bonus in the game, and the Red Riding Leggings offer the highest summon damage bonus in the game. The Red Riding Leggings are tied with Mythril Greaves for the second-highest combined bonuses to ranged damage and critical strike chance, behind Vortex Leggings.
The Spinning Nutcracker moves by performing a pirouette, a type of dance turn executed while balancing on one foot that is commonly performed in a ballet.
The Nutcracker, especially its Spinning Nutcracker form, is a reference to the classical ballet known as The Nutcracker by Russian composer Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky.
The Clentaminator has a range of 60 tiles.
It is affected by boosts which reduce ammo usage, thereby saving solution.
Trees cannot have their tiles converted individually, rather, they will be converted when the blocks they are on are converted.
Its stream emits a faint amount of light.
Using it is one of two ways to create Converted walls, alongside a Work Bench in a Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Clentaminator will only convert Grass, Ice, Sand, and Stone Blocks. Jungle Grass can also be changed to evil and Hallowed grass ( (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) and at the same time changing the Mud Block to Dirt Block ), but Mushroom grass can only be changed to Jungle Grass. Jungle Grass can also be changed to evil and Hallowed grass ( (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) and at the same time changing the Mud Block to Dirt Block ), but Mushroom grass can only be changed to Jungle Grass.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The zoom ability of the Rifle Scope or its upgrades can be applied to the Clentaminator.

Since boosts which reduce ammo usage also affect the consumption of Solution, it is recommended to have at least two ammo-conserving items or buffs before using the Clentaminator. The following items may be used: Chlorophyte Helmet and Vortex Breastplate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) ( Shroomite Breastplate alternatively) give a constant chance to not consume ammo; while Ammo Reservation Potion and the Ammo Box provide ammo-conserving buffs. Combining all four of these results in a 61.6% chance to not consume ammunition (including Solution).

It is possible to convert an entire world by digging Hellevators about every 120 tiles (240 ft on the Compass ) and slowly descending each one, spraying both sides. Alternatively, one might prefer to instead dig multiple tunnels, 120 tiles (240 ft on the Depth Meter ) apart horizontally, extending from a single Hellevator. Although more time consuming, this approach negates the need to dig Hellevators all around the world. Alternatively, one might prefer to instead dig multiple tunnels, 120 tiles (240 ft on the Depth Meter ) apart horizontally, extending from a single Hellevator. Although more time consuming, this approach negates the need to dig Hellevators all around the world.

Dark Blue Solution can be an effective way of slowing down or completely stopping world evils from spreading through the Jungle, as neither Corruption or Crimson can spread to Mushroom Grass; see Guide:Maintaining world purity for more info. It can be a potentially effective tool to search for Life Fruit, as it will break them out of place and convert the Jungle foliage to Glowing Mushroom foliage – illuminating and creating a contrast between the background and the Life Fruit. However, note that this will most likely also break Plantera's Bulbs, summoning Plantera. It can be a potentially effective tool to search for Life Fruit, as it will break them out of place and convert the Jungle foliage to Glowing Mushroom foliage – illuminating and creating a contrast between the background and the Life Fruit. However, note that this will most likely also break Plantera's Bulbs, summoning Plantera.
The Clentaminator could be used to illuminate the map, since its spray emits a small light source.
Due to its long range, using it with Green Solutions to cleanse the world is more effective than using Purification Powder.
"Clentaminator" is a noun constructed from a portmanteau of the verbs "to cleanse" and "to contaminate", these being its two major uses.

It is tied with the Diamond Ring and Tiki Totem as the fourth most expensive item players can buy (behind the Steampunk Wings, Parrot Cracker, and Companion Cube (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) in ascending order).

When using the Clentaminator, an apparatus can be seen on the character's back. A similar effect also occurs when equipping the Heat Ray, Leaf Blower, Elf Melter, and Terraformer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The apparatus is, as with the items listed above, invisible when the player wears wings and is midair.
Standing on a converted block while using the Clentaminator upwards will purify the block.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The Silver Shortsword and its Tungsten alternative are the only early-game shortswords that use 6 bars to craft, rather than the usual 7.

Unless the player has a good reason to make a shortsword (like not having very much Silver, or for completionist purposes), they are advised to make the Silver Broadsword as it does more damage and can swing in an arc.
The Shadow Mimic pet is slightly smaller than Shadow Chests and real Shadow Mimics.
Despite appearing to be a Shadow Key, it cannot open Shadow Chests. It is simply an item designed after it.
While flying, the pet Shadow Mimic will emit a soft, purple light. This can be useful for players without a light pet.

Skiphs' Blood is currently the only developer item that can be obtained in a normal mode world. Prior to the 1.4.0.1 update, the Arkhalis was also obtainable in normal-mode worlds through Enchanted Sword Shrines ; it has since been replaced in shrines by the Terragrim and is currently only obtainable through the Arkhalis developer vanity set.
This dye's sprite looks very similar to Phase Dye, also given from the Dye Trader.
This is the only dye that does not have the word dye in its name.
Compared to the Nightmare Pickaxe, the Deathbringer Pickaxe has superior power and mines faster making it the better pickaxe.

The Deathbringer Pickaxe is faster than the higher-tier Molten Pickaxe at mining blocks requiring one or three hits while it is slower at mining stronger blocks requiring two hits. Therefore, once the player has acquired the Molten Pickaxe, it is advisable to keep the Deathbringer Pickaxe around so they can be swapped as needed. Rapid swapping is possible by selecting the pickaxe which is farther right in the inventory and then holding Auto Select to swap to the other pickaxe as needed. After reaching Hardmode and acquiring a Cobalt / Palladium Drill or Pickaxe, however, both the Molten and Deathbringer Pickaxes can be discarded as these are stronger and faster. After reaching Hardmode and acquiring a Cobalt / Palladium Drill or Pickaxe, however, both the Molten and Deathbringer Pickaxes can be discarded as these are stronger and faster.

Only trees that can be grown from Acorns will be affected. When used to chop down Cacti, gem trees, or Giant Glowing Mushrooms, nothing will be placed. When used to chop down vanity trees, only regular Acorns will be planted instead of Sakura / Yellow Willow Saplings. When used to chop down Cacti, gem trees, or Giant Glowing Mushrooms, nothing will be placed. When used to chop down vanity trees, only regular Acorns will be planted instead of Sakura / Yellow Willow Saplings.
The Axe of Regrowth does not require or consume any Acorns in the player's inventory to plant trees. [1]
While in hand, projectiles made from hooks and minions will also harvest seeds from mature herbs.
The Axe of Regrowth will generally remain relevant as an axe throughout game progression, due to its unique ability to replant Acorns from trees it chops down.
Souls of Might drop from the body segment of The Destroyer that is closest to the player.
All types of souls are very useful for selling as profit once the necessary items have been crafted.
The Soul of Might is the only type of soul directly stating the boss it is dropped from in its tooltip.
Crafting all items requires 73 Souls of Might, meaning the player must defeat The Destroyer 3–4 times.
Squirrel: " Fast moving and erratic woodland creatures with grayish-brown fur. Got nuts? "
Red Squirrel: " Rare, red-furred hyperactive rodents which scurry about the woods. "

The direction in which Boulders start rolling depends on different factors: (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Boulders always roll left, unless there is no space for them to go left, in which case they roll right. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Boulders started with a pickaxe or drill appear to roll in the direction that will give them the longest amount of time to roll (e.g. if two walls are on either side of a long platform, placing it closer to one wall will cause it to roll the opposite direction). Boulders created by Boulder Statues choose their rolling direction depending on whether their x-coordinate is even or odd. So, to change the direction of one of these boulders, one can simply move the statue over by one tile. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Boulders always roll left, unless there is no space for them to go left, in which case they roll right. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Boulders started with a pickaxe or drill appear to roll in the direction that will give them the longest amount of time to roll (e.g. if two walls are on either side of a long platform, placing it closer to one wall will cause it to roll the opposite direction). Boulders created by Boulder Statues choose their rolling direction depending on whether their x-coordinate is even or odd. So, to change the direction of one of these boulders, one can simply move the statue over by one tile.

Once rolling, Boulders deal the same amount of damage regardless of their speed. A player or enemy hit by a Boulder that had just begun rolling will take just as much damage as they would from a Boulder moving at a higher speed. This also means that players trying to mine a Boulder while touching it will take damage.

Like all other projectiles, the Boulder will break after rolling for one minute. If moving along a flat strip of land, this allows it to roll a maximum distance of 1548.6 tiles. [3] If moving along a flat strip of land, this allows it to roll a maximum distance of 1548.6 tiles. [3]

Boulders can be placed atop flat-surface furniture, such as tables or bookcases, and can be stacked on top of each other. Mining the bottom Boulder causes all of them to fall and roll, while only the topmost Boulder only causes that one to roll off.
Boulders can activate red, green, and yellow (NPC-sensing) Pressure Plates by rolling over them.
Boulders are unable to fit through 2-tile high spaces in the Console version.
It is possible for Boulders to roll uphill, as long as there is one flat block in between each sloped block.

In Expert (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Boulder traps should be avoided at all costs, considering the deadly force of 280 / 420 average damage.
Boulders are effective when used along with Grenades against The Destroyer and Eater of Worlds.
Using Boulders is an efficient way to kill NPCs, should one wish to do that (for example, for getting their unique drops).

Players can detect Boulder traps "in the wild" by wielding a mechanism item such as a Pressure Plate ( (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) ), by carrying a Mechanical Lens (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrade The Grand Design (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or by using a Dangersense Potion. All except the last will allow the player to view placed wires, and the vertical wire with its 2×3 rectangle atop it is quite distinctive. Once detected, there are some basic ways to disarm them: If approaching from above, the player can mine their way toward the top of the trap, and use a pickaxe to break the boulder from outside the sealed chamber. From below, the player can make sure there is a slope downwards to the left, then trigger the plate from the right side and immediately dodge to the right. Once the player has The Grand Design (or even just a Wire Cutter ), they can easily disable the trap at a distance by cutting the vertical wire. If approaching from above, the player can mine their way toward the top of the trap, and use a pickaxe to break the boulder from outside the sealed chamber. From below, the player can make sure there is a slope downwards to the left, then trigger the plate from the right side and immediately dodge to the right. Once the player has The Grand Design (or even just a Wire Cutter ), they can easily disable the trap at a distance by cutting the vertical wire.
At full tilt, boulders roll faster than a running player with several speed boosts applied. Using a Hoverboard or Asphalt can help to overcome them.

Breaking the Pressure Plate will prevent the trap from triggering, but the Boulder will remain above, and may be encountered later. As with other traps, the mechanisms (but not the Boulder) can be harvested for later use. The pressure plate and active stone can be taken with a pickaxe, but collecting the wire needs a Wire Cutter or an upgrade thereof. As with other traps, the mechanisms (but not the Boulder) can be harvested for later use. The pressure plate and active stone can be taken with a pickaxe, but collecting the wire needs a Wire Cutter or an upgrade thereof.
In Hardmode, the Active Stone Blocks do not change into their respective biome. Therefore, they can be much easier to spot and deactivate.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Boulders are one of four non- accessories that are crafted at a Tinkerer's Workshop, the others being the Cell Phone, Multicolor Wrench, and The Grand Design.

Boulders are (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) the only / (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) one of the five placeable objects that cannot be picked up again once placed (the others being Rolling Cactus, Bee Hive, Bouncy Boulder, and Life Crystal Boulder ), as hammers have no effect on them, and mining them with a pickaxe or drill only causes them to roll (or destroys them, if they cannot roll).
Boulders are able to deal damage to Target Dummies.
Once the Boulder has reached top speed, it completes a full rotation approximately once every quarter of a second.
Midas is the name of a king in Greek mythology who was rewarded by Dionysus with the ability to turn anything that he touched into gold.

The debuff icon displays an item that looks similar to the Lucky Coin, which functions in a similar manner to the debuff when equipped. The main difference is that the Lucky Coin gives a chance for enemies to drop extra coins when damaged, not when slain.
Unlike the Darkness debuff, equipping a Blindfold, Ankh Charm, or Ankh Shield will not provide immunity to the Blackout debuff.
In the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the character's sprite appears to close their eyes while this debuff is active.
It is possible to build an invincibility machine using fall damage by utilizing hoiks.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The player should be careful when falling down long shafts such as hellevators without fall damage or knockback protection, as enemies will not reset the player's fall damage.

The maximum amount of fall damage the player can take on a small world with 0 defense is 10,090, from top of the world to the bottom of Underworld. On a large world, the maximum fall damage is 43,620.

Dying from fall damage will display one of the following unique death messages : " <Player name> fell to their death. " " <Player name> didn't bounce. " " <Player name> invented gravity. " " <Player name> discovered the meaning of defenestration. " " <Player name> was freeeee, free-fallin'. " " <Player name> tried to ice skate uphill. " " <Player name> thought they could fly. " " <Player name> fell to their death. " " <Player name> didn't bounce. " " <Player name> invented gravity. " " <Player name> discovered the meaning of defenestration. " " <Player name> was freeeee, free-fallin'. " " <Player name> tried to ice skate uphill. " " <Player name> thought they could fly. "
Spore Skeletons only spawn in the Underground Glowing Mushroom biome, in contrast to Spore Zombies, who can only spawn on Mushroom Grass above the Surface.
Unlike the Spore Bat, which drops the Shroomerang, the Spore Skeleton has no unique drops compared to its normal counterpart.

The Spore Skeleton and the Spore Bat are different from all other Glowing Mushroom biome enemies in that they require the player to be in the biome, i.e., there need to be at least 100 related tiles nearby. In contrast, the other enemies only require a single block of Mushroom grass to spawn on. [1]
The Bestiary entry for the Spore Skeleton: " Skeletons meandering through more moist caverns become hosts for glowing fungal growth, greatly empowering them. "
