The frames on the paintings generally correspond to a type of wood or block.

The paintings "Lady Of The Lake" and "This Is Getting Out Of Hand" have improper capitalization, with Of being capitalized. This also applies to the Can Of Worms and the Hand Of Creation. This also applies to the Can Of Worms and the Hand Of Creation.

Despite being such a powerful buff, debuffs that temporarily negate natural health regeneration, such as On Fire!, Poisoned, and Acid Venom completely invalidate any extra life regeneration it may provide.

In multiplayer, any player can pick up Life Boosters and benefit from the Life Nebula buff, even if they are not wearing Nebula armor. Additionally, picking up a Life Booster will grant all nearby players (within a 43.75-tile radius [3] ) one instance of Life Nebula. If the player acquiring the Life Booster is on a team, only nearby players within that team will obtain the buff.
Unlike the Slime Mount, the Pogo Stick does not damage enemies if it falls on them.

Strangely, despite doubling the players fall speed, akin to the Slime Mount, the Stopwatch and other informational accessories that show movement speed only display a maximum of 51mph instead of the correct 102mph.
Much like the Slime Mount, the doubled falling speed can be useful for traveling down hellevators faster than the players base falling speed.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The North Pole Spear projectile deals 100% of the weapon's damage (80 base damage) and 85% of its knockback (5.695 (Average) base knockback). [2] The snowflake projectiles deal 70% of the weapon's damage (56 base damage) and 46.75% of its knockback (3.132 (Weak) base knockback). [3]

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The North Pole Spear projectile deals 80% of the weapon's damage (58 base damage) and 85% of its knockback (5.695 (Average) base knockback). [4] The snowflake projectiles deal 64% of the weapon's damage (46 base damage) and 46.75% of its knockback (3.132 (Weak) base knockback). [5]
Holding this weapon will reduce melee speed boosts by half, which reduces the velocity increasing of the projectile from the melee speed boost.
Traveling horizontally, the projectiles move at 58 mph. [6]

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) There can only be 187 snowflakes on the screen at any given time. After reaching this cap, spear projectiles cannot produce any more until some snowflakes begin dissipating. [7] Additionally, every snowflake after 100 will spawn with 1% less damage. This can make them deal extremely low damage if the spear projectiles are launched high into the air. For example, while the 100th snowflake will still deal 64% damage (46 base damage) as normal, the 150th snowflake will only deal 32% damage (23 base damage), and the 187th snowflake, the last possible one, will only deal 8.32% damage (6 base damage). The high number of projectiles might trigger anti-cheat systems on some servers. Additionally, every snowflake after 100 will spawn with 1% less damage. This can make them deal extremely low damage if the spear projectiles are launched high into the air. For example, while the 100th snowflake will still deal 64% damage (46 base damage) as normal, the 150th snowflake will only deal 32% damage (23 base damage), and the 187th snowflake, the last possible one, will only deal 8.32% damage (6 base damage). The high number of projectiles might trigger anti-cheat systems on some servers.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The snowflakes are affected by the direction of the wind, so make sure to adjust the aim to compensate.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Like most spears, the North Pole does not have autoswing.

The projectiles are affected by liquids ; when used underwater they travel half the normal distance before being affected by gravity and arc downwards very sharply. This does not reduce the number of snowflakes spawned per projectile, however, leading to a denser cluster of snowflakes.

Fighting enemies with the North Pole out in the open gives it a huge advantage, especially when tackling groups of enemies during events. The North Pole's snowflake projectiles can easily fall upon and dispatch multiple targets at once.

Aim the North Pole straight up and launch the spear upwards, allowing all the snowflakes to descend and rain damage against large targets. This has a much higher rate of damage than even the Solar Eruption or Daybreak and can destroy weaker bosses or immobile targets like the Celestial Pillars with ease.
The North Pole can easily take care of worm enemies, including The Destroyer. Firing it up into the air creates waves of snowflakes which can easily damage the body all at once.

The North Pole is the northernmost point of the Earth, traditionally stated as the location of Santa Claus 's home and workshop. Being a spear, like a pole, it uses the North Pole as a pun for it being dropped during the Christmas -themed Frost Moon event.
The North Pole is the only weapon obtainable from the Frost Moon event which has a 07* rarity while the others have the 08* rarity.
There is unused and disabled code for the North Pole that gives it a slash similar to that of the Gungnir. It appears blue in game and uses the default sizing for this effect.
The North Pole can be seen sliding off of the player's hand.
There are few Stone Blocks available early on, so purchasing Wooden Arrows and a Furnace from the Merchant is advised.

Snow Flinxes can still be found deep below the outer edges of the world where Snow and Ice Blocks generate (since the number of Snow-related tiles there is sufficient to form an Ice biome). Deerclops can also be summoned in this area.
The phrase not the bees references the "NOT THE BEES!" meme which originated from the 2006 horror film The Wicker Man.
There is also an achievement named "Not the Bees!".

This content is transcluded from NPCs/dropnote. Since town NPCs cannot be damaged by players normally, external damage sources must be used to obtain this item. The Flymeal (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is one of the easiest options; other effective options include traps, lava, drowning, Boulders or Rolling Cacti (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), enemies, Explosive Bunnies, Land Mines, or the Halloween -exclusive Rotten Eggs (in tandem with Frost armor ).
The name Jim is a reference to Terraria artist, Jim T Myhre "Jimmarn" Kjexrud.

It is one of the only three items dropped by NPCs with special names, the others being the Green Cap, which is dropped by a Guide named Andrew, and Ivy, which is dropped by a Steampunker named Whitney.
The War Table can be activated limitlessly with no cooldown period. It is never consumed, and all players may use it to give themselves the buff.
It counts as a valid flat-surface item for housing, but cannot be stood upon.
The War Table is an item originally from Dungeon Defenders 2, where it is used to select which map to play next.
Fairies have a decreased spawn chance in the Underground and Cavern layers during Hardmode.

When a fairy spawns naturally in the lower half of the Underground or in the Caverns or is released manually, it will fly to the player and follow them. It does not take any damage, can move through blocks, and cannot be caught. As soon as it is within range of a treasure (see below ), it will briefly circle the player, emitting a soft chiming noise, then head in the direction of the treasure. It keeps a certain distance from the player in order to encourage being followed. Once the fairy reaches the loot, it will circle it briefly, then disappear in a burst of glowing glitter which illuminates the area for a few seconds before dying out. After a maximum of 5 minutes after spawning, the fairy will fly off-screen and despawn, even if it is still leading the player to treasure at that moment. [1] As soon as it is within range of a treasure (see below ), it will briefly circle the player, emitting a soft chiming noise, then head in the direction of the treasure. It keeps a certain distance from the player in order to encourage being followed. Once the fairy reaches the loot, it will circle it briefly, then disappear in a burst of glowing glitter which illuminates the area for a few seconds before dying out. After a maximum of 5 minutes after spawning, the fairy will fly off-screen and despawn, even if it is still leading the player to treasure at that moment. [1]

Every in-game minute (real-world second) between 9:18 PM and 2:42 AM, [2] there is a 1/180 (0.56%) chance for fairies to spawn three tiles above a random Fallen Log in the world, increased to 1/60 (1.67%) during new moons and full moons. [3] In Don't dig up worlds, they can spawn during the entire night, between 7:30 PM and 4:30 AM. Fairies will spawn at Fallen Logs in groups of 1–3, with a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of an extra one. [4] Fairies can spawn at Fallen Logs only once per night. [4] Fairies cannot spawn at the randomly selected Fallen Log if the log in question is on-screen for any player. They also cannot spawn if it is raining, if the Moon Lord is spawning, or if one of the following events is occurring: Blood Moon, Frost Legion, Frost Moon, Goblin Army, Martian Madness, Pirate Invasion, or Pumpkin Moon. [4] In Don't dig up worlds, they can spawn during the entire night, between 7:30 PM and 4:30 AM. Fairies will spawn at Fallen Logs in groups of 1–3, with a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of an extra one. [4] Fairies can spawn at Fallen Logs only once per night. [4] Fairies cannot spawn at the randomly selected Fallen Log if the log in question is on-screen for any player. They also cannot spawn if it is raining, if the Moon Lord is spawning, or if one of the following events is occurring: Blood Moon, Frost Legion, Frost Moon, Goblin Army, Martian Madness, Pirate Invasion, or Pumpkin Moon. [4]
The chance for a fairy to emerge from a shaken Pearlwood tree at night is 1.39%. Fairies can spawn this way even if all Fallen Logs in the world have been destroyed.
While a fairy is near the player, enemy spawns are reduced. The reduction effect is same as (and stackable with) Sunflowers ' Happy! buff. [5]
It is possible for a fairy to lead the player to treasures that are out of the world's borders, even though the player cannot see or reach said treasure.
In Celebrationmk10 worlds, all fairies have a 5/6 (83.33%) chance to be a Pink Fairy, and fairies have an increased spawn chance in the Cavern layer.
Capturing a fairy and releasing it allows locating treasure anywhere in the world, not just below the surface.
The Metal Detector pairs well with fairies, as it will indicate the type of treasure the player is being led to.
When a fairy leads to a Gold Chest, checking surroundings for traps can be useful, as the Chest might be a Dead Man's Chest.
It may be useful to destroy Chests after looting them. Fairies can lead the player to previously opened Chests, who would therefore miss the opportunity to locate valuable loot.
Since Fallen Logs are the reason fairies spawn, it is unwise to destroy them.

The fairies spawning near Fallen Logs at night are affected by the time alteration in Journey Mode 's Power Menu. Freezing time will prevent fairies from spawning at Fallen Logs, whereas speeding time up will increase their spawn rate. This is especially noticeable during full and new moons.
These smaller fairies bear a strong resemblance to the light pet summoned by the Fairy Bell, albeit much smaller in size.

Like the Pixie and the Fairy light pet, the fairy critters reference the Fairies from the fantasy action-adventure video game franchise The Legend of Zelda. The item tooltip and achievement name, 'Hey! Listen!', is a quote from Navi, a Fairy character from The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time. Terraria Fairies spawning around Fallen Logs are a nod to The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask, where the character Skull Kid meets two Fairies while he is taking shelter inside a log. The item tooltip and achievement name, 'Hey! Listen!', is a quote from Navi, a Fairy character from The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time. Terraria Fairies spawning around Fallen Logs are a nod to The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask, where the character Skull Kid meets two Fairies while he is taking shelter inside a log.
Eyezors and Reapers are unique among Solar Eclipse enemies due to them not serving as references to any horror movie.
It resembles a regular Zombie in appearance but with a Demon Eye for a head.
"Eyezor" is a play on the word eyesore, a term for something largely considered to look unpleasant or ugly.
The Eyezor's ability to move and shoot lasers more rapidly the more damaged it gets could be a reference to the Wall of Flesh, which has the same ability.

Styles are purely cosmetic and do not affect gameplay in any form outside of visually. For example, a female character with style 1 will not have any less defense than another statistically identical female character with style 4, despite having exposed legs, nor will females with style 1 equipped be hindered by being in a Snow biome. NPCs will also not give different dialogue to players depending on their character style. However, NPCs will have varying dialogue between female and male characters, for example, the Stylist.

Familiar outfit pieces bought by a player in a specific style will not preserve said style when equipped on another player who uses a different style; a Familiar Shirt bought by a player with style 2 will not appear as a style 2 shirt if equipped on a player with style 1. In short, the Familiar outfit will only ever show the style of its current wearer.

Some animations seem to "detach" an arm from the character as to angle it in a usually impossible way. For example, firing a ranged weapon will change the entire character sprite to rotate the arm, while playing an instrument or petting a town pet will rotate the arm as its own object.
There is a half-second cooldown between firing Nails. [1]
Despite having high health and dealing high damage, it moves slower than any other Solar Eclipse enemy, leaving it vulnerable to multiple attacks.
Due to the high contact damage, it is risky to fight the Nailhead at close range.
In Expert and especially Master Mode, the Nails become nearly as deadly as making contact with the Nailhead. It is crucial to deal damage from a distance, preferably from out of the line of fire.
The Nailhead is a reference to the character Pinhead from the 1987 British supernatural horror movie Hellraiser. [2]

The Lava Charm, Magma Skull, Molten Charm, Lava Waders, and Terraspark Boots all stack with the Molten Skull Rose to increase lava immunity by 7 seconds each. The Demonic Hellcart also gives an additional 7 seconds. This leads to a maximum total of 49 seconds. Of these, only the Demonic Hellcart is not itself a Lava Charm upgrade.

Combining the Magma Skull and the Obsidian Skull Rose into a Molten Skull Rose is not recommended as each of the two crafting ingredients requires a single Obsidian Skull, ultimately wasting one of them.
Toucans are members of the Ramphastidae family, native to the Neotropics. Its name originates from the Tupi word tukana, derived via Portuguese.
The Toucan, Blue Macaw, Gray Cockatiel, Owl, Scarlet Macaw, and Yellow Cockatiel are the only bird critters that cannot be cooked into food.

Due to the spread of the shots and the slow weapon speed, the Boomstick loses efficiency at long range. It is highly effective at close range, and hitting an enemy with all shots can deal enough damage to easily kill most pre-Hardmode enemies in Classic Mode.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Against single targets, it is inadvisable to use this weapon with piercing ammo like Meteor Shots. The bullets' piercing damage will cause the target to become invulnerable for a few frames, which means only one bullet will hit.

This weapon has a chance to drop from Jungle Crates found via fishing in the Jungle. By setting up an outpost viable for fishing there, the player can gain a great advantage without the need to defeat bosses or venture into deadly biomes.
This gun is strong enough to last through almost all of pre-Hardmode.

The term boomstick is a reference to the 1992 American dark fantasy comedy movie Army of Darkness from the Evil Dead horror movie franchise, in which the protagonist, Ash, refers to his shotgun as a boomstick. The word has since become a common name for shotguns, particularly short-barreled, or " sawed-off " double-barreled shotguns, which this appears to be.
The Boomstick bears a slight resemblance visually to the real-world gun Remington M1889.

The "actual" Windy Day event occurs only when the time is between 7:30 AM and 4:30 PM, meaning that the event's unique enemies and music will only spawn and play between these hours. However, enemies that can drop kites will still drop them regardless of time, so long as the wind speed is above 16 mph. However, enemies that can drop kites will still drop them regardless of time, so long as the wind speed is above 16 mph.
The Windy Day music only plays in the Forest and Hallow biomes and will override the "Town (Day)" theme if near a town.
NPCs have special dialog during a Windy Day.
If Rain occurs at the same time as a Windy Day, it will result in a Thunderstorm.
Windy Balloons and lost kites can occasionally appear as ambient entities, flying around in the background during the event.
The Nebula Floater is one of the enemies of the Nebula Pillar event that must be paid attention to. They are somewhat common, have frequent ranged attacks, and in groups can overwhelm the player.

Using weapons that are good for crowd control can come in handy when dealing with large groups of Nebula Floaters. If the Vortex Pillar has already been defeated, the Vortex Beater with Chlorophyte Bullets would be a great weapon of choice.

The lasers leave a trail on their path, making it easy to tell the location of Nebula Floaters. However, the lasers may be confused with the lines coming from slain enemies, which move towards the Nebula Pillar and are yellow and red in color.

As Nebula Floaters sometimes teleport when hurt, using a high-damage weapon (such as a Sniper Rifle ) may be advisable. It is also advisable for the player to not to move too fast, as Nebula Floaters' random teleportation can place them close to the player, and the player may take contact damage from them before they can react. It is also advisable for the player to not to move too fast, as Nebula Floaters' random teleportation can place them close to the player, and the player may take contact damage from them before they can react.
The Bestiary entry for the Nebula Floater: " These brain-like celestial beings have psionic capabilities, phasing through space and summoning powerful optical minions. "

The Toxic Flask is similar to the Inferno Fork, with its lingering projectiles and low velocity. While the Flask can potentially deal more damage, it has a higher mana cost and very limited vertical range.
While the Toxic Flask excels against crowds of enemies, it is usually less effective against single resilient enemies like bosses.
A single cloud will instantly disappear each time the weapon damages an enemy, which may or may not limit effectiveness depending on how many enemies are within the spread.

The Toxic Flask, Molotov Cocktail, and the Ale Tosser are the only weapons to feature a thrown bottle/glass projectile. It is the only magic weapon to have this property. It is the only magic weapon to have this property.
Being a magic weapon, despite having "Flask" in its name, it is in no way related to the buff-granting flasks and shares no other similarities.
Due to the Thorns set bonus, it is an upgrade over Wood armor. It provides damage and knocks enemies back.
Despite being a higher-tierd item compared to the Silver, Lead, and Iron hammers, it is actually slower than these hammers. So players should avoid crafting the Platinum Hammer.
Changing the speed of time in Journey Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) will not affect the marshmallow's cooking rate.
A Fireplace cannot be used to cook a Marshmallow.

In the 1.4.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) update, the sprites of the Marshmallow and the Cooked Marshmallow were updated to look less flat, but the Marshmallow on a Stick still uses the previous sprite.

On all versions, the Flower of Frost has a 50% chance to inflict the (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Frostbite / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Frostburn debuff in player-versus-player scenarios.
The Flower of Frost can be a powerful weapon in early Hardmode because of its relatively high DPS, ease of obtaining, and bouncing properties.

The Flower of Frost can be considered the Hardmode upgrade to the pre-Hardmode Flower of Fire. Similar to the Flower of Fire, the Flower of Frost is a reference to the Super Mario platform game series, in which the Ice Flower is a power-up that gives the player the ability to throw bouncing ice balls that freeze enemies on contact. In contrast to the Ball of Fire, the Ball of Frost can move through all liquids, falls slower, and gains height with each bounce. Similar to the Flower of Fire, the Flower of Frost is a reference to the Super Mario platform game series, in which the Ice Flower is a power-up that gives the player the ability to throw bouncing ice balls that freeze enemies on contact. In contrast to the Ball of Fire, the Ball of Frost can move through all liquids, falls slower, and gains height with each bounce.
Though this emblem depicts an arrow, it boosts all ranged weapons, including firearms and rockets.
Unlike most other developer items, the set changes color based on the player's undershirt color.

The color of the Arkhalis projectile will change to the color of the player's undershirt and its span will be larger if Arkhalis' Bodice is equipped. This is purely visual and does not affect the size of its hitbox.

The tooltip "I didn't get this from the Grid" could be a possible reference to the 2010 sci-fi action film Tron: Legacy, in which the digital world it takes place in is referred to as the Grid. It shares the same format as the tooltip for the Arkhalis sword, which states "I didn't get this off of a Schmoo."
The face that appears in Arkhalis' Hood is a sprite effect called ArkhalisMask in the game's code.
Most enemies in the Ice biome as well as in the Snow biome inflict the Chilled debuff, and more rarely the Frozen debuff.
An artificial snow biome can not be made using slush blocks.

The Cell Phone is the end result of combining 14 individual items: its original constituent items are the Compass, Depth Meter, DPS Meter, Fisherman's Pocket Guide, Gold/Platinum Bars and Chain (for Gold/Platinum Watch ), Lifeform Analyzer, Magic Mirror / Ice Mirror, Metal Detector, Radar, Sextant, Stopwatch, Tally Counter, and Weather Radio.
In a drunk world, it is possible to get the Cell Phone before defeating Skeletron.

Though the Cell Phone is a very versatile and powerful item, obtaining it will often take a huge amount of patience. Some of the required accessories, such as the Metal Detector and the Angler's quest items, may be very time-consuming to come across. However, some ingredients are also relatively common and are found easily.
Getting the Metal Detector is easier in Expert or Master Mode as Nymphs have a 100% chance to drop them.

The Cell Phone has one of the most complex crafting trees in Terraria, using 14 base items (and 7 crafting operations), beaten by its upgrade, the Shellphone, which uses 16, and beaten again by the Zenith, which uses 22.

The Cell Phone's nature as a single "catch-all" device parallels the multi-functionality of real modern smartphones, which have largely rendered once-common appliances like watches, compasses, timers, radios, and atlases obsolete in most cases. The usage of a mirror in the recipe could likewise be a reference how a smartphone's selfie camera may be used as a mirror. The mirror could also be because of the mirror-like touchscreen, which is vastly different from the older model phones which used buttons, or the "home" button found on many cell phones, due to the mirror being used to take the player "home." It does not seem to be based on any particular real-life smartphone models. It does not seem to be based on any particular real-life smartphone models.

The Cell Phone is one of four non- accessories that is crafted at a Tinkerer's Workshop, the others being the Boulder ( (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) ), Ultrabright Helmet, Multicolor Wrench and The Grand Design.
Although it is a powerful item and has a rarity of 07*, the Cell Phone can actually be acquired pre-Hardmode, as all ingredients can be obtained prior to defeating the Wall of Flesh.
It has one of the slowest use times in the game, tied with the Magic Conch, Demon Conch, Magic Mirrors, Shellphone, and Snake Charmer's Flute.
Unlike the Super Healing Potion (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Healing Potion, it is not made from the lower-tier potion.

The Greater Healing Potion, along with all other healing potions and mana potions, is identical in name and very similar in appearance to items in the action role-playing hack-and-slash computer video game Diablo II.
The Light Shard represents the Yang of the Yin Yang (Taijitu) symbol, and the Dark Shard represents the Yin. Both are combined in the Dao of Pow, making the full Yin Yang.
Unlike the Chlorophyte Shotbow, each shot always fires five arrows parallel to each other, which are closely knit and do not spread apart over distance.
When fired at the correct angle and distance, up to 2 of 5 of the Tsunami's arrows can be shot through closed doors.

This very lethal weapon can be obtained as soon as Hardmode is activated. If it is acquired before killing Golem, Plantera or any of the mechanical bosses, it can speed up game progression tremendously. However, characters playing in Expert Mode or Master Mode worlds may have much more difficulty beating Duke Fishron at such an early stage, so it may be advisable to gear up beforehand.

With the right modifier, damage-boosting accessories, Vortex armor, Holy Arrows and Archery Potion, the Tsunami can deal tremendous amounts of damage very fast, defeating most end-game bosses in seconds.
This bow can easily deal 300 damage per shot if all arrows hit a single target. This works best against large targets, such as bosses from the Frost Moon or Pumpkin Moon.

Holy Arrows and Ichor Arrows synergize well with the Tsunami because of the "five straight" shot pattern it possesses. If all five arrows hit, Holy Arrows rain down 10 stars to the target location, and Ichor Arrows can lower defense with the first arrow while the other four do even more damage resulting from it.

Because of how piercing damage works, the Tsunami's damage is maximized by using non-piercing arrows. Piercing projectiles like Jester's Arrows or Unholy Arrows can add an invincibility frame to the enemy (which normally lasts 0.17 seconds) that prevents more than one instance of damage, crippling the DPS of the bow to one fifth of its capabilities.
Prior to 1.3.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), using Hellfire Arrows could be highly hazardous, as the wall of arrows could easily damage the player when shot at certain angles.
(3DS version) The Tsunami is highly effective against Ocram. Using Heart Arrows, it can completely stun the boss, and its high DPS can easily take it down in naught but seconds.
The Tsunami appears in the real-time strategy video game Dungeon Defenders 2 as part of a crossover.
Caves with Dirt Walls are considered to be within the surface layer and will not contain gems.
Gem rarity is not affected by depth; there are as many gems just below the surface as near The Underworld.
Gems are less common in the Underground Jungle. Regular non-Jungle underground biomes contain much greater quantities.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Making Stained Glass is the most profitable way to sell gems.

The stats of the gem staves are directly related to the value of the gemstone being used, with the Diamond Staff having a higher damage than the Amethyst Staff. Amber is an exception, being weaker than the Ruby Staff. Amber is an exception, being weaker than the Ruby Staff.
In real life, some gemstones and minerals have been used as a dye, in particular azurite and cinnabar. This could be interpreted as the colored robes found in the crafting menu.
The hook fired when Quick Mount is pressed is identical to the Grappling Hook in appearance.

The Minecarp's name is a portmanteau, combining the words Minecart and carp fish. Its tooltip is a reference to the original teaser it was first shown in. Its tooltip is a reference to the original teaser it was first shown in.
Despite all of the Large Gems differing in appearance, all the Gem Minecarts look almost the same aside from color and detailing on the gem.
The unobtainable Color Only Dye shares its sprite with the Unicorn Wisp Dye.
Sparks will also travel randomized distances within a 45° cone and never travel beyond 30 tiles in any direction.
The Butcher's Chainsaw strikes an enemy twice per use, and each strike seems to have an approximately 50% chance to generate 1–2 sparks.
The Butcher's Chainsaw's sparks inflict melee damage, meaning that any melee buffs, accessories, or armor will boost them accordingly.
The duration of the Hellfire debuff inflicted by the sparks is as follows: [2] 5/6 (83.33%) chance for 1–2 seconds and 1/6 (16.67%) for 2–4 seconds (average duration is 1.75 seconds).

Due to its high damage per hit and ability to hit enemies multiple times in rapid succession, the Butcher's Chainsaw has a high DPS. With damage-boosting modifiers/ accessories, the weapon has a higher potential DPS than other weapons available after Plantera, including the Terra Blade.
As the Hellfire debuff only applies to enemies hit by the sparks, not by the chainsaw itself, careful positioning is required to make full use of the weapon's damage potential.
The Butcher and the Butcher's Chainsaw are both a tribute to the 1974 American slasher film The Texas Chain Saw Massacre. [3]
The Butcher's Chainsaw has the highest base damage and knockback of any tool, due to it being designed primarily for combat.
Enemies immune to the Hellfire debuff do not resist the damage from the sparks.
Like all chainsaws, it will stop functioning after a minute and has to be restarted.
The effects on NPC damage and defense stack with Advanced Combat Techniques. The two items can be consumed in any order.
The Stone Accent Slab mimics the behavior of the Stone Slab prior to 1.4.0.1. It was added because of feedback from players who relied on its non-blending appearance in their builds.

Iron Ore and Lead Ore are the only ores that do not have corresponding chandeliers. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, they are also the only ores that do not have corresponding bricks.
Real iron is very malleable and susceptible to corrosion, generally making it infeasible for crafting tools. The use of iron in Terraria more closely resembles real-life steel.
Its placed sprites look similar to the placed sprites for the Mythril Ore.

Modifiers can raise or lower the rarity of an item by up to two tiers. They can also raise its value by up to 210% (to more than three times the original value), or lower it by up to 69% (to about one-third of the original value).

The percentages displayed via in-game tooltips may vary depending on the item's base stats, since those percentages are determined after rounding. For example, the Murderous modifier (+7% damage) on a Handgun will display a 8% damage increase, while on a Magic Missile it will display a 6% increase. Item stats are always rounded to the nearest integer. Due to floating point inaccuracies, if a modifier would seemingly leave a stat ending in.5, it will round down for 0.9× and 1.15× modifiers (e.g. +10% speed, +15% damage) and round up for 0.85× and 1.1× modifiers. Item stats are always rounded to the nearest integer. Due to floating point inaccuracies, if a modifier would seemingly leave a stat ending in.5, it will round down for 0.9× and 1.15× modifiers (e.g. +10% speed, +15% damage) and round up for 0.85× and 1.1× modifiers.
The modifiers of items used in crafting have no effect on the crafted item. Any modifier given to the newly crafted item will be completely random.

A weapon cannot get a modifier that affects a stat it does not have. For instance, only ranged weapons can have their velocity modified and only magic and summoning weapons can have their mana cost modified. Furthermore, a weapon can only get a modifier if all of its changes have an effect on the weapon after rounding. For example, weapons that deal no knockback cannot receive modifiers that affect knockback, and magic weapons with very low mana costs cannot receive modifiers that affect mana cost. Furthermore, a weapon can only get a modifier if all of its changes have an effect on the weapon after rounding. For example, weapons that deal no knockback cannot receive modifiers that affect knockback, and magic weapons with very low mana costs cannot receive modifiers that affect mana cost.
10 tries for weapons with only the 14 universal modifiers
13 tries for accessories with their 19 modifiers
16 tries for weapons that can also have the common modifiers (24 modifiers total)
25 tries for weapons with magic or ranged modifiers (36 total)
28 tries for weapons with melee modifiers (40 total)

There are several modifiers with the same name: Two modifiers are named "Quick", one is an accessory modifier providing +4% movement speed, the other is a common weapons modifier providing +10% speed. Two modifiers are named "Deadly". One is a common weapons modifier providing +10% damage and speed. The other is a ranged weapons modifier providing +10% damage, +2% critical strike chance, and +5% speed, velocity and knockback. Two modifiers are named "Hasty", one is an accessory modifier providing +3% movement speed, the other is a ranged weapons modifier providing +10% speed and +15% velocity. Two modifiers are named "Quick", one is an accessory modifier providing +4% movement speed, the other is a common weapons modifier providing +10% speed. Two modifiers are named "Deadly". One is a common weapons modifier providing +10% damage and speed. The other is a ranged weapons modifier providing +10% damage, +2% critical strike chance, and +5% speed, velocity and knockback. Two modifiers are named "Hasty", one is an accessory modifier providing +3% movement speed, the other is a ranged weapons modifier providing +10% speed and +15% velocity.
There are two universal modifiers with the same effects but with different names, Forceful and Strong.
Like most other enemies with the ability to pass through tiles, Cursed Hammers are unable to spawn if the player is standing in front of valid housing walls.

Like most other Corruption enemies, Cursed Hammers can also spawn on top of Corrupt grass, Ebonstone, Ebonsand, or Purple Ice. They can do so even if the player is not specifically in a Corruption biome.

The Arkhalis (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or Terragrim (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are excellent weapons to deal with this enemy, as even a single hit forces to recharge its spin. In effect, these weapons can act as a shield surrounding the player, completely impassable by the Cursed Hammer.

On the Nintendo 3DS version, the Cursed Hammer and Shadow Hammer instead have a chance of dropping 2-4 Nature's Gifts, Silver Chandeliers, Band of Starpowers, Clay Pots, or Hellforges, also making it the only way to obtain multiple of an accessory in a single stack ( (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) apart from the Guide Voodoo Doll as of 1.4.4 ).

Out of the three Flying Weapon enemies, the Cursed Hammer is the only one with a sprite not directly based on an existing item or an item's previous sprite, although its handle appears to be built off of the Enchanted Sword, and by extension the Excalibur 's sprites. Furthermore, it is the only one to feature an exclusive variant.

Although Bubbles are not solid blocks, they are still considered valid frame tiles for housing. They are invalid home tiles, however. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) NPCs will occasionally move out of houses that use Bubbles as frame, making these kind of houses unreliable for accommodating NPCs. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) NPCs will occasionally move out of houses that use Bubbles as frame, making these kind of houses unreliable for accommodating NPCs.

Although Town NPCs will walk through empty Bubbles and Bubbles filled with water or honey, they will not walk through lava-filled Bubbles. Critters and enemies will walk through lava-filled Bubbles, though.
Bubbles have a rarity of 00*, so they can be destroyed by lava.

Bubbles are essentially the opposite of a Grate, one letting in entities but not liquids and the other letting in liquids but not entities. One notable difference is that unlike Grates, Bubbles cannot be toggled on or off, not even with Actuators.
Once placed, surrounding blocks and background walls can be removed, leaving a free-standing Bubble.

A liquid-filled Bubble and a Liquid Sensor can be used for a "reload detector", allowing complex circuits or machines to be restarted on world load. However, the Bubble will need to be manually reloaded before the next restart.
Honey-filled Bubbles are perfect for Honey buff pickups for arenas.
Using Bubbles for the frames of a house grants easy access to it. This can be useful for the Nurse 's house when going for healing in a hurry.
Care should be taken with setting lava traps for flying enemies, as the lava will kill flying critters as well.
Since water will trigger the Cute Fishron mount's boosts, the player can make several Bubbles of water around their world, so they would be able to travel at high speed using the mount.
In adventure-themed Terraria maps, Bubbles can be used as a filter to any liquid, including lava. This can be used to create scenarios like "lava stream escaping".

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The maximum increased attack speed (for melee) is +158.1% using Monk's Bushy Brow Bald Cap (20%), Shinobi Infiltrator's Torso (20%), Solar Flare Leggings (15%), Exquisitely Stuffed (buff) (10%), Tipsy (buff) (10%), and the five accessories Feral Claws (12%), Power Glove (12%), Mechanical Glove (12%), Celestial Shell (15.1% at night) and Berserker's Glove (12%), each reforged to Violent (20%). In Expert Mode, a Violent Fire Gauntlet can be worn for an extra 16%, with +174.1% total; In Master Mode, an additional Violent accessory can be worn for an extra 4%, with +178.1% total.

Mining speed of various tools is not affected by melee speed bonuses, and it is only boosted by specialized mining speed bonuses (such as the Mining Potion and Mining armor ) and speed bonuses granted by the tool's own modifier, the best of which is Light.

Enemies' invincibility frames should be taken into consideration when dealing with attack speed. Generally speaking, no invincibility time is applied when referring to projectiles that do not pierce, but those that do pierce or explode are not in this case. Normally it is 1/6 seconds (10 ticks) while there are some exceptions ranging from 5 ticks to 20 ticks.
Worlds can be viewed and sometimes edited by third-party programs known as map viewers.

If the player attempts to quit a world after defeating Wall of Flesh but before the Hardmode biomes are generated (i.e. before the " The ancient spirits of light and dark have been released. " is displayed), the loading description " Setting hard mode " [ sic ] will appear and the player has to wait for the game to generate the Hardmode biomes before returning to the main menu.

Worlds, like characters, are stored as individual files. A world has the file extension.wld. On Windows, they can be found in the directory %USERPROFILE%\Documents\My Games\Terraria\Worlds. On Android, they can be found in the directory Storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.and.games505.TerrariaPaid/Worlds and can be accessed in a file browser. Note: Android phones running Android 11 or higher will likely need an external app to access the Storage/emulated/0/Android/data/ folder. Alternatively, it can be accessed through a separate device, such as a computer via USB. Windows Steam users who have their worlds moved to the Steam Cloud will find them under, for example, C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\userdata\<userID>\105600\remote\worlds by default. See this Steam article for world locations in the Mac and Linux versions of the game. On Windows, they can be found in the directory %USERPROFILE%\Documents\My Games\Terraria\Worlds. On Android, they can be found in the directory Storage/emulated/0/Android/data/com.and.games505.TerrariaPaid/Worlds and can be accessed in a file browser. Note: Android phones running Android 11 or higher will likely need an external app to access the Storage/emulated/0/Android/data/ folder. Alternatively, it can be accessed through a separate device, such as a computer via USB. Note: Android phones running Android 11 or higher will likely need an external app to access the Storage/emulated/0/Android/data/ folder. Alternatively, it can be accessed through a separate device, such as a computer via USB. Windows Steam users who have their worlds moved to the Steam Cloud will find them under, for example, C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\userdata\<userID>\105600\remote\worlds by default. See this Steam article for world locations in the Mac and Linux versions of the game.
Since the explosion is delayed, a good strategy is to toss one on the ground and wait for enemies to step on it.

Sticky Grenades are still a very effective weapon against the Eater of Worlds, Devourers, World Feeders, and Bone Serpents. In some cases they might even be more effective than their non-sticky counterpart.
Despite the tooltip, the Sticky Grenade's throwing range is similar to that of the standard Grenade.
The set is a reference to the Xenomorphs from the Alien film series.

Unlike other sources of mana regeneration, the regeneration provided by the Mana Booster is independent of current mana supply or consumption, and will work even while continuously using a magic weapon. [1]

In multiplayer, any player can pick up Mana Boosters and benefit from the Mana Nebula buff, even if they are not wearing Nebula armor. Additionally, picking up a Mana Booster will grant all nearby players (within a 43.75-tile radius [3] ) one instance of Mana Nebula. If the player acquiring the Mana Booster is on a team, only nearby players within that team will obtain the buff.
It must be equipped to work in the Old-gen console version. It will not display the time if it is in the inventory.

On average, 1 SC 22 CC will drop each time the player strikes an enemy. This represents a limit to how much extra money can be extracted from any given enemy. For example, using a Slime Staff (see below ) against a Mimic will do 1 damage/hit due to defense, minions deal no critical hits, and the Mimic has 500 health. Thus the Lucky Coin can only add about 6 GC (on average) to the Mimic's normal drops.
Extra coins can drop from damage caused by player-placed traps in singleplayer, but cannot in multiplayer.
Extra coins will not drop from damage return effects, such as those provided by Turtle armor or Thorns Potion.

In Celebrationmk10 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds, the Lucky Coin can be purchased from the Princess for 5 GC after a Pirate Invasion has been defeated.
The Lucky Coin is very rare. It could take 33–34 complete Pirate Invasions before it drops.

Farming for a Lucky Coin/ Discount Card / Gold Ring (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is most efficient from Flying Dutchmen (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), rather than from common pirates. After getting event progress to 50%, one can ensure 10 Flying Dutchmen per event by getting high enough above the ground (using a small platform or flying mount ), but not too high, so that spawned enemies will be in the "Active Rectangle" and will despawn after 12.5 seconds, and then spawn again. Using this method, only Flying Dutchmen and Parrots can reach the player. Parrots can be killed safely as they do not count towards event progress.
This item is generally considered to be the best way to make money in-game, when paired with a very weak weapon, usually a Slime Staff with the Broken modifier.

To maximize profits, use the Slime Staff and Tiki armor together. Against stronger enemies (like Mimics ), the Baby Slime summoned by the staff will attack rapidly, but only do 1 damage per hit. And with the Tiki armor, the player can summon even more baby slimes to hasten the process. This offers more chances for coins to drop. Using this tactic during a Pirate Invasion can easily produce 2– 3 PC per invasion, and during a Solar Eclipse can produce 4– 5 PC per eclipse.
After defeating the Golem, his chamber in the Jungle Temple is also a good place to farm a steady stream of weak enemies, with the occasional Mimic adding to the haul.

In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), enemies have increased health which means the amount of Platinum Coins can skyrocket anywhere from 10– 15 PC. However, enemies also pick up coins in Expert mode, so letting anything escape can reduce the amount gathered dramatically.
Fight weaker bosses such as the Wall of Flesh, as they will not deal much damage but have lots of health.

Try using a Minishark. Its damage is low enough that it will usually only do one damage per hit to stronger enemies. Paired with its fire rate, the amount of coin drops increase drastically. To further decrease damage (and therefore increase how many hits can be achieved), consider a modifier that decreases damage. Frenzying can be a good choice, as it both decreases damage and increases speed.
A Chain Gun can be good for maximizing hits against enemies that are too strong to approach with a Minishark.

As with the Lucky Horseshoe, Deadly Sphere Staff (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Arcane Flower (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), it is possible to receive the Lucky modifier, giving it the name "Lucky Lucky Coin".
The amount of Mini Star Cells spawned upon death is based on the total number of Star Cells and Mini Star Cells already alive in the world: [1]
It may be to the player's advantage to leave the Mini Star Cells alive. This allows them to gain banners and demolish the Stardust Pillar's shield faster.

Since they tend to appear in clusters, using weapons with a large area of effect allows the player to hit them all at once. The Solar Eruption can kill a Star Cell and all the mini cells it spawns in a single strike. The Vampire Knives are a very effective weapon against Star Cells, hitting multiple copies of the enemy while healing the player for each hit. The Flairon can also be very effective. Due to the fact that it can summon lots of homing bubbles in a short amount of time, it can easily take out the Mini Star Cells that the Star Cell splits into. The Inferno Fork, Nebula Arcanum, and Celebration perform outstandingly well against these enemies. The beam spread attack from the Last Prism also works. The Aerial Bane can be good for taking out the Star Cells as it will kill the cells and then the arrow clusters from the bow will kill the Mini Star Cells. The Life Drain deals a reasonable amount of damage to them at a high rate, can target any number of them at once, and additionally increases the player's health regeneration. The Solar Eruption can kill a Star Cell and all the mini cells it spawns in a single strike. The Vampire Knives are a very effective weapon against Star Cells, hitting multiple copies of the enemy while healing the player for each hit. The Flairon can also be very effective. Due to the fact that it can summon lots of homing bubbles in a short amount of time, it can easily take out the Mini Star Cells that the Star Cell splits into. The Inferno Fork, Nebula Arcanum, and Celebration perform outstandingly well against these enemies. The beam spread attack from the Last Prism also works. The Aerial Bane can be good for taking out the Star Cells as it will kill the cells and then the arrow clusters from the bow will kill the Mini Star Cells. The Life Drain deals a reasonable amount of damage to them at a high rate, can target any number of them at once, and additionally increases the player's health regeneration.
As the Stardust Pillar itself spawns Star Cells, staying away from it will greatly reduce their spawn rate.
Intentionally leaving mini cells alive and using a room to keep them out, a weapon that fires through walls can easily destroy them, and thus breaking the shield with even more ease.
The tooltip of the Stardust Cell Staff saying: ' Cultivate the most beautiful cellular infection', hints that Star Cells may be disease-causing somehow.

In real life, living cells divide into two identical copies of themselves via mitosis. Each of these copies can then grow and divide again, similar to the Star Cells. However, real cells split normally and are killed completely, while Star Cells only split when the player attacks them.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It shares the same sprite as the Crimson Axe enemy, except for the red glow.
The Bestiary entry for the Rat: " These fuzzy rodents sniff about in putrid locations scavenging for food. They are avoided in fear of diseases they may carry. "
If the Moon Shell is made invisible in the accessory slot, the character will not appear to change into a Werewolf or a Merfolk although the buff is still applied.

If equipped into a social slot, the werewolf form overrides the human form regardless of the time of day. However, this is only a visual appearance, and the player will receive no actual buffs or bonuses.
While the components of the Moon Shell sell for a combined 10 GC 50 SC, the Moon Shell only sells for 8 GC (23.81% less).
The Moon Shell resembles a purple Neptune's Shell carved into an angled Moon Charm.
Like other flight-granting boots, Terraspark Boots grant a bonus on top of equipped wings.
The Terraspark Boots raise the player's base speed from 15 mph to 34 mph.
Landing on the surface of any liquid with Terraspark Boots equipped will not cause fall damage.

The Lava Charm, Magma Skull, Molten Skull Rose, Molten Charm, and Lava Waders all stack with the Terraspark Boots to increase lava immunity by 7 seconds each. The Demonic Hellcart also gives an additional 7 seconds. This leads to a maximum total of 49 seconds. Of these, only the Demonic Hellcart is not itself a Lava Charm upgrade.

The Terraspark Boots are better suited for general exploration and spelunking. Compared to the Amphibian Boots, they fall short in events and boss fights due to their lack of extra vertical mobility that the Amphibian Boots provide.
The Terraspark Boots have the same speed as the Frostspark Boots, but have the benefits of Lava Waders.
The Terraspark Boots can be crafted before defeating any bosses, and most of the required ingredients can be obtained from crates.

The Terraspark Boots share the "terra" aesthetic with the Terra Blade, Terragrim, Terra Toilet, and Terra Fart Kart. The accessory is the only item with this theme that can be crafted before Hardmode. While the Terragrim is also obtainable in pre-Hardmode, it is not craftable. The achievement for acquiring the Terraspark Boots has a very similar name to the achievement for acquiring the Terra Blade, "Sword of the Hero". The accessory is the only item with this theme that can be crafted before Hardmode. While the Terragrim is also obtainable in pre-Hardmode, it is not craftable. The achievement for acquiring the Terraspark Boots has a very similar name to the achievement for acquiring the Terra Blade, "Sword of the Hero".

Terraria 's lead developer, Redigit, has stated that he thinks the Terraspark Boots are too powerful. [1] Prior to the 1.4.0.1 update, he repeatedly mentioned that a tinker combination with the Frostspark Boots and Lava Waders would be "too overpowered" and that such an accessory would never exist nor fit in the game balance-wise. Verify Redigit stated that the accessory was only introduced so that players would "stop bugging him about it". [2]

Certain other helpful footwear accessories are not included in the crafting tree and therefore do not add to the Terraspark Boots' set of effects. A notable example are the Amphibian Boots (and by extension, although not realistically human footwear, the Frog Leg ). The Tabi and Shoe Spikes are instead used for crafting the Master Ninja Gear, and the Flame Waker Boots are purely aesthetic. The Tabi and Shoe Spikes are instead used for crafting the Master Ninja Gear, and the Flame Waker Boots are purely aesthetic.
None of the Horseshoe Balloons can be crafted with an Obsidian Horseshoe ; the original Lucky Horseshoe must be used.

Although it can be worn with the other horseshoe balloons, the extra jump height and fall reduction will only be applied once, meaning that only the extra jumps will stack (or the bees, if using the Honey Balloon ).
The double jump can be stopped midway by releasing the ↷ Jump button.
The Blizzard jump provides a speed boost when used, which can be used to quickly turn around while retaining some speed.

It is the weakest tool in the game, having the lowest tool power and slowest use time, along with a range penalty of -1. It also has the lowest DPS of any item in the game overall (especially with the Broken modifier), bested even by the infamous Copper Shortsword by a large margin (However, it does have more knockback than the Copper Shortsword).

While the Spectre Boots can be further crafted into the Lightning Boots, the Hellfire Treads cannot. Players who wish to obtain the Lightning Boots (and their upgrades, the Frostspark Boots and Terraspark Boots ) should therefore save their Spectre Boots and forgo the Hellfire Treads.
All pets can activate Teal Pressure Pads (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Although it is possible to change the color of the light pet itself using dyes, the color of the light they produce will stay the same.
All pet buffs have a duration of 5 minutes. This is constantly replenished, is hidden, and has no effect on the gameplay.
Some pets, such as the Cursed Sapling and Baby Truffle, provide light for the player which is rather useful when caving or in dark areas.
Chester is the only pet with any practical utility (aside from some pets providing some light). He provides access to your piggy bank, effectively doubling your storage.
The pet summoned is actually a long-lasting projectile that follows the player around.
The Pet Drone, summoned with the Mysterious Package, was introduced only on the Amazon version, but was unobtainable and later removed.
(Console and Mobile versions) Upon updating to 1.3, all exclusive pets were replaced with a Gold Bunny each.
Its tooltip is likely a reference to the American animated science-fiction sitcom Rick and Morty, where the character Jerry Smith, a former advertising agent, pitches a comically bad brand idea.
The UFO mount does not work in liquids. When attempting to fly through them, the player will automatically be dismounted.

The mount has a top speed of 41 mph when flying up/down or east/west. When flying diagonally, however, it can reach 58 mph max. Because of this, one can fly at the same speed as, if not faster, than the Dungeon Guardian (41 mph consistently). Because of this, one can fly at the same speed as, if not faster, than the Dungeon Guardian (41 mph consistently).
When ascending the UFO, it can travel upwards through a one block gap while also moving east or west.

The UFO cannot fly downwards through "bottom" platforms (that is, hammered to the lower half of the block), and will instead bounce off them. Other platforms can be passed downward with only a slight delay.

Falling from maximum speed and mounting the UFO allows it to fly at 51 mph. Similarly, it is possible to fall from a height at max speed and then mount the UFO and fly diagonally. This reaches a speed of 66 mph. Similarly, it is possible to fall from a height at max speed and then mount the UFO and fly diagonally. This reaches a speed of 66 mph.
When using this mount, it may be useful to replace other mobility accessories such as any wings or boots with damage or defense-based accessories.

Wings with hovering abilities in tandem with Lightning / Frostspark / Terraspark Boots can provide more speed and mobility than the UFO mount at the cost of infinite flight (unless Soaring Insignia is equipped).
Using wings with a fast ascent speed such as Jetpack, it is possible to fly upwards with the wings, deploy the mount and maintain the speed of the wings beyond the duration of the wings.
Using the Rod of Discord can be a great way to travel while using this mount, as it allows the player to teleport through tight areas rather than dismounting the UFO.
It is possible to give this mount to another player while mounted and still keep using the UFO.
The mobility of this mount and the ability to use items while riding it make it a good mount for construction.
If one needs to have an infinite flight mount underwater, the Cute Fishron Mount or the Witch's Broom are good replacements for the UFO.

This mount may not be the best to use in an arena for intense boss fights (such as the Empress of Light and Moon Lord ), as its infinite flight time is overshadowed by its rather slow speed, lack of dashing ability, and slow turning speed. It may be preferable to use the Cute Fishron with Honey and Water bubbles (which has a very fast speed along with boosting damage by 15% when in and shortly after leaving liquids) or to not use mounts at all and instead have the Soaring Insignia, the Expert mode -exclusive drop from the Empress of Light, which provides infinite flight time.
The buff tooltip is a reference to the film Independence Day, in which a Macintosh computer is used against an alien spaceship.

The name of the item might be a reference to a line in a rant about the insanity of everyday life by Eric T. Duckman from season 3, episode 6 "A Room with a Bellevue" from the American adult animated sitcom Duckman. The line goes, "...knowing when it's time to flash the cosmic car key at those Pearly Gates, I won't be in the coffin anyway...".
The Lunatic Cultist death sound will only play a maximum of once per minute, regardless of how many times the Cube touches lava.
The Companion Cube, if in complete darkness, does not need to touch the player to stab them.
The Companion Cube will move and bounce repeatedly through solid blocks to stay close to the player if they are more than 6 tiles away.
When sitting in a thin amount of lava and the player is standing still, the cube (when sitting in the lava) will bounce, disappear, and then reappear instantly where the player is standing.
The Companion Cube's stab attack can be avoided with dodging effects.
The Companion Cube is the single most expensive item in the entire game.
It is one of three pets that can make noises, the others being the Pet Worm (3DS version) and Glommer.

The Companion Cube is a reference to the Aperture Science Weighted Companion Cube from the puzzle-platforming video game series Portal. The Companion Cube reacting to lava is a reference to how the Companion Cube is disposed of in the original 2007 Portal game, by being dropped into an incinerator. The Companion Cube stabbing the player is a reference to a line spoken by GLaDOS in Portal, in which she states "The Enrichment Center reminds you that the Weighted Companion Cube will never threaten to stab you and, in fact, cannot speak." This line is also directly quoted in the buff's tooltip. The Companion Cube reacting to lava is a reference to how the Companion Cube is disposed of in the original 2007 Portal game, by being dropped into an incinerator. The Companion Cube stabbing the player is a reference to a line spoken by GLaDOS in Portal, in which she states "The Enrichment Center reminds you that the Weighted Companion Cube will never threaten to stab you and, in fact, cannot speak." This line is also directly quoted in the buff's tooltip.
Dying from being stabbed by the Companion Cube will display the following unique death message : " <Player name> was stabbed. "

If the world generated with Copper Ore instead of Tin Ore, then the only way to craft the Topaz Staff is to: Gather Tin Ore with the Extractinator. Mine Tin Ore from another World where it is naturally generated. Collect Tin Ore from slimes. Get Tin Ore and Tin Bars through fishing up crates. Transmute Iron Ore into Tin Ore via Shimmer Transmutation. Turn Copper Ore or Bars into Tin Ore or Bars via a Chlorophyte Extractinator. Gather Tin Ore with the Extractinator. Mine Tin Ore from another World where it is naturally generated. Collect Tin Ore from slimes. Get Tin Ore and Tin Bars through fishing up crates. Transmute Iron Ore into Tin Ore via Shimmer Transmutation. Turn Copper Ore or Bars into Tin Ore or Bars via a Chlorophyte Extractinator.

It has slow speed and low knockback, but even with the low starting base mana of 20, the staff can fire (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 4 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 5 consecutive shots.
Due to its somewhat slow projectile speed, this weapon suffers when facing moving aerial targets, such as the Demon Eye.

These Giant Bees gain the following boosts: Giant Bees always deal 1–3 extra damage and a knockback of 0.5 (Extremely weak), as opposed to a normal Bee's 1/2 (50%) chance to have 1 bonus damage. [2] Giant Bees can pierce enemies and ricochet off tiles for a total of three times instead of two, last 11 seconds instead of 10, and fly noticeably faster. [3] Giant Bees always deal 1–3 extra damage and a knockback of 0.5 (Extremely weak), as opposed to a normal Bee's 1/2 (50%) chance to have 1 bonus damage. [2] Giant Bees can pierce enemies and ricochet off tiles for a total of three times instead of two, last 11 seconds instead of 10, and fly noticeably faster. [3]
It also allows the Bee Gun, Bee Keeper, Honey Comb, and its derivative accessories an extra 1/3 (33.33%) chance to summon an additional bee projectile when used.
It also increases the firing rate of the Hornet Staff minions by 28.57%, and increases the damage and armor penetration of the Wasp Gun by 5. [4]
Like normal bees, Giant Bees will still dissipate immediately on contact with water or lava.
The Hive Pack will benefit the following bee-related items:
Despite being a higher-tierd item compared to the Silver, Lead, and Iron hammers, it is actually slower than these hammers. So players should avoid crafting the Gold Hammer.
Weapons that inflict damaging debuffs (like On Fire! ) are useful against these enemies, as they will take damage slowly even if they fly away.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The Wandering Eye counts towards the Demon Eye Banner.
The Bestiary entry for the Wandering Eye: " That suspicious feeling of being watched may very well come true in the dark of night, when Cthulhu's minions roam the skies. "
If multiple stacks of Temple Keys exist in the inventory, trying to unlock a Lihzahrd Door will consume one key from every stack.
Temple Keys cannot open Temple doors that are missing the top or bottom block of the door frame. This makes a standalone "Keyhole" of a locked Lihzahrd Door completely indestructible by any means.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, this item is useless after it is used to unlock the Jungle Temple, as it cannot be used to craft anything and has no value when sold.
As with all melee projectiles, the fly distance increases with faster attack speed.
The knife travels approximately 30 tiles before dropping.
It cannot get speed modifiers, making accessories, armor, and buffs the only way to increase its velocity.

The effects of the Shadowflame debuff will stack with those of On Fire!, Cursed Inferno, and Frostburn. Using the Shadowflame Knife with a Magma Stone or a Fire Gauntlet, a Flask of Cursed Flames and Frost armor facilitates inflicting all of those at once.

The Shadowflame Knife can be considered a melee alternative to the Magic Dagger. It has similar stats, costs no mana, has autoswing and flies faster than it. Although it does not pierce, its ability to ricochet can make up for it.

This weapon is a good option for melee players in early-to-mid Hardmode. It can be acquired immediately from a Goblin Army and its versatility as an unlimited projectile along with its debuff makes it extremely useful against Hardmode enemies and even the mechanical bosses, particularly The Destroyer, due to its bouncing ability allowing one knife to hit the boss up to three times.
Its falling and ricocheting properties might cause it to accidentally hit and activate a Biome Mimic, which can be fatal in early Hardmode.

A way to farm Man Eaters is to find a chain of horizontal caves in the Underground Jungle and dig a long passage between them, and then make two rows of platforms. Running between the platforms makes encountering a Man Eater faster. If any Hornets spawn, simply knock them up into the air, and they will not be able to pass down through the platform.

Vines are used in several crafting recipes, but always in smaller quantities than Stingers or (especially) Jungle Spores. Any excess relative to those more profitable materials can only be sold at its own low price.
The effects of the Tackle Box do not stack with the Angler Tackle Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or the Lavaproof Tackle Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
On average, the Tackle Box makes any given bait last one reel-in longer. See Bait power for the full details.

Two bait items are unaffected by the Tackle Box: Truffle Worms are always consumed. Gold Worms always have a fixed 1/20 (5%) chance to be consumed. Truffle Worms are always consumed. Gold Worms always have a fixed 1/20 (5%) chance to be consumed.
The High Test Fishing Line, Angler Earring, and Tackle Box are interchangable with Shimmer.
The Winged Slime Mount has a maximum speed of 33 mph on land, 102 mph when falling straight down, and 116 mph when falling diagonally.

This mount can essentially be used as wings, as it allows short flight and gliding. This means that wings can be somewhat avoided, along with other movement accessories. This can make a lot of room for combat accessories. This means that wings can be somewhat avoided, along with other movement accessories. This can make a lot of room for combat accessories.
The maximum horizontal speed is greater when in free fall than when moving on land, so it is recommended to keep jumping if trying to maintain maximum speed.

Exhausting the flight time on the mount's wings will also exhaust the flight time on the player's wings, and vice versa, though mounting/un-mounting before exhausting will allow the player to essentially combine the flight times.
The Gelatinous Pillion is faster than most sprinting accessories on land, except for the Lightning, Frostspark, and Terraspark Boots, where it moves 1 mph slower.
Its damage is considered summon damage, so accessories like the Summoner Emblem can increase it further.

Equipping wings with boost abilities like the Jetpack will allow the player to reach much higher altitudes with the Gelatinous Pillion. This is achieved by holding ▲ Up while flying with the wings and switching to the mount midair, which makes it accelerate upwards dramatically.
Due to the high fall speed of the mount, and the fact that it does not increase the player's width, it is useful for getting down a hellevator faster.
The Gelatinous Pillion is somewhat synonymous to the Slimy Saddle, but both imply different meanings.
In real life, a pillion is a cushion attached behind a saddle for an additional passenger. This is not the case in the game, however, as the Gelatinous Pillion is the actual saddle itself.

This set references one of the representative works of Spike Chunsoft (the publisher of the Japanese version of Terraria ), the Shiren the Wanderer series. This set was added as a replacement for the Plumber's set due to copyright concerns over the latter costume. As such, the method of obtaining both sets is completely identical. [2]

Since this set is exclusive to Japanese Console, it has only Japanese name and no official English name. The meaning of its Japanese name is "Wanderer's costume". The Japanese name of this set is "ふうらいにんの衣装" when transliterated into Japanese kanji as "風来人の衣装" (Furainin no Ishō, Furainin's costume), where "風来人" (Furainin) has the same meaning with "風来坊" (ふうらいぼう) in Japanese, means a traveler with unknown identity and no fixed abode, which is similar to the meaning of "Wanderer" in English. The Japanese name of the Shiren Hat in this set is "さんどがさ" when transliterated into Japanese kanji as "三度笠" (Sandogasa), refers to the hat worn by traveling merchants and monks in Japan. The Japanese name of The Shiren Shirt is "ふうらいにんのふく" when transliterated into Japanese kanji as "風来人の服" (Furainin no Fuku), means Furainin's skirt. The Japanese name of The Shiren Pants is "ふうらいにんのこしあて" when transliterated into Japanese kanji as "風来人の腰当" (Furainin no Kusiate), means Furainin's waistband.
