Minions cannot normally deal critical hits, only by wearing a full set of Monk armor (16.7%) or Shinobi Infiltrator armor (25%) with any of the Lightning Aura sentry summons or by using a Morning Star (12%) or Kaleidoscope (10%) with any minion can crits be dealt at a fixed rate depending on which is used.
Players attacking other players in PvP will also not deal critical hits.
Damage is doubled after being reduced by defense.
When held, weapon modifiers affect all outgoing critical hits from that class's projectiles. Weapon modifiers will cease affecting critical chance when not selected.
While ammo might seem to be affected by crit bonuses, crit chance actually entirely depends on weapon stats.
It is generally best to attempt to equalize total accessory crit chance bonus and total accessory damage bonus, as this will maximize the overall DPS.
Despite the name of the item, its color was a reddish orange rather than gold (though the summoned Turtle was gold).
The turtle's flying animation may have been a reference to Gamera, a Japanese turtle monster similar to Godzilla that could fly, breathe fire, and was a friend to a child who loved turtles.
Lead Ore will not be generated at all in Constant worlds.

Lead Ore and Iron Ore are the only ores that do not have corresponding chandeliers. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, they are also the only ores that do not have corresponding bricks.
Real lead is very soft, malleable, and poisonous, generally making it infeasible for crafting tools. The use of lead in Terraria more closely resembles real-life steel.

This tool functions much like drills or chainsaws, in that it mines via a "machine" with constant directed contact, rather than being swung repeatedly at targets. While there are several drills and chainsaws fulfilling pickaxe and axe duties via a machine method, the Chlorophyte Jackhammer is the only such tool fulfilling hammer duty.
In real life, jackhammers are actually digging tools rather than hammering tools.
The Chlorophyte Jackhammer is the only jackhammer in-game.
Etherian Javelin Throwers spawn less frequently than Etherian Goblins and Etherian Goblin Bombers.
The Bestiary entry for the Etherian Javelin Thrower: " These bulky brutes are awkward and ungainly, but their javelins are still razor sharp, and their aim is deadly. "
It is the only punch to give the Plenty Satisfied buff instead of the Well Fed buff, due to the fruits used to make it, the Star Fruit and Dragon Fruit, also granting Plenty Satisfied.
The tooltip, "Feel the rainbow, taste the crystal!" is likely a reference to Skittles ' slogan, "Feel the rainbow, taste the rainbow!"
Its item tooltip emphasizes the absurdity of a gold goldfish, which has a similar structure to a pleonasm.
The best way to make money with these is to craft Queen Spider Staffs, which sell for 5 GC each.
Crafting all items requires (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 79 / (Old-gen console version) 76 Spider Fangs.
Prior to the 1.3.0.1 update, Red's Wings had the ability to hover and granted unlimited flight.

According to a post made by Redigit, this set is inspired by the armor of Golbez, the primary antagonist from the role-playing video game Final Fantasy IV. [1] Red's Wings may also be a reference the Red Wings of Baron, the antagonistic army which Golbez led at one point of the game. Red's Wings may also be a reference the Red Wings of Baron, the antagonistic army which Golbez led at one point of the game.

Prior to 1.3, if the Frost Breastplate and Leggings were paired with a Gold Helmet, and all pieces were dyed with Blue Flame and Black Dye, it would cause an afterimage and pulsing aura, akin to Hallowed armor. This was the armor Red used to wear before this set was added.

The Venus Magnum is a direct upgrade of the Uzi, as it also converts Musket Balls and Tungsten Bullets into High Velocity Bullets, and has slightly better stats across the board. (Old-gen console version) In the Old-gen console version, the Venus Magnum cannot autofire, which means the Uzi has at least one advantage over it. (Old-gen console version) In the Old-gen console version, the Venus Magnum cannot autofire, which means the Uzi has at least one advantage over it.
In appearance, the Venus Magnum seems to resemble The Undertaker, but with a laser sight and different colors.
The Sniper Rifle, Uzi, and Venus Magnum all share the same tooltip.

In real life, magnum refers to a class of firearm cartridges that are known for having much more power than their projectile size would normally suggest, such as the.357 Magnum (from which the term is derived),.44 Magnum,.460 S&W Magnum, and.500 S&W Magnum for handguns, as well as.300 Winchester Magnum and.338 Lapua Magnum for rifles (among others), all much more powerful than their standard counterparts.
It is a very effective weapon against the Brain of Cthulhu, as it can easily kill the Creepers in the first phase and knock it back in the second phase.

Modifier prefixes are added in front of the "The" in its name, which can result in a grammatically incorrect name such as "Keen The Rotted Fork". It shares this trait with all other items that can obtain modifiers and whose names begin with "The". This error is not present in the Old-gen console version.
Despite appearing to be a weapon made of Crimtane Bars and Tissue Samples, it is uncraftable.
It resembles a real-world guandao, a type of Chinese pole weapon that is used in some forms of Chinese martial arts.
Strangely, there is no Corruption equivalent to The Rotted Fork, despite the Ball O' Hurt having a Crimson equivalent in The Meatball.
Minions and NPCs will continue to attack all nearby slimes.
Since Gastropods and Toxic Sludges are considered slimes, they are affected by the Royal Gel as well.
This accessory is particularly valuable during Slime Rain, as it allows the player to kill almost all enemies without worrying about taking damage.

This accessory can keep Lava Slimes away while building a bridge for the Wall of Flesh, especially useful since they spread lava on death. In Hardmode, they can prevent Gastropods from shooting the player with lasers, making it much easier to fish or farm enemies in the Hallow at night.
This accessory can be a very useful tool in the Underground Jungle and Ice biome early on, as it prevents Spiked Jungle Slimes and Spiked Ice Slimes from shooting their thorns at the player.
The Royal Gel's name may be inspired by royal jelly, a food substance that bee workers feed to bee larvae to change how they grow, specifically so the larvae can become a queen bee.
Royal Gel appears in the video game Core Keeper as an item of the same name, as part of a crossover.
All Golf Balls are obtainable pre-Hardmode, and none are visible on the character.

Nearly all platform variants are functionally identical, and are differentiated only by their appearance and their crafting recipes. Obsidian, Stone and Ash Wood Platforms are an exception, in that they do not break upon contact with lava the way most platforms do, although they will still disintegrate if dropped or thrown into it. Team Platforms can be broken by lava; however, they cannot be destroyed due to their rarity. Meteorite Platforms' bright spots show up when exposed to any amount of light. This can make them visible even in the darkness surrounding a light source. Echo Platforms are completely invisible when placed and cannot be seen by the player unless they have Spectre Goggles equipped or are near an Echo Chamber. Team Platforms can be broken by lava; however, they cannot be destroyed due to their rarity. Meteorite Platforms' bright spots show up when exposed to any amount of light. This can make them visible even in the darkness surrounding a light source. Echo Platforms are completely invisible when placed and cannot be seen by the player unless they have Spectre Goggles equipped or are near an Echo Chamber.

Hooks can attach to platforms. While grappling to a platform on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it is impossible to grapple to anything else, regardless of the direction the hook is fired in. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the hook will ignore all platforms covered by the player's body.
The player will fall through platforms while in a Minecart.
Wraiths cannot fly up using platforms but are able to hover on top of them.
On Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile versions, the dungeon, wood, brass, and metal shelves can be crafted at the Bone Welder with Ecto Mist.
Stairs are a key part of many advanced movement techniques, such as hoiks, NPC-proof doors, elevators, or enemy traps.
Similarly to ordinary blocks, it is possible to remove every second platform in a row of platforms without movement disadvantages, as the player is two tiles wide and will not fall through.
Echo Coating is cheaper than Echo Platforms and has an almost identical invisibility effect.

As the Harpoon is one of the few sources of ranged damage that does not consume ammo, this weapon makes a decent (albeit weak later in the game) backup weapon for characters specializing in ranged weapons and armor. Eventually, however, it is eclipsed by Hardmode weapons like the Piranha Gun and the Toxikarp.

Once launched, the player is unable to switch away from the Harpoon before the projectile returns, making distant shots risky as it will leave the user vulnerable if they miss. It should be optimally used for close to mid-range combat.

When surrounded by weaker enemies, it may be a good idea to fire over the crowd, hitting them all on the return trip, rather than firing straight in front of the player and only hitting one enemy at a time.

The auto-fire rate of the Harpoon is greater the closer an enemy is. It can deal large amounts of damage against strong Fighter AI enemies like the Nymph or even the Chaos Elemental at very close range.
The Harpoon was originally called Harpoonitron prior to release. [1]
The Anchor can be considered the Harpoon's Hardmode upgrade because of its similar mechanics. It is a melee weapon, however.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the more powerful versions generally have shorter durations but are still fairly accessible. For food items that provide Exquisitely Stuffed, Burgers, dropped from Crimeras and Eaters of Souls, are the easiest ones to obtain from enemies. Golden Delights, crafted from gold critters, provide 48 minutes of Exquisitely Stuffed, the longest-lasting buff of all Well Fed tiers, but can be hard to obtain, let alone farm, due to the critters' rarity. Easier methods of obtaining a sustainable supply of Exquisitely Stuffed food would be to grind rare enemies in the Dungeon to obtain BBQ Ribs, or break Pigronatas to get Bacon, which is a quicker and easier process but comes at the expense of spending large amounts of coins. Food items that provide Plenty Satisfied are dropped much more commonly, most notably Banana Splits, dropped from most pre-Hardmode Underground Desert enemies. The Bowl of Soup, Sashimi, Pumpkin Pie, Monster Lasagna, and Froggle Bunwich can be easily crafted from more common materials. Food items that provide the Well Fed buff are the easiest to obtain, such as Cooked Marshmallows, Cooked Fish crafted from plentiful fishing catches, Bunny Stew from Bunnies, Roasted Bird from Birds, Penguins, and Seagulls, and fruit obtained by shaking trees. For food items that provide Exquisitely Stuffed, Burgers, dropped from Crimeras and Eaters of Souls, are the easiest ones to obtain from enemies. Golden Delights, crafted from gold critters, provide 48 minutes of Exquisitely Stuffed, the longest-lasting buff of all Well Fed tiers, but can be hard to obtain, let alone farm, due to the critters' rarity. Easier methods of obtaining a sustainable supply of Exquisitely Stuffed food would be to grind rare enemies in the Dungeon to obtain BBQ Ribs, or break Pigronatas to get Bacon, which is a quicker and easier process but comes at the expense of spending large amounts of coins. Food items that provide Plenty Satisfied are dropped much more commonly, most notably Banana Splits, dropped from most pre-Hardmode Underground Desert enemies. The Bowl of Soup, Sashimi, Pumpkin Pie, Monster Lasagna, and Froggle Bunwich can be easily crafted from more common materials. Food items that provide the Well Fed buff are the easiest to obtain, such as Cooked Marshmallows, Cooked Fish crafted from plentiful fishing catches, Bunny Stew from Bunnies, Roasted Bird from Birds, Penguins, and Seagulls, and fruit obtained by shaking trees.

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, this buff is simpler, but is still extremely useful as it is easy to obtain, extremely versatile, and has a long duration. During Halloween, Pumpkins for Pumpkin Pie are plentiful. Other food items can be crafted or picked up from varied sources. Alternatively, a modest amount of fishing for other purposes can provide enough fish to keep a player well-fed despite the shorter duration. During Halloween, Pumpkins for Pumpkin Pie are plentiful. Other food items can be crafted or picked up from varied sources. Alternatively, a modest amount of fishing for other purposes can provide enough fish to keep a player well-fed despite the shorter duration.

Most players should carry a stack of "food" items, and try to keep the buff always active. The movement bonus alone would make that worthwhile, but in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) food is even more important, as it is required to regenerate health normally. In any mode, the small but broad boost to combat abilities comes in handy. This is especially true in The Constant (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) seed, where the player can die from starving. This is especially true in The Constant (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) seed, where the player can die from starving.
Exquisitely Stuffed completely negates the defense decrease of the Tipsy debuff, making the effect much more beneficial to the player.

Using this buff before boss fights or venturing into dangerous areas can afford the player a cheap and easy advantage. The bonuses to movement and mining speed make it worthwhile even for exploring and mining.
The Cooked Marshmallow is currently the only food item that has the same duration on all platforms.

The buff icon for each food buff is a Roasted Bird (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), a Seafood Dinner (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and a Roasted Duck (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) respectively. Roasted Duck does not give the Exquisitely Stuffed buff, despite its icon usage. Instead, it gives Plenty Satisfied. Roasted Duck does not give the Exquisitely Stuffed buff, despite its icon usage. Instead, it gives Plenty Satisfied.
Each activation produces a 10-second fountain.
The fountain effect reaches about 20 feet (10 tiles) high and travels through blocks.

Much like the Terraria critters, real-life pupfish are usually only found in intense conditions and isolated locations, such as the rare Devils Hole pupfish which is only found in its namesake, a water-filled cave in Nevada.
Unlike the Gold Fish Bowl, the Pupfish Bowl is not an armor or accessory item, nor is the Pupfish a consumable food ingredient.

While the Cell Phone is based on the more popular slate smartphones, the Shellphone is based on the clamshell form factor, which declined in popularity after the 2000s but has regained some popular status with the trend of foldable smartphones.

The Shellphone's tooltip references both the belief that conch shells sound like the ocean (as referenced in the Magic Conch 's tooltip) and car warranty scams, a type of scam which is widely propagated via cell phone spam calling.
The Shellphone has the second most complicated item crafting tree with 16 items, surpassed by the Zenith, which has 22.

Using the "dummy" Shellphone (the one without a target location; item ID 5437) will cause the character to hold the Shellphone up and make the warping sound effect, but not move the character anywhere.
It has one of the slowest use times in the game, tied with the Magic Conch, Demon Conch, Magic Mirrors, Cell Phone, and Snake Charmer's Flute.

Though it has infinite ammo, the Endless Musket Pouch only counts as one in the ammo count on a weapon (as seen in the lower-right corner of its icon in the closed inventory's hotbar). Consequently, if the player's only ammo (in bullets) left is the Endless Musket Pouch, the ammo count will only read one, instead of infinity.

The Endless Musket Pouch follows the same ammunition priority rules as other ammo types. If held in the inventory, bullets in the dedicated ammo slots will be fired first, followed by those further up and to the left in the player's inventory. While in the ammo slots, those above it will be fired. Players can use this to quickly alternate between infinite and special ammo.
Players exclusively using an Endless Musket Pouch gain no benefit from effects that decrease ammo consumption, and are free to dedicate equipment and accessories to other effects.
The Endless Musket Pouch can be obtained right after initiating Hardmode by finding the Wizard, buying the Crystal Ball, and purchasing 3996 Musket Balls from the Arms Dealer.
It is highly useful when paired with rapid-firing weapons such as the Uzi or S.D.M.G., as these tend to deplete ammo quickly, even with the S.D.M.G.'s ammo conservation chance.

The Endless Musket Pouch may be less useful in Journey Mode because the player can simply duplicate Musket Balls or any other type of bullet. However, not needing to frequently restock on Musket Balls does prove useful in Journey Mode as well.
While the cost of 3996 Musket Balls is 2 GC 79 SC 72 CC, an Endless Musket Pouch only sells for 1 GC. Hence, there is no profit in producing Endless Musket Pouches for resale.
As mentioned before, the Endless Musket Pouch can be used to reserve other finite projectiles for more important fights, like Ichor or Chlorophyte Bullets.

The Endless Musket Pouch is useful for fighting the Dungeon Guardian, as it has 9999 defense and only takes 1 damage per attack, meaning that ammunition type does not matter as they will all inflict 1–2 damage. This allows it to be slain without an excessive consumption of ammunition.
Despite needing to be crafted in Hardmode, its rarity is 02*.
Prior to 1.4.4, the crafting recipe used to require 4 stacks of Musket Balls, as they could only stack to 999.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Despite Pink Prickly Pears having Corruption/Crimson/Hallow variants, they can only grow on regular or Hallowed Cacti, and the remaining two variants can only be created by biome changes (e.g. due to biome spread or solutions ). [1]
Although Pink Prickly Pears are available in placed form on the Nintendo 3DS version, breaking one never yields an item.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Selling the ore rather than the bar yields 2 SC more per bar.
Aaron's Breastplate is the first item in alphabetical order of all items by its internal name.
This is the only developer set to have only three items.
In Drunk worlds, Bee Hives are significantly larger, have irregular outlines, and often contain multiple Larvae. Because of this, the amount of Bee Hives per world are typically less than normal.
Honey and Honey Blocks naturally spawn in small amounts in the Underground Jungle, however, contrary to popular belief, this is not a sign that a Bee Hive is nearby.

The bottom of the hive will be filled with honey. Standing in the honey provides a regeneration buff, but greatly slows the player's movement, which makes dodging difficult. If a player is stuck in the honey pool when they accidentally spawn Queen Bee, they will be acutely vulnerable and likely take many hits before they can escape. Placing platforms can help avoid falling into the honey pool. Care should be taken not to place platforms or anything else on a Larva, as that will break it.

A Larva can be hidden under the surface of the honey. If a hive seems not to have a visible Larva (or a large hive has only one) the player should be very cautious about using weapons in the honey or shooting into it, lest they face a surprise attack from the Queen Bee.
Any water poured onto the honey will create Honey Blocks. If a Larva is partly submerged or just under the surface, the forming blocks will break the Larva, summoning Queen Bee as usual.

If a hive is large enough, it can be made into a decent arena by (optionally) clearing the walls of the hive and adding platforms. This is not only useful for the Queen Bee fight, but also for the Plantera fight.

Wearing Chlorophyte armor or Orichalcum armor in the Underground Jungle is risky; either set bonus can accidentally break a Larva somewhere in the distance, setting off an unexpected Queen Bee fight. At this point the player should be fairly well equipped with Hardmode gear, but even so, a player can be caught off-guard.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Should the player be staying in a Bee Hive for extended periods of time, such as when building arenas for future battles against the Queen Bee, it may prove difficult or even life-threatening to survive due to the large numbers of Hornets that frequently accumulate within Bee Hives. For dealing with multiple Hornets, ranged weapons such as the Musket, Undertaker, or gem staves can be useful for eliminating them quickly, as well as equipping a Bezoar, submerging in honey to get its regeneration buff, and placing Hornet Banners around the hive. The player should also try to place blocks around the Larvae to avoid accidentally awakening the Queen Bee by firing arrows or bullets at them. Weapons that can pierce enemies or travel through blocks such as whips, the Vilethorn, and the Gray Zapinator should be avoided or used extremely carefully within the hive's enclosed spaces.
Bee Hives usually have one Larva, but larger hives can contain two Larvae, and smaller hives have a low chance of not containing any Larva.
Very rarely, two Bee Hives can overlap, making one giant Bee Hive.

This helmet resembles a real-life hard hat, which is a piece of safety gear worn by workers on a job site to protect themselves from falling objects and frayed wiring. Engineers working on a job site are, in most countries, required to wear a hard hat.

The Engineering Helmet is most likely a reference to the Engineer from the 2007 first-person shooter video game Team Fortress 2, due to their extreme visual similarities and usage of similar clothing in the 1.3.1 spoilers.
The Engineering Helmet seamlessly connects with the Architect Gizmo Pack.
If the Dirt Block that the Blinkroot is planted on turns into a grass block, the Blinkroot will break, dropping as an item.
Blinkroots grow slightly faster when placed below surface. [1]
Blinkroots are most commonly found in the Underground layer and below, due to the general lack of grass in those areas.

Due to its random blooming behavior, mass farming methods may be less feasible with this herb. Each mass harvest would need to be triggered manually based on a visual inspection of how much of the crop is currently in-bloom, to ensure enough seeds drop for replanting.
Due to its blinking nature, it can be useful for finding unexplored cave systems through its visibility beyond the walls that the player has already discovered.
Blinkroot is the fastest-growing herb in the game, capable of being harvested within seconds of planting.
The Party Girl NPC mentions Blinkroot in one of her quotes: " We should set up a blinkroot party, and we should also set up an after-party. "

Similarly, the Pirate NPC will occasionally reference Blinkroots, saying: " Yo ho ho and a bottle of....blinkroots! ". This is a play on the original expression often attributed to pirates, "Yo ho ho and a bottle of rum!"
The Bestiary entry for the Etherian Goblin Bomber: " Hurling bombs with reckless abandon, these sappers serve the Old One's Army with maniacal passion. "

The spawn rate of Butterflies/Stinkbugs are set to a random value at every dusk (7:30 PM), or each time the world is loaded, making them spawn at different amounts every day. They will be more common in Celebrationmk10 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. See below for the detailed spawn condition.
New players should be on the lookout for days when lots of butterflies spawn, since they can fetch high prices. One day can easily net over 10 GC.
Butterflies: " Beautiful fluttering insects that love sunrises. Fish are attracted to these based on their color variety. "
Hell Butterfly: " A solemn butterfly seeking blooms rooted in hell. Its wings glimmer with fiery veins. "
The Rock Lobster's name and tooltip, 'But it wasn't a rock!', are references to the 1978 song " Rock Lobster " by the new wave band The B-52s.

The temporary Ice Block summoned by the Ice Rod is unrelated to Ice Blocks found naturally in Snow biomes. Summoned Ice Blocks cannot be collected or placed, and break automatically about 15 seconds after summoning.
Wall -mounted light fixtures like Torches will switch to a placed Ice Block over a background wall until it breaks.
Storage items cannot be placed on summoned Ice Blocks.

Due to being considered blocks and not projectiles, the temporary Ice Blocks can be actuated, hammered, and painted (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions). This means it can be used to make suitable housing, although only temporarily. This means it can be used to make suitable housing, although only temporarily.
Ice Skates, Frostspark Boots, or Terraspark Boots (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) greatly enhance mobility on the Ice Blocks created by the Ice Rod.
Aside from its useful block-placing capabilities, the Ice Rod can prove to be an effective magic weapon during early Hardmode, due to its ease of obtaining as well as its high fire rate.

The Ice Rod can be used with wings to repeatedly reset flight time in midair, by casting an Ice Block beneath the player's feet as they start falling. The flight timer will be reset as soon as they land on the Ice Block.

Regular blocks can be placed adjacent to the created Ice Blocks, which can prove useful in building floating structures (especially at higher elevations such as in Space ), as it is not necessary to build a temporary connection from the ground or a Floating Island to the building site.

Since the Ice Blocks created can be grappled to with a hook or similar device, the Ice Rod can be used to reach areas high above the surface, such as Floating Islands, more easily. While "stairs" are also possible, caution should be taken not to fall off.

The Ice Rod's ability to fire through its own Ice Blocks creates unique shielding possibilities during combat – while the player can fire through their shield of Ice Blocks, enemies and their attacks are impeded by the blocks. This gives it surprising utility in PvP combat, where attacks generally do much greater damage and tend to travel too fast to dodge. This gives it surprising utility in PvP combat, where attacks generally do much greater damage and tend to travel too fast to dodge.
Upon shattering, summoned Ice Blocks release illuminated sparks that travel down through blocks, making the Ice Rod useful for discovering ores and caves.

This content is transcluded from Vanity Accessories/tip. Because vanity accessories such as the Glass Slipper cannot be reforged to grant any benefits besides appearance, it is recommended to equip them in the player's social accessory slots.
The Glass Slipper is a reference to the classic fairy tale Cinderella by the Brothers Grimm. It also plays a notable role in the original 1950 Disney classic by the same name.
Crafting any of the helmets and selling them is more profitable than selling the bars required to make them.

Since the value of Holy Protection depends on how much damage the player would have taken in a single hit, wearing Hallowed armor is one of the best ways to increase survivability while using an offensive-focused accessory loadout.

The Hallowed Mask provides enormous defense and considerable melee bonuses, and can be substituted onto other armor sets (such as Turtle armor or Squire armor ) for significantly improved overall stats.
Unlike other summoner armors, the summoner variant of Hallowed armor provides modest bonuses to melee, ranged, and magic, making it a formidable mixed-class armor set.

The Hallowed Hood provides the lowest defense out of all Hardmode armor pieces, despite it being available after defeating a mechanical boss. Additionally, the Hallowed summoner set provides lower summon damage than Spider armor, an early Hardmode summoner armor set, with the former providing only +17% summon damage, compared to the latter's +28% summon damage. Additionally, the Hallowed summoner set provides lower summon damage than Spider armor, an early Hardmode summoner armor set, with the former providing only +17% summon damage, compared to the latter's +28% summon damage.
Sometimes, the heads of the duplicates created by Holy Protection will not be visible.
Hallowed armor is the only armor set that has variations for all four classes.

According to Redigit, the Hallowed armor's design is inspired by the paladin armor of Cecil Harvey, the protagonist of Final Fantasy IV. [1] The resemblance is most apparent when the armor is worn with Hallowed Headgear. The resemblance is most apparent when the armor is worn with Hallowed Headgear.
Its tooltip is a reference to the 2003 namesake song " Milkshake " from Tasty, the third studio album by American singer Kelis.
At exactly 0 mph, the game will prefer westward wind, but due to the decimal system used for wind speeds, this value will often be near, but not exactly 0.

On the title screen, wind is initialized with speeds up to 40 mph. This will not carry over to generated worlds, however, which will instead start with winds up to 20 mph. Due to the these initial speeds, there is a 1/400 chance that the world will spawn with a Windy Day in progress. Due to the these initial speeds, there is a 1/400 chance that the world will spawn with a Windy Day in progress.
Winds will decrease to zero during Lantern Nights, provided the player is not controlling the windspeed with Journey Mode.

Only the target wind speed will be saved with a world, and when the same world is loaded the current wind speed will be set to the target. This can cause slight differences in wind speeds when a player exits and re-enters a world.

On the Desktop, Console, and Mobile versions, one-half of the world generation progress bar will be green, and the other half purple or red, depending on if the world is to have Corruption or Crimson. The step in world generation in which the Corruption is created is called " Making the world evil ", and the step in world generation in which the Crimson is created is called " Making the world bloody ". Also, a tree at the side of the world name in world selection has one green/normal side, the other purple/red (indicating Corruption/Crimson respectively). In Hardmode, part of the tree will be yellow, representing The Hallow.
Drunk (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds always contain both evil biomes.
A compass rose is a symbol commonly found on maps and other navigational equipment to indicate the directions north, south, east, and west.
When used with worlds generated prior to the release of the 1.2 update, it only shows areas visited while playing under 1.2 or later.
If Autopause is enabled, it will unpause when viewing the full-screen map.
Paint shows up on the map, allowing the player to mark sections of the map (assuming enough paint of a distinctive enough color is used).
If the player enables the full-screen map and zooms out the maximum amount, the map will appear as a handheld map, and a background corresponding to the player's current biome will be shown.
When a character is moved to the cloud, minimap files can be deleted.
In the Old-gen console version, the minimap is already lit, revealing things very far away from the player.
During a Thunderstorm, the minimap background will be dark, with the occasional flashing synced to the lightning strikes in the overworld.
If the player does not have any light sources, they can use the zoomed-in Overlay Mode to see where they are going. However, enemies will not show up on the minimap.
This item is a reference to the farm life simulation role-playing game Stardew Valley, in which the Blue Chicken is a rare variant of normal Chickens.
The buff tooltip is a reference to the fact that in Stardew Valley, Blue Chickens are only available after the player has earned enough friendship with Shane, an NPC in the game.
In Stardew Valley, blue chickens actually hatch from white eggs, and there are no blue eggs.

Tree Globes only work when thrown onto biome grass or snow. When thrown into another biome while in a different biome, no change of styles will occur. When thrown into another biome while in a different biome, no change of styles will occur.
The only biomes affected by the Tree Globe are the Forest, Jungle and Snow biome due to them having the only trees with alternate styles.
Trees in the Hallow are not affected by the Tree Globe, but instead have styles that match with specific Hallow backgrounds. Thus, Hallowed trees can only be changed with World Globes.

Even when it could be obtained with hacks or inventory editors, the Icemourne was never a usable weapon. Although its name, sprite, and overhead swinging animation did work, trying to use it as a weapon would not affect the enemy.
In Nintendo 3DS version, the item tooltip referred to it as "placeable", and it would turn into an Angel Statue when placed.
This sword's name and appearance is a reference to the Frostmourne from the Warcraft franchise. It was likely removed because it would violate the copyright agreement of Blizzard Entertainment.

Upon killing an enemy (except a Mother Slime, a Corrupt Slime or a Slimer with wings), there is a 1/6 (16.67%) chance (which is affected by luck (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) ) to start a drop attempt. If this succeeds, then check if the player has full mana; if not, then there is a 1/2 (50%) chance (which is unaffected by luck) for the enemy to drop a Star. If the player has full mana or the Star drop attempt failed, then there is a 1/2 (50%) chance (which is unaffected by luck) for the enemy to drop a Heart. After finishing the drop attempts above, and the player does not have full mana, then there is another 1/2 (50%) chance (which is affected by luck) a Star will drop. If this succeeds, then check if the player has full mana; if not, then there is a 1/2 (50%) chance (which is unaffected by luck) for the enemy to drop a Star. If the player has full mana or the Star drop attempt failed, then there is a 1/2 (50%) chance (which is unaffected by luck) for the enemy to drop a Heart. After finishing the drop attempts above, and the player does not have full mana, then there is another 1/2 (50%) chance (which is affected by luck) a Star will drop. After finishing the drop attempts above, and the player does not have full mana, then there is another 1/2 (50%) chance (which is affected by luck) a Star will drop.

In addition to the standard drop, the following enemies have additional Heart drops or have a unique chance of dropping Hearts upon death: [2] Creeper : 1/2 (50%) chance if player does not have full health. Segments of the Eater of Worlds : 1/4 (25%) chance if player does not have full health. The Hungry and Leech : 1/1 (100%) / 1/5 (20%) chance. Probe : 1/2 (50%) chance. Gingerbread Man : 1/3 (33.33%) chance. Scarecrow, Hellhound, and Poltergeist : 1/4 (25%) chance. Zombie Elf : 1/5 (20%) chance. Splinterling : 1/6 (16.67%) chance. Headless Horseman : drops 1 Heart. Present Mimic : drops 5-10 Hearts. Mourning Wood, Pumpking, Everscream, Santa-NK1, and Ice Queen : drop 6-11 Hearts. All non-event bosses : drop 5-9 Hearts.
