The total bonuses are composed of the following: +10% summon damage from each piece +1 minion capacity from each piece and +1 minion capacity from full set bonus. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +10% whip range from the mask and +20% whip range from full set bonus. +10% summon damage from each piece +1 minion capacity from each piece and +1 minion capacity from full set bonus. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +10% whip range from the mask and +20% whip range from full set bonus.
Tiki armor is often used before the player obtains Spooky armor, due to its high stats and ease of obtaining right after defeating Plantera.

The Tiki armor currently allows achieving the second highest minion boost when equipped along with the Pygmy Necklace, Necromantic Scroll, and Papyrus Scarab, and the Summoning and Bewitched buffs, which push the minion count to 10 (1 from base, 3 from accessories, 2 from buffs, and 4 from armor). The highest minion count is 11 and comes from using the Stardust armor (1 on helmet, 2 on chest, 2 on pants), along with the previously mentioned equipment and buffs. This is not counting the Stardust Guardian, or sentry-style minions, which can increase this number by up to 5 for 16 minions total.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It is often a good idea to use Spooky armor to first summon the minions (for the increased damage), before switching to Tiki armor to gain the bonus minion.
Unlike Ice Blocks, Ice Walls do not have Corruption, Crimson, or Hallowed counterparts.
The Imp attacks with an average rate of fire of once every 1.13 seconds. The delay between attacks can range between 0.75 seconds and 1.5 seconds. [1]
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Imp Fireball applies 6 ticks of static immunity frames upon hitting an enemy, which means that multiple Imps will consistently interfere with each other.

While the Imp can fly through water, its fireball projectiles cannot travel through water. They stop at the water's surface and will not appear at all when the Imp is submerged in water. Regardless, the Imp will still attempt to fire at underwater enemies.

Despite receiving a fire rate buff in Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it has a significantly slower fire rate than the Hornet Staff. This means that its damage output is only slightly better against a single target. Due to their very slow attack speed, Imps receive very little benefit from whip tag damage or armor penetration compared to the much faster Vampire Frogs or even the Flinx minions. Due to their very slow attack speed, Imps receive very little benefit from whip tag damage or armor penetration compared to the much faster Vampire Frogs or even the Flinx minions.

(Old-gen console version) It is possible to obtain this weapon at the very start of the game without having to defeat a boss, giving early summoners a huge advantage. This can be done by fishing a Reaver Shark at the Ocean, which requires nothing more than a Reinforced Fishing Pole and worms as bait. With the Reaver Shark, the player can immediately venture to the Underworld and obtain Hellstone in order to craft the Imp Staff. As of 1.4.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the Reaver Shark's pickaxe power has been significantly reduced, rendering it unable to mine Hellstone. As of 1.4.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the Reaver Shark's pickaxe power has been significantly reduced, rendering it unable to mine Hellstone.

Lava Slimes, Dungeon Slimes, King Slime, Spiked Slimes, Gastropods, Queen Slime, Crystal Slimes, Bouncy Slimes, Heavenly Slimes, Hoppin' Jacks, Golden Slimes, and statue-spawned Slimes cannot be transformed into a Shimmer Slime.
The Shimmer Slime is not required for the Gelatin World Tour achievement. [1]
The Lava Slime and Shimmer Slime are the only slimes that are based on and named after a liquid.
Selling the Bee Wings instead of the individual components will be more profitable. The wings sell for 8 GC, whereas the components sell for a collective 2 GC 90 SC.

Compared to its alternative ore, Silver, having Tungsten in a world may be more favorable to magic weapon users, as it allows acquiring the magic-boosting Meteor armor faster. A Tungsten Pickaxe can mine Meteorite, while a Silver Pickaxe cannot. Meteorite is required for crafting the Meteor armor.
Because Tungsten armor only grants 1 defense less than Gold armor, it is usually not worth spending time to gather Gold for the armor. Tungsten Ore is generally much more common than Gold Ore.

In reality, tungsten is extremely difficult to work due to its hardness; it has one of the highest melting points of the elements. It also is used in the filament for light bulbs due to its heat resistance. A real furnace similar to the Furnace in Terraria would likely be incapable of reaching a temperature high enough to make tungsten shapable. Furthermore, real-life tungsten is actually a white metal, not green. A real furnace similar to the Furnace in Terraria would likely be incapable of reaching a temperature high enough to make tungsten shapable. Furthermore, real-life tungsten is actually a white metal, not green.
The word tungsten derives from the Swedish and Danish words tung ("heavy") and sten ("stone").
It is almost necessary when traversing The Underworld, as knockback from enemies and damage from Hellstone and Hellstone Brick are two of the major threats the player will have to deal with.
The Obsidian Shield can synergize with the Brand of the Inferno (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) to block attacks, granting the Striking Moment buff.
The damage increase effect can also apply to critical hits.

Because the Gray Zapinator gains effects on hit, following hits can give the same beam new effects, which can lead to stacked damage and knockback modifiers, causing some beams to deal thousands of damage and/or extreme knockback.
Only the front of the beam deals damage. Enemies can walk through a beam without taking damage if they do not touch the front.
The Gray Zapinator cannot be purchased after entering Hardmode, as the Traveling Merchant will sell the Orange Zapinator instead.
The Gray Zapinator is extremely risky for use in the Underground Jungle, as its teleporting shots may break off-screen Larvae and spawn the Queen Bee even when the player is not inside a Bee Hive.
Despite its low rarity, it can be a very effective weapon throughout pre-Hardmode, given the luck required to benefit from the projectiles' behavior.
It can be ideal for the Eater of Worlds boss fight because the projectiles do not disappear after hitting an enemy, allowing them to pierce multiple segments.
There is a 5.87% chance that none of the special effects occur upon hit. The general 40% velocity and 10% damage and knockback decrease is still applied in this case.
The odds of triggering all possible effects at once are 1 in 5,647,152,000,000.
It is one of the only weapons that becomes completely unobtainable in Hardmode, the other being the Cascade.

The Gray Zapinator's name and sprite resemble the Famicom Zapper, an electronic light gun accessory for the Famicom (known as the Family Computer in Japan, and the Nintendo Entertainment System or NES in North America and internationally). The Gray Zapinator in particular appears similar to the Famicom light gun that was first released in Japan in 1984, with its gray coloration and red trigger. The erratic behavior of the projectiles along with the tooltip, 'It might be broken', are most likely references to the fact that NES Zappers were inconsistent when used in their respective light gun games on the NES. The erratic behavior of the projectiles along with the tooltip, 'It might be broken', are most likely references to the fact that NES Zappers were inconsistent when used in their respective light gun games on the NES.

The Zapinator was first introduced in the original desktop release by the developers to instantly kill enemies for testing purposes, and it was removed with the 1.0.1 version. Later on, the item was added to the Nintendo 3DS version. The Zapinator was eventually re-introduced to the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version as the Gray Zapinator and Orange Zapinator in 1.4.0.1.

The detailed spawning conditions of scorpions are as follows: [1] If there are town NPCs nearby, scorpions can spawn on regular Sand Blocks at any time. If there are no town NPCs nearby, scorpions can only spawn on regular Sand Blocks that is not submerged in liquids at daytime. They also cannot spawn in Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Ocean biomes. If there are town NPCs nearby, scorpions can spawn on regular Sand Blocks at any time. If there are no town NPCs nearby, scorpions can only spawn on regular Sand Blocks that is not submerged in liquids at daytime. They also cannot spawn in Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Ocean biomes.
Scorpion: " Harmlessly scuttles around the desert looking for food. Fish are barely attracted to these. "
Black Scorpion: " Despite its menacing appearance, it is quite docile unless threatened or facing smaller prey. Fish are occasionally attracted to these. "
With sufficient fishing preparations and some patience, the Falcon Blade can be obtained very early on. It surpasses even the Light's Bane / Blood Butcherer in damage.
The Falcon Blade is a crossover item also found in the 2015 indie side-scrolling real-time strategy video game Pixel Piracy.
It can almost be considered a pre-Hardmode Cutlass, sharing many of the same features, pros, and cons, as well as the similar designs.

The Falcon Blade has a design that resembles a falchion, a one-handed, single-edged sword of medieval European origin. In addition to this, the words falchion and falcon bear a close resemblance to each other. In addition to this, the words falchion and falcon bear a close resemblance to each other.
The Crystal Sofa is referred to as CrystalSofaHowDoesThatEvenWork in the game's internal files.
The Dynasty Sofa's sprite is the only one that does not have a backrest.

Bees from the Bee Gun, the Bee Keeper, The Bee's Knees, the Beenade, or the Honey Comb are completely unrelated to Bee enemies, as these bees are friendly projectiles. Unlike bee projectiles created by players, Bee enemies do not die or despawn when entering water. However, a Bee Hive will not spawn Bees when broken if it lands in water. Unlike bee projectiles created by players, Bee enemies do not die or despawn when entering water. However, a Bee Hive will not spawn Bees when broken if it lands in water.

In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the damage done by Bees is greatly increased in Hardmode. This can catch players off-guard, as Bees are normally easily dealt with at this stage of the game.
Bees do not drop Souls of Light, Souls of Night, Biome Keys, or Biome Key Molds.

Since Bees can spawn from Hive blocks, it is recommended that the Bee Hive is entered with caution, even though they have little defense and health. While even the lowest-tier pickaxe, the Copper Pickaxe, is capable of killing them, breaking too many Hives at once can overwhelm a player with low-tier armor.
They are one of the only enemies, along with the Servant of Cthulhu and Meteor Head, to deal more base damage than their own maximum life.
Each swing lasts 30 ticks [1], with an extra tick between swings [2]. The whipsword reaches its longest length, pointed directly at the cursor, on the 16th tick of the swing.

The whipsword carves out an ellipse with its furthest point being pointed at the cursor. The minor axis of the ellipse has a random length up to 11 blocks wide total [3], and extends out 33 blocks at its longest point.

Hitting enemies with the whipsword causes a solar explosion ranging from 2.75 tiles to 6.5 tiles in diameter, hitting nearby enemies and the main target for a bit after. A solar explosion can be created every 8 ticks [1].

Both the whipsword and the solar explosions give 4 global immunity frames, meaning the weapon can hit a target at most 15 times per second. If the whipsword inflicts a solar explosion, that explosion lasts long enough to guarantee 3 hits on that target, while getting more hits on a given target requires the whipsword contacting the target for longer. The maximum 15 hits per second is possible at point blank but not further away. If the whipsword inflicts a solar explosion, that explosion lasts long enough to guarantee 3 hits on that target, while getting more hits on a given target requires the whipsword contacting the target for longer. The maximum 15 hits per second is possible at point blank but not further away.
The Solar Eruption is not affected by melee speed bonuses.

While the whipsword can receive the following bonuses, the solar explosions cannot: Flasks. Frostbite from Frost armor. Hellfire from the Magma Stone or its upgrades. Flasks. Frostbite from Frost armor. Hellfire from the Magma Stone or its upgrades.
Killing an enemy that spawns smaller enemies, such as a Mother Slime, will not cause the Daybroken debuff to stay active on newly spawned enemies.
The whipsword will still do damage even if a solar explosion does not occur.

With infinite pierce and the ability to attack through walls, the Solar Eruption is effective against multiple targets such as against the Celestial Pillars.  Its counterpart, the Daybreak, has much better range and single-target damage in return for a lack of pierce. The random arcs and limited range of the Solar Eruption can make it difficult or dangerous to use, however, and its damage output near the edge of its range is low. Other crowd control options like the Flying Dragon or Terra Blade may be preferred due to their range, and the Daybreak is a much stronger weapon against the Moon Lord fight after the pillars. The random arcs and limited range of the Solar Eruption can make it difficult or dangerous to use, however, and its damage output near the edge of its range is low. Other crowd control options like the Flying Dragon or Terra Blade may be preferred due to their range, and the Daybreak is a much stronger weapon against the Moon Lord fight after the pillars.
Due to the long reach and small sweep of the Solar Eruption, it is great at destroying plants.
The Solar Eruption is very useful for lighting up areas through blocks.

Due to the explosion ensuring a minimum of 3 hits, the Solar Eruption can be a good cheap option for killing Moon Leech Clots during the Moon Lord fight, but this can also be done with other weapons that are also good against Moon Lord itself.
A "solar eruption" is another name for a solar flare.

The Solar Eruption's behavior was likely inspired by solar prominences. They are large arcing and looping projections of plasma created by the sun's magnetic field, which frequently release from the surface of the sun into space for several thousands of kilometers.

The Solar Eruption's projectile is internally named SolarWhipSword [4], implying that this weapon may have been meant as the sword-type item for the set of equipment crafted from Lunar Fragments. It appears to be based on a whipsword, a fictional weapon that is a combination of a whip and a sword. It appears to be based on a whipsword, a fictional weapon that is a combination of a whip and a sword.

The Daybroken debuff that the Solar Eruption and the Daybreak inflict does not have its own debuff icon as it currently cannot be inflicted on players. It uses the Stardust Dragon buff icon as an internal placeholder.
The shaft of the whipsword has a total of 18 pairs of spikes.
The tip of the whipsword looks identical to that of the spear wielded by the Drakanian and Drakomire Rider.

The best way to fish for Prismites is to fish in a forest Hallow in the surface or sky. This gets rid of the chance to fish up any other item, like underground or biome-specific fish and loot. Although, fishing in this way prevents you from fishing for a combination of important potion fish.

It is advisable to use Prismites solely for crafting Lifeforce Potions, because of their immense value to players. Seafood Dinners can also be crafted with other common catches like Princess Fish, which are even caught from the same fishing pool.

As with other Hallow-exclusive content, Prismites can be acquired prior to entering Hardmode if an artificial Hallow is created, e.g. by bringing in Hallowed Seeds from a Hardmode world, or if playing in a Celebrationmk10 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) world.
3DS Prismites have no use apart from being sold ( 1 GC each), as neither Seafood Dinner nor Shiverthorn is present.
Like all creatures than can pass through blocks, the Fungi Bulb is immune to lava.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Destroying the block a Fungi Bulb is attached to will kill it instantly without dropping any loot.
The Bestiary entry for the Fungi Bulb: " When the glowing fungus is ready to spread, these bulbs will sprout to spread its spores to other locations and hosts. "
As the Molten Quiver does not boost the damage of ammunition, its actual damage increase is less than 10%.
The 10% arrow damage boost of the Molten Quiver can stack with the Magic Quiver and the Stalker's Quiver ; however, arrow velocity and ammo conservation chance do not stack.

Extra arrow velocity works by setting the arrow's extraUpdates value to 1. This does not affect Jester's Arrows, Ichor Arrows, Venom Arrows, or Stakes, as they already have an extraUpdates value of 1 (or greater).

The conversion from Wooden Arrows (5 base damage) to Flaming Arrows (7 base damage) results in a base damage bonus of +2. The +2 damage bonus is not applied when using the Eventide, The Bee's Knees, or the Hellwing Bow, which convert Wooden Arrows into special projectiles on their own. This is because their conversion takes place first, and the projectile is no longer considered a Wooden Arrow afterward and hence will not be recognized by the Molten Quiver. [1] However, the +2 damage bonus is applied when using any of the other bows which convert any type of arrow into special projectiles (e.g. Aerial Bane, Phantom Phoenix, etc.), as long as Wooden Arrows are used as ammunition. [2] The +2 damage bonus is not applied when using the Eventide, The Bee's Knees, or the Hellwing Bow, which convert Wooden Arrows into special projectiles on their own. This is because their conversion takes place first, and the projectile is no longer considered a Wooden Arrow afterward and hence will not be recognized by the Molten Quiver. [1] However, the +2 damage bonus is applied when using any of the other bows which convert any type of arrow into special projectiles (e.g. Aerial Bane, Phantom Phoenix, etc.), as long as Wooden Arrows are used as ammunition. [2]

The only advantage this item has over the Magic Quiver is rather dubious, as by Hardmode most players have better alternatives to Wooden Arrows. It can still be useful when paired with the Endless Quiver, although the ammo conservation bonus is wasted on the latter. It can still be useful when paired with the Endless Quiver, although the ammo conservation bonus is wasted on the latter.
Crafting the Molten Quiver requires the Magma Stone which is a melee-specific accessory, while the Molten Quiver is a ranged-specific accessory.
The tooltip "'Quiver in fear!'" is a pun using the term "quiver" as a verb, meaning to shake or vibrate rapidly.
Both Crimson Hearts and Shadow Orbs drop a gun, magic weapon, melee weapon, light pet, and an accessory.

Crimson Hearts and Shadow Orbs share the same counter for how many have been destroyed in a world, meaning that if both appear in the same world, such as in drunk worlds (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), destroying three total of either will summon the boss associated with the last one broken.

Unlike all other worm enemies, whose segments are rigidly attached together, Milkyway Weavers' segments are connected loosely and will space out further the faster the enemy is moving. Because of this, if it is moving very fast, a Milkyway Weaver can span a large portion of the screen.
Most of the soil that the player will get will be from digging into the ground. Digging long tunnels will greatly increase the character's supply of soils.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) All soils can be stacked up to 999, which makes them some of the easiest items to store.
The only block types that can be converted by Corruption, Crimson, and Hallow are among soils.
All Music Boxes are obtainable only in Hardmode, and none are visible on the character.

Like the Dark Harvest, the Firecracker forgoes summon tag damage for a special on-hit effect. Its effect is very different, as it scales with the minion's base damage and its own attack speed rather than the attack speed of the minion. This makes it more potent than the Cool Whip when actively attacking, but unlike the Spinal Tap or Snapthorn, it does not provide lingering damage bonuses.

This whip can achieve very high DPS with most minions. However, due to its relatively low range and summoners' generally poor defense, it will require more skill in dodging attacks to use it as a main weapon.
Due to its unique tag multiplier effect, the whip can remain viable even after the Moon Lord has been defeated.
It pairs well with other whips that temporarily increase melee speed on hit, such as the Dark Harvest and Durendal, as higher attack speed means it can re-apply its tag more often.
This weapon produces light when swung, making it helpful for revealing caves and ores through walls.

Because the Firecracker's effect multiplies damage dealt instead of giving an additive tag damage increase, it works best with minions that have high base damage. It is particularly effective when paired with the Desert Tiger Staff, Abigail's Flower, or the Stardust Dragon Staff, due to their unique ability to increase minion damage based on the number of slots invested in them. On the contrary, minions that hit rapidly with low base damage such as Enchanted Daggers and UFOs pair poorly with this whip. On the contrary, minions that hit rapidly with low base damage such as Enchanted Daggers and UFOs pair poorly with this whip.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, using a Dye Vat to craft two Red Dyes is more profitable than just selling the Red Husk on its own because both dyes sell for 20 silver each.

The following ammo items do not automatically get placed into the ammo slots. If the player is running low on inventory space and still has ammo slots open, these items can be placed there to conserve space.

Completing the Old One's Army event on any difficulty sets a hidden attribute for both the world it was completed on and the character who completed it. Any characters, including newly made ones, who visit that world may then use Rods, Canes, and Staves on that world. The character who completed the event may also use Rods, Canes, and Staves on any world.

While Lightning Auras can be placed next to other Tavernkeep's sentries, it is not possible to place another Tavernkeep's sentry inside the radius of an existing Lightning Aura. Therefore, Lightning Auras should be placed last when clustering various sentries together.

The Lightning Aura's maximum radius is 9 tiles, with the top "orb" being in the 10th tile up from the base. If summoned in a space shorter than 10 tiles (blocked by either blocks or platforms), the Lightning Aura shrinks, down to a minimum radius of three tiles, with the orb inhabiting the fourth tile above. [3] If the player is wearing the Shinobi Infiltrator armor, the radii are increased by 4 tiles, to a maximum of 13 and a minimum of 7. [3] If the player is wearing the Shinobi Infiltrator armor, the radii are increased by 4 tiles, to a maximum of 13 and a minimum of 7. [3]

The Lightning Aura requires a line of sight from the orb to any enemy inside its radius in order to damage them. Summoning a Lightning Aura in a space shorter than 10 tiles places the orb inside a block, rendering most of its attack range moot; though it will still damage enemies directly beneath it. While platforms will decrease the range of a Lightning Aura, they will not block line of sight, allowing the aura to function normally.

Dungeon Guardians and any other enemy that happens to have over 999 defense are excluded from the Lightning Aura's defense compensation ability, and will cause the Aura's damage to be reduced as normal. [1]
The Lightning Aura has a cooldown of 0.5 seconds after attacking. If the player is wearing the Monk armor or Shinobi Infiltrator armor, this cooldown is reduced to 0.42 seconds. [3]
Since some hostile projectiles are technically enemies with 1 health (e.g. the Chaos Ball ), the Lightning Aura can destroy them if they happens to fly into its radius.
The Lightning Aura's area of effect and frequent attacks are effective against segmented enemies like worms.

A Lightning Aura sentry placed close to one of the Mysterious Portals in the Old One's Army event will kill or severely weaken most of the tier 1 enemies before they can get anywhere close to the Eternia Crystal, making tier 1 much easier.

A Lightning Aura sentry emits light, therefore it can be useful when exploring caves to locate undiscovered sections. Attempting to place it in a solid area will not consume mana, so it can be freely used to probe "blank" areas for possible caverns. Binoculars or similar items can be helpful to extend the area mapped by the light.

Lightning Auras can be displaced. This behavior can lead to some interesting movement of the sentry when placed in narrow sloped tunnels, like those of the Underground Desert, and it can end up some distance away from its intended placement, inside walls, or even completely off-screen.
The Lightning Aura Rod has the lowest base damage of all summon weapons. Prior to its introduction, the Slime Staff had the lowest base damage.

The seed being randomized can technically lead the game to create a drunk world or a Celebrationmk10 world without specifying the seed, but the chances of it happening are astronomically low ( 1/2,147,483,648 (0.000000047%) for the drunk world, 1/1,073,741,824 (0.000000093%) for the Celebrationmk10 seed). This is due to the random seed being a random number between 0 and 2147483647; the random seed can match the one needed for one of these secret seeds. The chances are doubled for the Celebrationmk10 seed due to the fact that two seed numbers trigger the secret seed. This is due to the random seed being a random number between 0 and 2147483647; the random seed can match the one needed for one of these secret seeds. The chances are doubled for the Celebrationmk10 seed due to the fact that two seed numbers trigger the secret seed.
The smiley-faced moon seen during the generation of a drunk world is a reference to an astronomy hoax that was said to happen the same day Journey's End was released on PC. [8] [9]

Unlike the other secret seeds, the drunk world and Celebrationmk10 seeds are interpreted as numbers, so any number of 0s can be added in the front (e.g. 000005162020 for the drunk world). In addition, there are numerous unintended strings that generate these two secret seeds (due to the use of the CRC-32 algorithm [10] ), such as: Drunk world (case-sensitive): now aunt brush Joke Disappear Horizon disapprove stiff solution Celebrationmk10 (case-sensitive): Thirst of dress engineer governor reproduction inform Representative yorai Drunk world (case-sensitive): now aunt brush Joke Disappear Horizon disapprove stiff solution now aunt brush Joke Disappear Horizon disapprove stiff solution Celebrationmk10 (case-sensitive): Thirst of dress engineer governor reproduction inform Representative yorai Thirst of dress engineer governor reproduction inform Representative yorai

If a modified world were to have 2 or more active secret seeds at the same time, the icon for it would follow this priority: Get fixed boi > Drunk world > For the worthy > Not the bees > Celebrationmk10 > The Constant > Don't dig up > No traps.

Obtaining Worm Tooth in Crimson worlds can be difficult, as Devourers do not spawn naturally in these worlds. They can be obtained with additional steps, however. The easiest way is to craft Unholy Arrows with Vertebra, and then throwing the arrows into Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The arrows will decraft into Worm Tooth and Wooden Arrows. Another way is to talk to the Dryad in Hardmode when in a Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). This allows her to sell Corrupt Seeds, which can be used to create an artificial Corruption biome, and therefore allow Devourers to spawn. The easiest way is to craft Unholy Arrows with Vertebra, and then throwing the arrows into Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The arrows will decraft into Worm Tooth and Wooden Arrows. Another way is to talk to the Dryad in Hardmode when in a Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). This allows her to sell Corrupt Seeds, which can be used to create an artificial Corruption biome, and therefore allow Devourers to spawn.
Placing torches next to the fog machine colors the fog.
The fog it produces can be used to hide parts of builds such as wiring. It also makes great clouds and other ambience.
Fog produced by the Fog Machine is less thick in a Graveyard.
Cloud Walls painted white become 100% white ( hex triplet #FFFFFF) during sunny middays. This can be used to create ideal backgrounds when taking screenshots.
Solar Fragment Blocks emit a faint glow when placed.
This bow has identical stats to the Boreal Wood Bow and the Rich Mahogany Bow.

Since it is almost assured that the player will have to go through the Crimson / Corruption to get to the Ocean biome where Palm Wood is found, it is recommended to make an Ebonwood or Shadewood Bow, as they are stronger. Nonetheless, the Palm Wood Bow can still see use if Palm Wood is found near an Oasis, as the evil biomes are dangerous to early characters. The Boreal Wood Bow can be seen as an easier to get alternative, as the Snow biome is large and easier to find compared to Oases. Nonetheless, the Palm Wood Bow can still see use if Palm Wood is found near an Oasis, as the evil biomes are dangerous to early characters. The Boreal Wood Bow can be seen as an easier to get alternative, as the Snow biome is large and easier to find compared to Oases.
Stats-wise, Palm Wood armor and Boreal Wood armor are exact copies of this armor.
The Dye Trader NPC states that it is the only wood type worth dyeing, although this has no effect whatsoever as it is purely trivial.

The Sugar Cookie's tooltip implies that its excessive sugar content may give the player lots of energy, similar to the Sugar Rush buff. However, eating the Sugar Cookie only grants the Exquisitely Stuffed buff.

Although the Cobalt Waraxe and Cobalt Chainsaw have equal axe powers, the waraxe is faster than the chainsaw at chopping down trees (assuming no buffs or modifiers are at play). It also dishes out more damage and knockback, making this the obvious best choice for players that are new into Hardmode since it can be utilized effectively as both a tool and a weapon. However, once the player obtains and equips accessories such as the Celestial Stone and Celestial Shell, the Cobalt Chainsaw becomes faster than the Cobalt Waraxe at chopping down trees, but still remains far behind in the damage category.
It is one of the earliest available axe tools upon entering Hardmode, along with its slightly stronger alternative, the Palladium Waraxe.
The Crystal and Lesion Sinks are the only ones to face to the left.
The Lihzahrd Sink is the only sink to face both ways.
The Sandstone Sink is the only sink without any visible pipes or faucets.
The Spider Sink is named SpiderSinkSpiderSinkDoesWhateverASpiderSinkDoes in the source code, [1] in reference to "Spider-Pig," the The Simpsons Movie spoof of the 1960s Spider-Man theme song.

The Bamboo Sink might be based on the sōzu (添水), a type of water fountain made of bamboo that is often installed in Japanese gardens. It was originally used to scare away animals that might eat the garden plants, but now is mostly used to add visual and aural ambience. Alternatively, it might be based on the tsukubai (蹲踞), which is a washbasin with a bamboo pipe found at the entrances to holy places in Japan. These are used by visitors to purify themselves before entering said places, by doing a ritual consisting of hand washing and rinsing of the mouth. It may also be based on a tropical rain filter. Alternatively, it might be based on the tsukubai (蹲踞), which is a washbasin with a bamboo pipe found at the entrances to holy places in Japan. These are used by visitors to purify themselves before entering said places, by doing a ritual consisting of hand washing and rinsing of the mouth. It may also be based on a tropical rain filter.

Wooden Crates are able to drop rare items from Surface Chests, making those items renewable. However, none of the early-game weapons, such as the Blowpipe or the Wooden Boomerang, can be obtained from Wooden Crates.

The enemies that drop Pizza (Hoplites and Medusas) are Ancient Greece -themed. Although it is commonly held that real-life pizza originated in Italy, its history ranges back to antiquity. In Ancient Greece, citizens made a flatbread called " plakous ", which was flavored with toppings like herbs, onion, cheese, and garlic.
The tooltip, ' With pepperoni and extra cheese.', refers to ordering real-life pizza, however, the sprite also resembles a pepperoni pizza with cheese drooping on the edge of the slice.

The exact tile that the player is transferred to is the one furthest from them horizontally, then the highest, that is not obstructed by liquid. When a world first generates, this will typically be on the sand, directly in front of the water. If the player is on the eastern side of the world relative to the spawn point, then they will be teleported to the western Ocean, and vice versa. If the player is on the eastern side of the world relative to the spawn point, then they will be teleported to the western Ocean, and vice versa.

There must be blocks extending down to the Ocean surface level underneath a tile for the conch to teleport the player to it. The blocks can have gaps less than the height of the player between each other and above the Ocean. This allows the Magic Conch to potentially teleport a player to 6 different locations per map, utilizing mounts to change their height. If both Oceans are fully obstructed from spawning (e.g. flooding), the teleport will fail, and the player will be teleported to their current location.

A failed Magic Conch teleport will reset the player's momentum, and reset any extra jumps from accessories. Furthermore, holding ↷ Jump until the teleport fails will only reset the flight time provided by Rocket Boots and its upgrades, while releasing ↷ Jump before the teleport will reset the flight time provided by both Rocket Boots and wings, making it possible to gain "infinite" flight.
The particular tile the player will be teleported to is determined right before the actual teleportation takes place, not when activating the item.

The particles that are seen upon use are water particles. These particles will change color depending on the biome that the player is in. The effect of Water fountains and Blood Moons also changes the particle colors, taking priority over the biome's natural color.

The Magic Conch can be used to find the Angler quickly to start fishing quests, if both Oceans have not been yet explored. However, because the item is found in the Underground Desert, a dangerous biome for unprepared players, or found in Oasis or Mirage Crates, which are rare fishing drops, it might be faster just to travel on foot to the Oceans. However, because the item is found in the Underground Desert, a dangerous biome for unprepared players, or found in Oasis or Mirage Crates, which are rare fishing drops, it might be faster just to travel on foot to the Oceans.
Since only one Ocean Pylon can be used in a world while each world has two Oceans, the Magic Conch can also be useful for accessing the Ocean that does not have a Pylon.
The Magic Conch is especially useful during the Lunar Events, as two Celestial Pillars often spawn closer to the edges of the world.

The Magic Conch makes setting up a Pylon network a lot easier. When setting up a town in the Ocean biome, the Magic Conch allows the player to go from their spawn point to the Ocean they are setting up much quicker and return back to spawn in order to get supplies, as opposed to having to travel across a large portion of the world.

The Magic Conch makes traveling to the Dungeon much quicker as well. Since the Dungeon is always closer to the Ocean, the player can access it much more easily. This is especially useful when exploring the post- Plantera Dungeon, as it is likely the player will be dying a lot there.

The Magic Conch will send the user to the other Ocean biome if they are already in one. This allows easy access to either side of the world, as the player simply has to use the Magic Conch a second time.
The Magic Conch can save time when attempting to start the Martian Madness event, as it enables teleporting straight to either side of the map where the Martian Probe can spawn.

The Magic Conch's tooltip, " If you listen closely, you can hear the ocean " is a reference to how holding a shell to one's ear can sound like ocean waves. In reality, the cavity of the shell causes surrounding noises to resonate, which can sound like ocean waves.
It has one of the slowest use times in the game, tied with the Demon Conch, Magic Mirrors, Cell Phone, Shellphone, and Snake Charmer's Flute.

The name of the Magic Conch is likely based on the Magic Conch Shell featured in "Club Spongebob", the second episode of the third season of the animated television series Spongebob Squarepants, which became a popular meme online.
Using this dye in combination with the King Slime Mask and a blank vanity (like the Martian Costume set ) allows the player to resemble a slime.
The effect of this dye appears very similar to the Blue Acid Dye 's effect, as they are both blue and have wavy visuals.

While wielding the Leaf Blower, a green tank which appears to contain a small tree will appear on the player's back. The Heat Ray, Elf Melter, Clentaminator, and Terraformer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) also have this feature. If the player has a pair of wings equipped, the wings will not be visible unless in use. If the player has a pair of wings equipped, the wings will not be visible unless in use.
(3DS version) Due to the damage and velocity increase of the Zapinator, it is largely considered favorable over the Leaf Blower. However, it is a rarer drop from Plantera.
It can be considered a predecessor to the Razorpine.
In real life, a leaf blower is a device that fires air out of a nozzle to move plant-based debris, including leaves and grass cuttings.
On some mounts, the Leaf Blower does not appear properly on the back. It will instead appear a few pixels too high as if it was stuck to the player's head.

Bars can be placed like furniture, take up a space of one tile, and can be stacked on top of each other. When placed, they can be used just like platforms, to stand on and drop down from, and furniture can be placed on the top.

Bars cannot be placed without another block underneath them; this makes it impossible to build a house made of bars without the aid of other blocks. This mechanic makes breaking bars similar to cutting down trees, where breaking the bottom bar in a stack will break all bars above it. The only way to make placed bars "float" would be to abuse the fact that Chests with items inside cannot be destroyed. Using bars as support under such a chest would mean they cannot be destroyed until the chest is emptied. This allows them to float in-air without any supporting blocks. The only way to make placed bars "float" would be to abuse the fact that Chests with items inside cannot be destroyed. Using bars as support under such a chest would mean they cannot be destroyed until the chest is emptied. This allows them to float in-air without any supporting blocks.
Hallowed Bars are the only bars to not require an ore to be made.
Although a single bar is consumed when it is placed, the tile sprite appears to be 3 or possible 4 bars stacked on top of each other.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The textures of the pre-Hardmode bars, such as Copper Bars, are slightly different to textures of the Hardmode bars in shape (observe the bottom-right corner). The only exception to this is the Chlorophyte Bar, which is the same shape as a pre-Hardmode bars.
The old bar textures are modified versions of the old Minecraft ingot textures, as seen when comparing e.g. the old Minecraft iron ingot and the old Terraria Iron Bar.
Waterleaves grow slightly faster when raining. [2]
The Waterleaf takes the longest to bloom out of all the herbs.
It bears no resemblance whatsoever to the real-life leaf vegetable Talinum fruticosum, which is also often called waterleaf.

Contrary to what its inventory sprite suggests, the Chlorophyte Partisan is actually quite long. Because it additionally has a spore cloud that follows its thrust, the Partisan has a massive range, possibly the second largest (after the North Pole ) range of spear-type weapons.
The spore cloud has the same damage range as the spear itself, and is able to deal critical hits.
When using the Magma Stone or Fire Gauntlet, the spores do not have the flame particles, but can inflict the Hellfire debuff.

It can be used to damage enemies through blocks via the spore cloud it emits, but not by the actual spear. Because of this, the user must be at a specific distance in order for the spore cloud to make contact. The cloud will not make contact if the enemy is too close, since it is only released at the tip of the spear during the apex of the thrust.
Because of the damage and knockback, it is a useful weapon against groups of enemies. It can knock back several enemies at once, this also makes it useful for defense.
Its spores have the same appearance as the Chlorophyte Saber 's.
(Console and Mobile versions) All existing Tonbogiris in 1.3.0.1 -equivalent worlds were replaced by Chlorophyte Partisans upon updating.
Creepers drop Hearts at a higher rate than most enemies, at a 1/2 (50%) chance.
Creepers do not drop Souls of Night, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Biome Keys, or (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Biome Key Molds.

If the player leaves the Crimson, the Brain of Cthulhu will move downwards and despawn. However, if the player returns to the Crimson before the Brain of Cthulhu despawns, the battle will continue as normal. However, if the player returns to the Crimson before the Brain of Cthulhu despawns, the battle will continue as normal.
Two Brains can be summoned at once by smashing Crimson Hearts. They seem to share their Creepers and go into their second phases simultaneously.

Note that actually defeating the Brain of Cthulhu is not completely necessary to progress, as the Creepers may drop the needed amount of materials. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) However, defeating the Brain of Cthulhu is the only way to gain access to the Tavernkeep and Meteorites. In Expert Mode, defeating the actual Brain is the only way to get access to the Brain of Confusion, a powerful accessory that can benefit the player well late into the game. This trait of being able to gain the progression-based items of a boss simply by damaging it instead of defeating it is shared with its Corruption counterpart, Eater of Worlds. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) However, defeating the Brain of Cthulhu is the only way to gain access to the Tavernkeep and Meteorites. In Expert Mode, defeating the actual Brain is the only way to get access to the Brain of Confusion, a powerful accessory that can benefit the player well late into the game. This trait of being able to gain the progression-based items of a boss simply by damaging it instead of defeating it is shared with its Corruption counterpart, Eater of Worlds.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Crafting the Deathbringer Pickaxe (from Tissue Samples and Crimtane Ore ) will not be necessary if the player obtains the Reaver Shark (through fishing ).
Since Hellstone can be destroyed with explosives in Hardmode, and Hardmode ores can be obtained from fishing, defeating the Brain of Cthulhu is not necessary to obtain those items.

In For the worthy and Get fixed boi secret worlds, the Brain of Cthulhu receives the following changes: Has +20% damage (applied before any Expert/Master difficulty bonuses) Has +21 defense for a total of 35 defense, making the second phase extremely difficult when using most pre-BoC weapons (damage of those weapons is typically lower than 25). Spawns with 40 Creepers, twice as many as normal. When Creepers are charging at the player, their acceleration is about 8/3 times compared to Expert Mode. Creeper charging frequency is √(8/3)~1.6 times compared to Expert Mode. The Brain of Cthulhu itself moves 3 times as fast in its first phase. The Brain of Cthulhu has fully opaque illusions for the entirety of its second phase after taking its first damage, regardless of difficulty. Gravity is reversed once the Brain of Cthulhu enters its second phase, and cannot be reversed by gravity-reversing items (e.g. Gravitation Potions or the Gravity Globe ). Has +20% damage (applied before any Expert/Master difficulty bonuses) Has +21 defense for a total of 35 defense, making the second phase extremely difficult when using most pre-BoC weapons (damage of those weapons is typically lower than 25). Spawns with 40 Creepers, twice as many as normal. When Creepers are charging at the player, their acceleration is about 8/3 times compared to Expert Mode. Creeper charging frequency is √(8/3)~1.6 times compared to Expert Mode. The Brain of Cthulhu itself moves 3 times as fast in its first phase. The Brain of Cthulhu has fully opaque illusions for the entirety of its second phase after taking its first damage, regardless of difficulty. Gravity is reversed once the Brain of Cthulhu enters its second phase, and cannot be reversed by gravity-reversing items (e.g. Gravitation Potions or the Gravity Globe ).
Creepers have low individual health and are especially susceptible to the On Fire! and Frostburn debuffs. Weapons that inflict these debuffs can make quick work of them.
Grenades and other splash damage weapons can kill the Creepers very quickly, as they will bunch up often.

Since the Brain of Cthulhu is susceptible to knockback, weapons with high knockback such as the The Rotted Fork can keep both Creepers and the Brain from closing distance between teleports. It is also possible to use early-game melee weapons such as the Katana or the Zombie Arm as long as they do not have disadvantageous modifiers. It is preferable to use spears for this fight since they deal more knockback, however, so the Trident or The Rotted Fork is recommended. Note that this may not work in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), since it might be hard to tell which Brain to attack among the illusions. Note that this may not work in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), since it might be hard to tell which Brain to attack among the illusions.

Jester's Arrows or other piercing weapons can be immensely helpful while fighting the first stage, since Creepers often group up in a clustered formation, effectively allowing the player to hit most if not all of the Creepers in one well-aimed shot.
The Minishark is extremely effective in keeping the Brain of Cthulhu away from the player during the second stage.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) There are several methods to reveal the real Brain of Cthulhu in the second stage: The real Brain is the only one with a health bar. Bone Javelins only stick out of the real Brain. Minions and sentries will target the real Brain. The On Fire!, Frostburn, and Poisoned debuffs only damage the real Brain, as well as apply visual effects. The Slime Gun and Water Gun only apply visual effects onto the real Brain, though they cannot inflict damage. The Slime Mount only bounces off the real Brain. The illusions position themselves in relation to the player. The illusions will quickly spread away from the real Brain if the player is walking away from it, but the real Brain will continue to move at a steady pace. When using a controller, the lock on feature will only target the real Brain. The real Brain is the only one with a health bar. Bone Javelins only stick out of the real Brain. Minions and sentries will target the real Brain. The On Fire!, Frostburn, and Poisoned debuffs only damage the real Brain, as well as apply visual effects. The Slime Gun and Water Gun only apply visual effects onto the real Brain, though they cannot inflict damage. The Slime Mount only bounces off the real Brain. The illusions position themselves in relation to the player. The illusions will quickly spread away from the real Brain if the player is walking away from it, but the real Brain will continue to move at a steady pace. When using a controller, the lock on feature will only target the real Brain.

Selling all the Crimtane Ore that can be obtained from the fight, or better yet, converting the ore into Crimtane Bars and selling them that way is a very effective method to make money in pre-Hardmode.
The Brain of Cthulhu, among several other bosses, is based on Cthulhu, a creature first imagined by American writer H. P. Lovecraft in his 1926 short story " The Call of Cthulhu ".

Unlike the correlation between the Eater of Worlds and The Destroyer, the Brain of Cthulhu does not have a Hardmode counterpart, although The Destroyer's Probes are similar in function to its Creepers. – According to the Terraria lore pages, the Mechanic never finished Cthulhu's mechanical brain, thus explaining its lack of a mechanical counterpart. On a technical level, the reason the Brain has no mechanical version is that the mechanical bosses were introduced in Desktop 1.1, whereas the BoC was introduced in Desktop 1.2. – According to the Terraria lore pages, the Mechanic never finished Cthulhu's mechanical brain, thus explaining its lack of a mechanical counterpart. On a technical level, the reason the Brain has no mechanical version is that the mechanical bosses were introduced in Desktop 1.1, whereas the BoC was introduced in Desktop 1.2.

Assuming that the player is 5′ 9″ (1.75 m) in terms of height, the Brain of Cthulhu would be about 13′ 2″  (4.01 m) tall and 19′ 1½″ (5.83 m) wide. The Creepers would be about 3′ 7″ (1.09 m) tall and wide.

The Brain of Cthulhu has the least health out of all the bosses, with even less than the Eye of Cthulhu in its second form. However, when adding in the health of the Creepers, it has more health than King Slime.
The Brain of Cthulhu is the only boss that is affected by knockback.
It is one of the only three bosses whose map icon does not change after entering its second phase, the others being Santa-NK1 and Queen Slime.
The Brain of Cthulhu is sometimes abbreviated as "BoC".

The list of debuffs inflicted by the Brain and Creepers in Expert Mode just so happens to be exactly the same as the list of debuff immunities granted by the Ankh Charm. The Ankh Shield also gives these immunities, with the addition of Burning and Chilled. Of course, it is fairly trivial to defeat the Brain of Cthulhu at the point in the game that the Ankh Charm can be obtained.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, a cloud in the shape of the Brain of Cthulhu can occasionally be seen in the background.
The Sharkron's Tsunami jump is the second lowest double-jump available, beating only the Cloud jump.
The Sharkron Balloon still reduces jump height in water, despite both of its components being aquatic-themed.
The Sharkron Balloon sells for less than the added prices of its components.
If it is dyed with a compound dye, the bigger part will be the first color, the smaller one the second.
It represents a fishing-based alternative to the crafting paths involving the Shiny Red Balloon.
The Sharkron Balloon's double-jump can be used to avoid fall damage with good timing.
The Sharkron Balloon is especially effective when combined with wings, because the Tsunami jump will jump-start the wings and the Pufferfish will let the player fly higher.

When using the Housing Menu query to check houses with Stinkbug Blockers inside, special status messages will be displayed: Stinkbug Blocker: " This room is infested by a stinkbug! " Ghostly Stinkbug Blocker: " This room is infested by a ghostly stinkbug! " Stinkbug Blocker: " This room is infested by a stinkbug! " Ghostly Stinkbug Blocker: " This room is infested by a ghostly stinkbug! "
Town pets are unaffected by both blockers allowing them to be in rooms other NPCs can not.
Jungle Crates contain valuable loot that can greatly aid the player in pre-Hardmode without the need to defeat any event, boss, or venture far into any deadly biomes.

As the Jungle has many surface ponds, some can be very deep, and it can be very easy to set up a viable outpost for fishing. Ideally, the base should sit right atop the water, or over the entire pond altogether, to prevent flying enemies from getting in.
The Jungle Crate resembles the ancient wooden cage ambient object. However, the object is unrelated and has no function other than being broken.
Selling the Tattered Fairy Wings instead of the individual components will be more profitable. The wings sell for 8 GC, whereas the components sell for a collective 2 GC 90 SC.
Internally, the autoReuse attribute determines whether an item has autoswing ability.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Autoswing can be enabled for all weapons in the Settings menu by enabling the "Autofire" option. Autoswing can also be enabled on melee weapons and whips by certain accessories: Feral Claws, Power Glove, Mechanical Glove, Fire Gauntlet, and Berserker's Glove (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Note that none of these actually change the autoReuse attribute of an item. Note that none of these actually change the autoReuse attribute of an item.
All weapons with the exception of a selected few have autoswing enabled.

Autoswing is a very useful attribute that should be considered when comparing weapons as it allows maximizing the number of hits. For example, all other statistics aside, an autoswing weapon that deals 30 base damage can be preferred over a non-autoswing weapon that deals 34 base damage. Note that as of 1.4.4 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) all weapons have the capability to autoswing by enabling the "Autofire" option.
Items without autoswing can still be swung automatically via third-party software like auto clickers.
Despite being made with two possible components of the Lava Waders, the Obsidian Skull Rose cannot be directly crafted into the Lava Waders.
The Orichalcum Halberd appears to be a pike rather than a halberd, while the Palladium Pike appears to be a halberd rather than a pike.
The Orichalcum and Mythril Halberds share the name halberd, unlike the four other Hardmode ore spears, which have unique names ( naginata / pike and glaive / trident ).

The item's tooltip, 'Come to the dark side, we have smoothies', is a reference to the " Come To The Dark Side " meme (often followed by "we have cookies"), which originated from the American epic space opera franchise Star Wars.

Obtaining this weapon requires the player to visit both a Corrupted / Crimson Desert and a Hallowed Desert in order to obtain both shards, and the Underground Crimson / Corruption and Underground Hallow to get both soul variations.
The Dao of Pow is available early into Hardmode, and is available without defeating any Hardmode bosses, making it a suitable upgrade from late pre-Hardmode weapons.
While the Confused debuff can help keep certain enemies at bay, particularly groups of fighters, many other enemies are immune to this debuff.
Like all flails, holding the ⚒ Use / Attack button will cause the head to remain deployed, dealing full damage to enemies that make contact with it.
The chance to inflict the Confused debuff is calculated once for each attack, meaning that either every enemy hit during one attack sequence will get it or every enemy will not get it.
All thrown flails are very effective against worm-type enemies. The Dao of Pow, having a good reach and velocity, is notably effective against Wyverns, and a good method of obtaining Souls of Flight.
The Dao of Pow pairs well with flasks and other sources of lingering damage, which will wear enemies down as they wander around while Confused.

This is one of a small "set" of weapons made with two shards apiece, the other members being the Onyx Blaster (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and the Sky Fracture (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Their recipes, names and appearances link the weapons to themes of Darkness, Light, and Balance, with the Dao of Pow representing Balance. The set also includes one weapon for each of the three "classic" damage types (melee, magic, and ranged), where the Dao of Pow is the melee weapon.

The Dao of Pow is colored black and white in a taijitu or "yin-yang" -style design commonly associated with Daoism. The Chinese word 道 means way or path, and can also mean philosophy. The word is often romanized to either tao or dao.
The tooltip, 'Find your inner pieces', is a play on the phrase Find your inner peace, referring to the inherent objective that Taoists should strive towards.
The Dao of Pow is one of the three craftable flails in the game, the other two being the Flaming Mace (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Meatball.
Po' boys are traditional sandwiches originating from Louisiana, which almost always consist of either meat, such as roast beef, or fried seafood, such as fish, shrimp, crawfish, oysters, or crab.
Despite the name, Shrimp cannot be used to make Shrimp Po' Boys.
Its tooltip is a play on words on the phrase " oh boy ".

The Lunatic Cultist plans on restoring Cthulhu and has forced the Mechanic to forge mechanical organs of Cthulhu. However, since she has never completed the mechanical brain, the restored Cthulhu cannot function, and thus, unless the aforementioned implication that he became the Moon Lord is true, he never appeared again.

In the concept art, he is missing one of his eyes, presumably because the missing eye became the Eye of Cthulhu boss. One of the title messages on the Desktop version refers to this: " Terraria: Cthulhu is mad... and is missing an eye! " One of the title messages on the Desktop version refers to this: " Terraria: Cthulhu is mad... and is missing an eye! "
The pet is similar to Flying Fish but with different colors.
Zephyr is a Greek word meaning (the gentle) west wind. Zephyr has been used in various media, and in the naming of numerous land, air, and sea vessels.
Flying Snakes and Lihzahrds will begin to spawn if the player stands in front of natural Lihzahrd Brick Wall at the entrance to the Temple, even if Hardmode has not been activated yet.
The Flying Snake may be based on Quetzalcoatl, a deity in Aztec, Mayan, and Olmec Mythology, or real-life flying snakes, which live in Southeast Asia.

Flying Snakes are technically the enemy with the most base damage that a player can encounter during pre-Hardmode, as they can spawn at the entrance of the Lihzahrd Temple before Hardmode has been activated.
Flying Snakes appear to have the same wings that Slimers have, looking similar to the Demon Wings.

The first sword generated on each swing will always be a Zenith projectile, which generates a mint-green trail. Each sword generated will have a unique swing color, which generates a large amount of light.
The Zenith can only go up to 600 pixels (37.5 tiles) vertically and 960 pixels (60 tiles) horizontally.

Increasing melee speed affects the number of swords that appear per use, but not the number of swords thrown per second or the swords' velocity. At default melee speed, 3 swords will appear per use. Higher melee speed will cause fewer swords besides the Zenith to appear. With high enough attack speed, it is possible for only the Zenith itself to appear. However, the Zenith will lose the ability to home in on enemies, since the Zenith itself never homes.
Each sword sprite can hit 8 times per second, and may hit multiple times on a single enemy, depending on size and positioning.
Swords also deal damage behind the player while returning.

Despite being nearly identical to its copper counterpart, the Tin Shortsword cannot be used to craft the Zenith. This is presumably due to the Copper Shortsword's role as the very first sword every player will encounter (with the exception of Journey Mode characters).
The Zenith is generally considered as the game's strongest weapon, making it ideal for any type of fight.

If the player has made a Journey Mode character or has lost their Copper Shortsword and has no Copper Ore in the world, Copper can be obtained by using a Chlorophyte Extractinator with Tin Ore or Tin Bars, fishing, using an Extractinator, killing slimes for bonus drops, dipping Tin Ore into Shimmer, or bringing some ore from a different world which has Copper.

In regular combat, most players will see the Zenith dealing around 20,000 to 30,000 DPS. However, it has the potential to reach much higher DPS numbers: Against most single targets, it can reach more than 70,000 DPS with the right armor, accessories, modifiers, buffs, and correct positioning. Against segmented worm enemies like The Destroyer, it can surpass 1,000,000 DPS. In an optimized environment, the Zenith can do more than 7,000,000 DPS. Against most single targets, it can reach more than 70,000 DPS with the right armor, accessories, modifiers, buffs, and correct positioning. Against segmented worm enemies like The Destroyer, it can surpass 1,000,000 DPS. In an optimized environment, the Zenith can do more than 7,000,000 DPS.
The Zenith can defeat the Moon Lord on Master Mode (277,311 combined HP) in about 11 seconds.

The word zenith is defined as "the time/point at which something is at its most strength or successful". [1] This ties in with the fact that the Zenith is often considered the final and best weapon in the game.
The Zenith represents the player's journey, as implied from the achievement description and crafting materials.

Before the release of the 1.4.0.1 update, the sword had various placeholders and scrapped names, including Final Fractal and Summit. [2] [3] The precursor design of the Zenith exists as an unobtainable weapon, the First Fractal, which resembles an upgraded Terra Blade.
The Zenith projectiles will always include both the Light's Bane and Blood Butcherer, no matter which one was used.

The Zenith's projectiles include the Terragrim, despite not being in its crafting tree. The Bee Keeper has been in the Zenith's animation since its release in 1.4.0.1, but was only added to the crafting recipe in the 1.4.0.3 hotfix.
The following is a list of all swords displayed in the Zenith's attack animation:

The Apricot, Cherry, Grapefruit, Plum, Pomegranate, and Spicy Pepper are the only fruits that do not have unique recipes of their own. They can only be used to make Fruit Juice, Fruit Salad, and Ambrosia – recipes that allow any fruit to be used.

Cursed Skulls can be attacked through walls with melee weapons. Weapons with long range or can attack through blocks like spears or the Vilethorn work well. This may, however, result in drops being trapped inside of walls beyond the player's reach. However, this can be alleviated simply by mining into the wall or with items such as the Treasure Magnet (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Cursed Skulls and Dragon Skulls can, rather rarely, drop more than 3 ( 6 ) Bones when defeated. Verify

Cursed Skulls are effective enemies to farm for the Nazar since they spawn more often than the few other enemies that also drop it. This should preferably be done in Pre-Hardmode, since it is more difficult to obtain in Hardmode, especially when more enemy varieties start to spawn in the post- Plantera Dungeon.
The Bestiary entry for the Cursed Skull: " Exposed to dark rituals, this skull has begun floating around on its own, chasing the living. Its touch leaves its victims defenseless. "
Having different-colored wrenches for each player on multiplayer can be useful, as each player will get their own Wire color.
Having a wrench or other wire-vision item can be very useful when exploring, as it will make hidden traps much easier to see.
Selling the Ancient set will net 45 SC (42.86%) more than selling all required ingredients.
The Ancient set visually resembles the Forbidden armor set despite it having no unique ability.
The Ancient Headdress resembles common depictions of Anubis, the jackal-headed ancient Egyptian god of mummification (an ancient method of corpse preservation).
Instances of Horned God set pieces were replaced with the Ancient Headdress/Garments/Slacks upon upgrading to 1.4.0.5.4.1.
Once a world enters Hardmode, Giant Bats will almost entirely replace the once common Cave Bat.
The Bestiary entry for the Giant Bat: " The oversized cousins of Cave Bats, these bats are more dangerous and can confuse their enemies with their bite. "
The sphere fires projectiles at a rate equal to a use time of 9 (Very fast).
The sphere moves farther when it has a modifier reducing speed.
Like homing weapons, the Magnet Sphere's orb will not fire on other players in PvP, though the orb itself will deal damage on contact.
The book that the player holds out while casting can damage certain entities, including several not normally targeted by a regular weapon.
The Magnet Sphere's orb will fire at disguised Mimics.
The Magnet Sphere's projectile is visually similar to a real-life meteorological phenomenon called ball lightning.

The Lunar Cultist set resemble that of the Lunatic Devotees at the Dungeon's entrance, while the Solar Cultist set are the same shape, but have the color theme of the unspawnable White Cultist Archer.
While wearing the full Lunar Cultist set, the Lunar Cultist Hood can be replaced with the Lunatic Cultist Mask to make the player look like the Lunatic Cultist.
While wearing the full Solar Cultist set, the Solar Cultist Hood can be replaced with the Lunatic Cultist Mask with Bright Orange Dye to make the player look like a "Solatic" Cultist.
The Sharpening Station can be activated limitlessly with no cooldown period. It is never consumed, and all players may use it to give themselves the buff.

The Sharpening Station's armor penetration bonus actually checks if the player is holding a melee weapon during the buff duration in real time [1], so it can also be applied to damage done by ranged, magic, or summon weapons, even damage without types by switching held items. This is useful for minion/sentry weapons, and some fire-and-forget weapons such as Spiky Ball, Crimson Rod, Weather Pain, Nimbus Rod, Clinger Staff, Magnet Sphere, and Rainbow Gun. Since it applies to all minion/sentry weapons, melee-summoner hybrid builds benefit a lot from it. However, this bonus does not apply to whips because of the buff Real-time checking holding weapon，meaning that the player will have to give up whip bonuses in place of 12 extra armor penetration. Since it applies to all minion/sentry weapons, melee-summoner hybrid builds benefit a lot from it. However, this bonus does not apply to whips because of the buff Real-time checking holding weapon，meaning that the player will have to give up whip bonuses in place of 12 extra armor penetration.
In real life, sharpening stations, also known as grindstones, are used to sharpen blades.
The buff does not reduce enemy spawn rates during the Pumpkin Moon, Frost Moon, or Frost Legion events.
The Calm buff will stack with the buff provided by Peace Candles and the Happy! buff from Sunflowers, further reducing enemy spawn rates.
The Battle Potion has the opposite effect.
The Calm buff also reduces the spawn rate of critters, as do all other artificial reductions to enemy spawn rates, besides the presence of Town NPCs.
If the player wants to loot the Chests in the Dungeon and already has a sufficient number of Golden Keys, using this potion before entering may be a good idea.

While not directly helpful against bosses themselves, it can be useful to use against some like the Queen Bee or the Wall of Flesh whose biomes typically have numerous enemy spawns which could make the fight harder, or when mining Meteorite to curb Meteor Head spawns.

The Broken Hero Sword drop explicitly requires that all three mechanical bosses have been defeated. [1] This is always the case in regular gameplay, since it is a prerequisite to fighting Plantera and Mothron, but if Mothron is encountered earlier because of mods or other third-party tools, then it will not drop a Broken Hero Sword.

Given the drop rate, it is not guaranteed to obtain a Broken Hero Sword during a Solar Eclipse. Therefore, it can be a good idea to use Water Candles and/or Battle Potions during a Solar Eclipse to increase the number of opportunities of having one or even multiple Broken Hero Swords dropped.

This item is an allusion to the classic literary trope of the disgraced or defeated hero who must repair their sword, or the similar trope of taking up the weapon of a past hero (perhaps killed by the monster dropping this item) to fulfill a destiny.
Shadow Candles will also stop the Town Day/Town Night music tracks from playing in their vicinity.
In the presence of a Shadow Candle, standing still or in front of safe walls will not prevent Wyverns, Chaos Elementals, and other enemies with such particular conditions from spawning.
Since the Skeleton Merchant is not considered a town NPC in regards to reducing enemy spawns, the candle has no effect on his disruptive presence in farms.
The item is not consumed upon use and does not have a mana cost. The drone can be re-summoned limitlessly.
As the drone is a projectile, it can trigger Teal Pressure Pads.
The drone can be dyed via the pet slot in the equipment menu.

The effects from the biome the player is in, including music, retain when the drone is in a different biome or depth level while using the FPV Goggles. For example, flying the drone from the Underworld to the Cavern will keep the Underworld music and the heatwave effect. For example, flying the drone from the Underworld to the Cavern will keep the Underworld music and the heatwave effect.
Flying the drone can be much more difficult thanks to the thumbstick controls.
The item's tooltip is a reference to a quote from the 1996 novel Fight Club : "The first rule of fight club is: You don't talk about fight club".
When hitting a player in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), a Creeper always inflicts one of the nine following debuffs: [2]
Creepers are susceptible to all damaging debuffs like On Fire!, Frostburn, or Poisoned, making weapons that inflict them as well as flasks a good choice for increasing DPS.

Creepers can be made more manageable with piercing weapons and ammunition, such as Jester's Arrows, Unholy Arrows, and Hellfire Arrows, as well as weapons with splash damage such as Grenades and Molotov Cocktails.
Creepers do not drop souls, Biome Keys, or Biome Key Molds (Old-gen console and 3DS versions).

In Classic Mode, the Brain of Cthulhu does not drop any Tissue Samples itself; only Creepers do. However, both enemies drop Crimtane Ore. [3] In Expert Mode, the Brain's Treasure Bag will drop some Tissue Samples.
The Creeper's 1/2 chance to drop a Heart is six times higher than the regular 1/12 chance of most other enemies.
The Creeper resembles the Phantasmal Sphere attack of the Moon Lord and his True Eyes of Cthulhu.
Creepers are one of the few enemies that cannot pick up dropped coins in Expert Mode.

The Obsidian Lock Box sells for 40 SC, but every item that is obtained from it sells for 2 GC 50 SC. Therefore, opening the box and selling its content is at least 625% more profitable than selling the box itself.
In real life, Guy Fawkes masks are based on a stylized depiction of Guy Fawkes, a member of a group of provincial English Catholics who planned the failed Gunpowder Plot of 1605.
Two of the Scarecrow variants in the Pumpkin Moon event appear to be wearing Guy Fawkes Masks.
The tooltip is a reference to Maxwell 's examination quote for the Froggle Bunwich in Don't Starve.

The Lever is identical in operation to the Switch. The Lever is easier to see and activate, as it provides a larger clicking target; whereas Switches can be more difficult to spot and click on due to being only a single tile in size. On the other hand, Levers (somewhat non-intuitively) cannot be placed against a vertical block, as Switches can. The Lever is easier to see and activate, as it provides a larger clicking target; whereas Switches can be more difficult to spot and click on due to being only a single tile in size. On the other hand, Levers (somewhat non-intuitively) cannot be placed against a vertical block, as Switches can.

Paint can be used to identify what the Lever is used for, as well as what each state does. By using a different color for each side, the Lever's two states can be colored differently; this is particularly useful when the Lever does something more complex than an "on/off" function, like switching a Minecart Track junction. Using non-deep paints will allow the ball to be recolored while having minimal impact on the Lever's arm and base.
The inventory sprite shows the Lever switched to the left side, although it is switched to the right by default when it is placed.
On the Lever's sprite, the base appears to be the sprite of a Pressure Plate, but does not show any of the colors that can come from any of the actual pressure plates.
Leeches do not despawn once the Wall of Flesh has been defeated.
Unlike most other burrowing enemies, Leeches do not create a digging noise, nor produce particles while digging.

In Classic Mode, they will always drop a Heart when they die, but in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the chances of a Leech dropping a Heart get reduced to a fifth. Preparing a platform before the fight can help to collect their dropped Hearts.
The Bestiary entry for the Leech: " A worm-like parasite spit forth from the Wall of Flesh, filled with the lifeblood of its host. This blood has healing properties. "

The best way to monetize Granite Blocks is to craft Granite Candelabras : Convert to Smooth Granite Blocks at a Work Bench without any loss, then use 5 Smooth Granite Blocks and 3 Torches. Candelabras sell for 3 SC, for a profit of 1 SC 50 CC if Torches are purchased, or 2 SC 70 CC if crafted. This takes into account the value of the Torches if sold directly.
The real-life counterpart of the granite found in-game is most likely Larvikite, also called "blue pearl granite."

Due to the block dropping from both Granite Golems and Granite Elementals, Granite (and some items made from it) can be considered renewable. Granite Golems spawned from their respective statue will still drop Granite Blocks, making it an incredibly easy block to obtain. Granite Golems spawned from their respective statue will still drop Granite Blocks, making it an incredibly easy block to obtain.

The phrase in the Guardian Golem's tooltip, "'Power cells not included.'", is a nod to how most battery-powered toys in commercials and advertisements state a similar warning for "batteries not included", and alludes to how Golem is summoned with Lihzahrd Power Cells.

The buff's tooltip is a reference to the song " Living Doll " written by Lionel Bart for Cliff Richard and The Shadows (then still known as "the Drifters") in 1959. The original lyrics were: "Got myself a cryin', talkin', sleepin', walkin', livin' doll". The tooltip simply replaces "doll" with "idol", as Golem is the Lihzahrdian Idol.
When summoned, the Toy Golem will always attempt to position itself in front of the player. This is likely because it is meant to act as a guardian, hence the name of the item.
The Angry Tumbler will despawn if the nearest player is not in a Desert biome. [1]
The Angry Tumbler is rather slow when moving in the opposite direction of the storm, so jumping over it and forcing it to change direction can help deal with the enemy.

Ranged weapons are useful when fighting Angry Tumblers, such as a bow with a lot of arrows, especially if they inflict debuffs, like Frostburn Arrows. Due to the enemy's fairly low knockback resistance, any weapon that fires quickly and/or deals high knockback is preferable.
The Angry Tumbler is a tumbleweed, which is a classical and sometimes humorous symbol of desolate desert locations in film.

Magic Power Potions are very useful when using the Spectre Hood version of the Spectre armor, as the hood will reduce magic damage by 40% (25% after the bonuses of the other armor pieces). Thus, this potion can reduce the penalties of the armor down to only 5% less magic damage, causing greater damage and thus greater healing potential.
Since the usefulness of the Toolbelt's effect is often limited in combat, it may be preferable to leave it in a social slot or storage item in those situations, to make room for another accessory.
Unlike regular broadswords, the True Excalibur can only hit up to six targets per swing.
The True Excalibur will always knock enemies away from the player, regardless of the direction it is swung.
Due to the large arc of the True Excalibur's attack, it makes for a great melee weapon against Plantera, as it can easily dispose of Plantera's Tentacles.

Although the True Excalibur and True Night's Edge were previously comparable due to their similarities and being obtained in the same place in progression, changes in 1.4.4 have made them much more distinct weapons.

Using different-colored gem torches or Gemspark Blocks beneath each sapling can be a good way to indicate which type of tree is planted where. Alternatively, paint can be used on the other blocks (as in the picture above); a Gemcorn planted on a painted block will sprout into a painted Gem Tree (just as it would with other types of trees ) that could instead make it difficult to see the type of gem due to the coloring. However, using the Illuminant Coating on the actual blocks where Gem Trees are planted could help to tell the gems apart, since it causes the trees and the colored gems on it be fully visible, regardless of lighting (or lack thereof). However, using the Illuminant Coating on the actual blocks where Gem Trees are planted could help to tell the gems apart, since it causes the trees and the colored gems on it be fully visible, regardless of lighting (or lack thereof).
Gemcorns can be sold for the value of their respective gem.

While Gemcorns can be planted on mossy stone, the outgrowths of moss can block the sapling's growth. Furthermore, while a single stroke of a pickaxe will normally remove moss from Stone, this does not work if a Gem Tree has grown on the block. (Moss can still be removed from beneath a sapling)
