The "One Eyed Pirate" variant seems to resemble a miniature version of the Pirate Deadeye enemy.
The pirates seem to use a miniature version of the Falcon Blade when attacking.

This item is one of several crossover references to the game Pixel Piracy. The pirates' defecation behavior is similar to their behavior in the Pixel Piracy game. The pirates' defecation behavior is similar to their behavior in the Pixel Piracy game.
If the player strays too far from a pirate, a parrot will carry it back to the player.
The Seaweed Planter appears to be in a Greek- or Roman-style pot.

Like the Steampunker and Santa Claus, the pirate's spawn requirements do not necessarily require the world to be in Hardmode. However, at least one Hardmode world is required to obtain the event-summoning item.
In the housing menu, his description states "I think he lost his boat".
The Pirate looks like the Pirate Captain in the Pirate Invasion (minus the gold gloves on the enemy's sprite).

The Pirate's Shimmered form appears to be of a ghost, in reference to ghost ships, which can be seen often in media. The Shimmered form shares a resemblance with the Pirate's Curse, an enemy that spawns when a Pirate Captain enemy is defeated. The Pirate uses a ghostly death sound https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:NPC_Killed_6.wav when killed in his Shimmered form (instead of the normal NPC death sound https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:NPC_Killed_1.wav ). The Shimmered form shares a resemblance with the Pirate's Curse, an enemy that spawns when a Pirate Captain enemy is defeated. The Pirate uses a ghostly death sound https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:NPC_Killed_6.wav when killed in his Shimmered form (instead of the normal NPC death sound https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:NPC_Killed_1.wav ).

Many of the Pirate's possible names allude to historical captains (though the "pirate" status of many of these figures is contested to this day): Black Beard to the English pirate Edward "Blackbeard" Teach. Red Beard to the Ottoman seaman Oruç Reis who was known as Baba Oruç, which was transformed into Barbarossa (Redbeard in Italian) in Europe. David to the idiom Davy Jones' Locker. Captain Morgan to the Welsh privateer Sir Henry Morgan. James T. Beard to the fictional starship captain James T. Kirk from the American media franchise Star Trek. (Notably not a pirate character) Jack to the main protagonist of the Pirates of the Caribbean film series, Captain Jack Sparrow. The name Jake could be a reference to the American musical and interactive children's animated television series Jake and the Never Land Pirates. Black Beard to the English pirate Edward "Blackbeard" Teach. Red Beard to the Ottoman seaman Oruç Reis who was known as Baba Oruç, which was transformed into Barbarossa (Redbeard in Italian) in Europe. David to the idiom Davy Jones' Locker. Captain Morgan to the Welsh privateer Sir Henry Morgan. James T. Beard to the fictional starship captain James T. Kirk from the American media franchise Star Trek. (Notably not a pirate character) Jack to the main protagonist of the Pirates of the Caribbean film series, Captain Jack Sparrow. The name Jake could be a reference to the American musical and interactive children's animated television series Jake and the Never Land Pirates.

His quote " I'm no landlubber, but it's better to have lubbed and lost than never to have lubbed at all. " is a reference to "It's better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all" from Alfred Tennyson's poem In Memoriam A.H.H..
His quote " What in blazes are ye talkin' about? Moby Dick is mine! " is a reference to the 1851 novel Moby-Dick.
His quote " Yo ho ho and a bottle of....blinkroots! " is a reference to the sea song " Dead Man's Chest ".
Although the Cyborg says that the Pirate treats him favorably, the Cyborg does not appear to affect the Pirate's Happiness.
Rarely, the Pirate and the Guide can have the same name (Jake or Jack).
During a Party (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), other than donning a party hat, his sleeves also appear different.
The flaming pumpkins from The Horseman's Blade will home in on the Pirate even though he is not an enemy.
Apparently the Pirate has a soft spot for the Angler and wants to teach him to be a pirate.
The Pirate sometimes defecates, similar to the Pirate minion.

Christmas pudding is a pudding made from dried fruit that is traditionally served for dinner on Christmas in Great Britain alongside a cream-based or alcoholic sauce, and originated from medieval England.
The Dark Shard represents the Yin of the Yin Yang (Taijitu) symbol, and the Light Shard represents the Yang. Both are combined in the Dao of Pow, making the full Yin Yang.
The Penguin looks identical to the penguin inside the Penguin Cage.

The Staff of Regrowth will not destroy the following tiles when hitting them, unless it is used on them directly: [1] Flowers and weeds (including Nature's Gifts and Jungle Roses ) Mushrooms, Glowing Mushrooms, Vile Mushrooms, and Vicious Mushrooms Regular, Jungle, Mushroom, Crimson, and Hallowed vines (flower vines are destroyed) Jungle Spores Herbs in all stages of growth Moss fuzz Cattails, lily pads, Sea Oats, and seaweeds Flowers and weeds (including Nature's Gifts and Jungle Roses ) Mushrooms, Glowing Mushrooms, Vile Mushrooms, and Vicious Mushrooms Regular, Jungle, Mushroom, Crimson, and Hallowed vines (flower vines are destroyed) Jungle Spores Herbs in all stages of growth Moss fuzz Cattails, lily pads, Sea Oats, and seaweeds
Normally, destroying a herb yields the herb item and 1–3 of its seeds. The Staff of Regrowth increases this yield to 1–2 of the herb item and 1–5 of its seeds. [2]

Herbs that are planted in a Clay Pot or Planter Box (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and are not blooming cannot be harvested whatsoever with the Staff of Regrowth. This is likely to prevent accidental harvesting of non-mature herbs.
Despite being found in the Jungle, the Staff of Regrowth does not grow Jungle Grass on Mud Blocks.
If grass is grown near lava, it will revert to dirt after a few moments.
Using the Staff of Regrowth to collect Glowing Mushrooms will not yield extra Glowing Mushrooms nor Mushroom Grass Seeds.
Grass placed below, and moss placed above 0 depth will not naturally spread and will not grow tall grass or fuzz.

The Staff (or Axe (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) ) of Regrowth is the tool of choice to increase herb yields, especially from farming. When harvesting plants from Clay Pots and Planter Boxes, it will only collect blooming herbs at remarkable speed, and leave the other variants unaffected. This guarantees a yield of seeds and also removes the danger of wasting a plant by accident (i.e. when using a pickaxe). Over blocks, however, the Staff of Regrowth can force the full-grown versions to drop seeds. This is useful to get seeds for plants that bloom rarely, e.g. the Deathweed. When harvesting plants from Clay Pots and Planter Boxes, it will only collect blooming herbs at remarkable speed, and leave the other variants unaffected. This guarantees a yield of seeds and also removes the danger of wasting a plant by accident (i.e. when using a pickaxe). Over blocks, however, the Staff of Regrowth can force the full-grown versions to drop seeds. This is useful to get seeds for plants that bloom rarely, e.g. the Deathweed.

The Staff of Regrowth may grow grass on any Dirt Block, no matter how deep it is. Unfortunately, grass has limited function underground, as in the Underground layer and below, grass will not grow weeds or Dayblooms, and Acorns will not mature.
The Staff of Regrowth functions well as a trail marker in the Underground layer, as grass stands out well in the environment of grays and browns.
The Staff of Regrowth can be used to indirectly spread Hallowed grass, Corrupt grass, or Crimson grass underground by growing grass near Pearlstone, Ebonstone, or Crimstone respectively.
The Staff of Regrowth is useful for placement of Sunflowers in arenas, homes, etc. Sunflowers can be placed anywhere with just two grass-covered dirt blocks, and enough vertical space.
The rate at which grass, and moss is created with the Staff of Regrowth is increased by the Brick Layer.
It is the only staff in the game that is classified as a melee item.

Chlorophyte Bullets pair well with the Chain Gun, as their homing ability negates the gun's singular weakness of accuracy. Note that it may cause framerate drops on low-end computers, due to its streak effect. Note that it may cause framerate drops on low-end computers, due to its streak effect.
Crystal Bullets also can deal large amounts of damage to larger, stationary enemies and bosses such as Golem.

With the Rapid or Frenzying modifier, the Chain Gun will gain 25% speed. This happens due to rounding down its already exceptionally low use time (4 to 3). The Godly modifier is better for players preferring to save ammo, at the cost of slightly less damage. DPS for Godly: DPS=(36+bullet-roundup(def/2))*60/4*1.09. The DPS for Rapid: DPS=(31+bullet-roundup(def/2))*60/3*1.04.

Because of its extremely high rate of fire, the Endless Musket Pouch should be used in regular combat to save more valuable shots for important boss fights. This is made especially evident when considering that firing at 15 shots per second means that even 999 bullets at 50% ammo conservation will still be entirely used, on average, within 2 minutes and 13 seconds. Considering 999 Chlorophyte Bullets need (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 17 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 15 Chlorophyte Bars, this could be seen as very expensive and impractical or not a full return on investment in terms of time spent obtaining the ammo compared to time utilizing the ammo. This is made especially evident when considering that firing at 15 shots per second means that even 999 bullets at 50% ammo conservation will still be entirely used, on average, within 2 minutes and 13 seconds. Considering 999 Chlorophyte Bullets need (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 17 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 15 Chlorophyte Bars, this could be seen as very expensive and impractical or not a full return on investment in terms of time spent obtaining the ammo compared to time utilizing the ammo.

The Chain Gun is a very good weapon to use if fighting the Dungeon Guardian due to its exceptional fire rate. This is best done with Crystal Bullets, as the shards that they create can damage the Dungeon Guardian multiple times per shot.
The gun appears to be a miniature version of Santa-NK1 's arm.

The Chain Gun fires 3 more shots per second than the S.D.M.G. with no speed modifiers. The Chain Gun fires 15 shots/second which translates to 900 shots/minute. The Chain Gun fires 15 shots/second which translates to 900 shots/minute.

The Chain Gun is one of the 11 guns in Terraria based on a real gun, the others being the Flintlock Pistol, Handgun, Musket, Quad-Barrel Shotgun (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Red Ryder (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Revolver (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Shotgun, Sniper Rifle, Tactical Shotgun, and Uzi. Despite its name, the Chain Gun is not actually a chain gun, but a rotary cannon due to the fact that it possesses multiple barrels in a presumably Gatling-style configuration. It still being referred to as a chain gun despite this fact could make it a reference to the Chaingun from the video game series Doom, which is also not an actual chain gun. Despite its name, the Chain Gun is not actually a chain gun, but a rotary cannon due to the fact that it possesses multiple barrels in a presumably Gatling-style configuration. It still being referred to as a chain gun despite this fact could make it a reference to the Chaingun from the video game series Doom, which is also not an actual chain gun.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It is not advisable to consume Marshmallows directly, since cooking them raises their buff duration tenfold and requires merely a single piece of any type of Wood.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Marshmallow has the shortest duration of any food item in the game.
Its tooltip 'How many can you fit in your mouth?' is a reference to the recreational game " chubby bunny ", which involves the placement of an increasing number of marshmallows into one's own mouth.

Toggles for Actuators and Wires have three states: Bright : actuators/wires of this color will be always displayed at maximum brightness. Classic : actuators/wires of this color will be displayed as normal, with their brightness affected by nearby light sources. Faded : brightness is determined the same way as the Classic state, but actuators/wires of this color will also be semi-transparent. Bright : actuators/wires of this color will be always displayed at maximum brightness. Classic : actuators/wires of this color will be displayed as normal, with their brightness affected by nearby light sources. Faded : brightness is determined the same way as the Classic state, but actuators/wires of this color will also be semi-transparent.

The Mechanical Display toggle have two states: Forced : all Actuators and Wires will be displayed regardless of item held, while their display method is determined by the respective toggle. Normal : all Actuators and Wires will be displayed only if a mechanism -related item is held. Forced : all Actuators and Wires will be displayed regardless of item held, while their display method is determined by the respective toggle. Normal : all Actuators and Wires will be displayed only if a mechanism -related item is held.

There are some differences between The Grand Design and its component wiring tools: Instead of affecting only one single block per use, the tool is used by holding the ⚒ Use / Attack button to draw a line (including one possible corner) where the tool places / harvests wire when releasing the button. When dragging out a line to place or remove wires, the player can control the direction the path takes by changing the character's direction. If the character faces to the right, the path selected by The Grand Design will travel vertically from the starting point, and then horizontally to the cursor. If the character faces to the left, the path selected by The Grand Design will travel horizontally from the starting point, and then vertically to the cursor. It can place about 1,000 tiles of wire and/or Actuators at a time and can be used while moving, making long range settings (like Teleporters ) easier to construct. This is particularly easy when using the UFO Mount running wires in the sky. Note that the "drawing mode" will be canceled after one minute of holding down the ⚒ Use / Attack button, needing to be re-used to function again. The Grand Design can be used without range limits, whereas the various wrenches must be within range of the player's building area to place wires. Breaking a wire or Actuator with The Grand Design causes them to automatically appear at the player's feet, regardless of distance or obstructions, unlike the Wire Cutter. If the player stands in lava (presumably with the help of the Lava Charm or a similar item), any broken wire or Actuators will be lost, as the item spawns directly on the player when it is broken, and therefore will be destroyed if the player is submerged in lava. If the player stands in lava (presumably with the help of the Lava Charm or a similar item), any broken wire or Actuators will be lost, as the item spawns directly on the player when it is broken, and therefore will be destroyed if the player is submerged in lava.
Like the Multicolor Wrench, it places / harvests wires of the selected colors, which means it is possible to place / harvest all 4 colors of wires at the same time.
This item is an effective way of dealing with traps, such as Explosives and Boulders, and serves as a far more compact way of storing wiring tools.

When dismantling certain naturally-generated traps (like those in the Dungeon which are diagonally-placed), a Wire Cutter may be preferable, as the Grand Design cannot take advantage of smart cursor. For other traps, however, the Grand Design is usually the best tool, as it allows remote collection of wires.
The internal name for both The Grand Design and its projectiles is WireKite, possibly a humorous poke at its inventory icon resembling a real-world kite.
The Grand Design is possibly a reference to a book by Stephen Hawking of the same name.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It is possible to obtain Cursed Flames in a world which was generated with Crimson by creating an artificial Underground Corruption. To do so, one can buy Corrupt Seeds from the Dryad during Hardmode while in a Graveyard, and use them to seed the Underground Corruption biome. Alternatively, one might simply bring the material from another world which has Corruption. Alternatively, one might simply bring the material from another world which has Corruption.

The Cursed Flame may be based on Greek fire, an incendiary weapon used by the Byzantine Empire that was able to burn almost anywhere and was used in naval warfare. It also may be based on the cursed green flames from " The Festival ", a short story by H. P. Lovecraft. It also may be based on the cursed green flames from " The Festival ", a short story by H. P. Lovecraft.
Spazmatism can shoot Cursed Flame, but it will not drop Cursed Flame items.
The Cursed Flare is the only item made from Cursed Flame that does not have an Ichor variant.
In multiplayer, only one 0x33's Aviators will be dropped from each Eye of Cthulhu, regardless of the number of players involved in the fight.
This item is a reference to Terraria streamer 0x33 who killed the Moon Lord in Expert Mode with a Hardcore character.
Its tooltip, "'Great for impersonating streamers!'", is both a reference to 0x33 and to developer items, whose tooltips are similar ( " 'Great for impersonating devs!' " ).
0x33's Aviators, Chippy's Couch, and Pedguin's set are the only pre-Hardmode items to have the 09* base rarity. These items are also all references to Terraria streamers.

0x33's Aviators are the only Master Mode-exclusive item without the 13* rarity. This is likely due to its status as a streamer item, which all have the 09* rarity. This is likely due to its status as a streamer item, which all have the 09* rarity.
The Pirate Ship Mount deals 100 base summon damage. Like other mounts, this damage can be boosted by items that boost summon damage.
The Flying Dutchman can be fought before beating any of the mechanical bosses, making the Pirate Ship Mount the only mount with infinite flight obtainable at this progression.
While most other mounts are four tiles tall, the Pirate Ship Mount is five tiles tall.

This mount is the only currently known mount that is capable of dash storage. During dash storage—even after stopping or dismounting—the effects of a Shield of Cthulu dash remain, including being knocked back after hitting an enemy.

Obtaining The Black Spot prior to defeating a mechanical boss is a challenging (given the difficulty of the Master Mode, early-Hardmode Pirate Invasion ) but rewarding task. See Pirate Invasion § Tips and Guide:Pirate Invasion strategies for tips.
It is advisable to remove mobility accessories when using the mount, as they will not boost its movement.

Although the Pirate Ship Mount has decent speed, its acceleration, turning, and stopping rates are relatively slow, making it less agile than other flying mounts. The acceleration also makes its ramming capabilities difficult to utilize. Other mounts, such as the Witch's Broom or UFO Mount (both have an acceleration of 49 mph /second, compared to the Pirate Ship Mount's 25 mph /second), may be more suited e.g. for dodging incoming attacks.
The item is a reference to the adventure novel Treasure Island by Scottish author Robert Louis Stevenson, where pieces of paper marked with a black spot play an important role.

The buff tooltip may be a nod to the 2013 American biographical drama-thriller movie Captain Phillips, where the pirate Abduwali Muse says "I'm the captain now", a phrase commonly used within meme communities on the internet.

Prior to the 1.4.1 update, the Pirate Ship Mount had an extraordinary speed of 81 mph ( 91 mph diagonally, and no decrease in water). Therefore, it was often considered to be among the best mounts in the game, despite being obtainable before any of the mechanical bosses have been defeated.
It must be equipped to work in the Old-gen console version. It will not display the time if it is in the inventory.

Melee users should not have too much trouble with this enemy since most melee weapons available at this point cannot be reflected. Ranged users should use weapons that fire rockets, such as the Snowman Cannon. Many useful magic weapons cannot be reflected, such as the Razorblade Typhoon, the Rainbow Gun, and the Magnet Sphere. Summoners also have an advantage as most minions deal contact damage without firing projectiles.
The Selenian, Stargazer, Predictor, and Vortexian all share very similar sprites.
The word selenian means pertaining to the moon and refers to Selene, the Greek goddess of the moon and sister of the sun god Helios.
General color of ears corresponds to character 's skin color.
The Dungeon will generally contain 1-2 Handguns.

The internal code for generating dungeon chests fills chests with different items in order of their distance to the Dungeon's entrance, with the Handgun being the last item on the list before it starts over. As such, if a dungeon has more than 9 or 10 chests, one will always have the Handgun.

It is recommended to upgrade the Handgun to the Phoenix Blaster as soon as possible, as it gives (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 4 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 7 additional damage, and increases its velocity by 3.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Since Hellstone can be obtained pre- boss (if the Reaver Shark is obtained early on), one can easily upgrade to the Phoenix Blaster.
The Handgun is modeled after the M1911 pistol. (specifically the M1911A1 as there are no diamond cutouts on the grip)

The Handgun is one of the 11 guns in Terraria based on a real gun, the others being the Chain Gun, Flintlock Pistol, Musket, Quad-Barrel Shotgun (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Red Ryder (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Revolver (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Shotgun, Sniper Rifle, Tactical Shotgun, and Uzi.
The Skeleton Sniper must pause again after being hit, so using rapid-firing weapons will prevent it from attacking.
Weapons with high knockback are not advisable for this enemy, because knocking it back far enough will make it pause instantly (provided it lands on solid ground) and shoot the player with ease.

The Skeleton Sniper's overall aesthetic bears striking resemblance to an undead German Wehrmacht sniper from the WWI - or WWII -era. This follows the common " Nazi zombies " archetype in popular culture and works of fiction. The Skeleton Sniper's weapon of choice follows this aesthetic: The weapon resembles a traditional bolt-action rifle with wood furnishing, such as the Karabiner 98k which was the standard-issue service rifle in Germany during WWII. The weapon may also be modeled after the FG 42, which was used by German paratroopers during WWII. The FG 42 was meant to be a replacement for a light machine gun, not a sniper rifle. However, a few were equipped with ZF4 scopes and used in a limited sniper role. The Skeleton Sniper also appears to wear a Stahlhelm, a helmet commonly used by the German military during both World Wars. The Skeleton Sniper will only occasionally drop a Rifle Scope, and it is not a guaranteed drop. This reflects the period during WWII when only a very small amount of semi-automatic and bolt-action rifles were equipped with scopes. The overwhelming majority of small arms in WWII were only fitted with iron sights, and very few actual snipers had the luxury of a scoped rifle. There were more marksmen and snipers than there were scopes. The Sniper Rifle dropped is a completely different type of sniper rifle, itself resembling a more modern L96A1.

It is a reference to the Red Ryder BB Gun. The gun is also referenced in the 1983 American Christmas comedy film A Christmas Story, hence the tooltip, which refers to a phrase often shouted in the story: "You'll shoot your eye out!"

The Red Ryder is one of the 11 guns in Terraria based on a real gun, the others being the Chain Gun, Flintlock Pistol, Handgun, Musket, Quad-Barrel Shotgun (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Revolver (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), Shotgun, Sniper Rifle, Tactical Shotgun, and Uzi. Out of these, the Red Ryder and Uzi are the only two to use the trademarks of the guns they are referencing. Out of these, the Red Ryder and Uzi are the only two to use the trademarks of the guns they are referencing.

If a player with the buff stands still, regardless of being inside or outside of honey, their health will regenerate faster. When the buffed player moves again, health will regenerate slower. This applies to all forms of regeneration.

It is strongly advised that players create a Wooden Sword instead of a Rich Mahogany Sword because players spawn in a Forest, and it would be a hassle going through the dangerous enemies of the Jungle.
With acorns, mud and Jungle Grass Seeds, the player can plant Jungle Trees closer to home.

The Rich Mahogany Sword's sprite is very similar to that of the Wooden Sword; however, there are a few changes, the most obvious being that it has an altered color. Also, the handle is slightly different in that it has sharp, angled quillions, rather than the stubbier ones of the Wooden Sword.

Dirt Walls generally completely cover the background at Underground depths above zero ( see Layer, Depth Meter ). Placing new walls in this area would require first tearing down the existing walls starting from the top (the Surface ) or the bottom (zero depth), which can be an arduous task. Alternatively, the existing walls can be destroyed using explosives.

At depths below zero, the backdrop of the map is generally no longer covered with actual wall tiles, though this can be difficult to differentiate visually since the biome background at these depths can have a similar appearance. Walls can be placed freely here by players.
Torches and several other furniture items can be placed directly on background walls without requiring blocks below them.
Most walls have no coin value, even if they were crafted from rare materials. Stained glass and wallpaper bought from the Painter are exceptions.
Walls appear to have their own placement layer.
Hellhounds cannot descend through platforms.

Hellhounds are mythical beasts, mentioned in the mythologies of various cultures, that are often related in some way to death, the afterlife, or the supernatural. While their physical characteristics may vary, they are commonly portrayed as possessing black fur, immense size and strength, and red eyes or an association with fire.
The Lunar Portal cannot target or attack enemies through blocks.
The Lunar Portal Laser applies 10 ticks of local immunity frames upon hitting an enemy.
The portal gives off light and has no restrictions on where it can be placed, allowing the player to find caves easily.

By default, only one sentry can be placed at a time, and attempting to place another will remove the previous sentry unless the player is wearing an accessory or a piece of armor that increases sentry capacity.
The Lunar Portal starts firing a new beam every half a second. Considering its perfect tracking, this means two hits per second per portal is the lowest possible hit rate for a single target.

If a portal happens to be located very close to its target (preferably inside it) then both beams are consistently in contact with it. In such situations, the target suffers the listed portal damage ten times every second.

The portal fires a beam that will sweep across enemies in a wide arc, so it should be positioned in a way that allows it to sweep the beam across a large section of the ground. This facilitates hitting large numbers of enemies, inflicting high DPS to enemies and bosses made up of segments like The Destroyer. Generally, this means making sure to place it fairly high overhead, although it varies based on terrain.

The portal is very similar in appearance to the projectiles launched by the Nebula Arcanum and the swirling portals that form around the Vortex Pillar. The laser being fired is similar to the Phantasmal Deathray fired from the Moon Lord and its True Eyes of Cthulhu.
The Lunar Portal Staff is internally called MoonlordTurretStaff.
It appears in the video game Dungeon Defenders 2 as part of a crossover.
Grapefruit originated in Barbados and when found was given the name "Forbidden Fruit".

The Apricot, Cherry, Grapefruit, Plum, Pomegranate, and Spicy Pepper are the only fruits that do not have unique recipes of their own. They can only be used to make Fruit Juice, Fruit Salad, and Ambrosia – recipes that allow any fruit to be used.
The Anti-Gravity Hook is useful to exploit the AI of flying bosses with dash abilities, such as Mothron. Spinning in circles may allow the player to dodge attacks effortlessly.

Smooth walls can be climbed extremely quickly with the Anti-Gravity Hook by pressing the Grapple key quickly and holding the ▲ Up key while the mouse is at the top and slightly to the right of the middle of the screen.
In Old-gen console and 3DS versions, the Celestial Stone stacks with the Sun Stone or Moon Stone.
The life regeneration granted by this accessory is as powerful as (twice as powerful in (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) versions) a Band of Regeneration, and will also stack with the Band.
Players should upgrade it quickly with the Moon Shell to make the Celestial Shell (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), as it gives the stats of both items with no losses.
The Celestial Stone is not visible on the player when equipped, despite the fact that its ingredients are.

Of all accessories, the Ankh Shield and the Celestial Stone give the fourth most base defense, being bested by the Flesh Knuckles (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Berserker's Glove (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (8 base defense), the Celestial Shell (7 defense when worn at night), the Paladin's Shield and Frozen Shield (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (6 base defense), and the Hero Shield (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (10 base defense).

The easiest way to farm Sea Snails would be to summon a Blood Moon or a Solar Eclipse, and to camp out at the bottom of the Ocean with a Water Candle and a Battle Potion as well as using equipment that lets the player breathe underwater (such as a Neptune's Shell ) and killing any enemies that spawn. If done correctly, the player should obtain the Sea Snail's respective banner in roughly two in-game days.

It closely resembles the Syrinx aruanus (commonly known as Australian trumpet or false trumpet), the largest extant snail (shelled gastropod) species in the world, and the largest (heaviest) gastropod in the world.
The Murex sea snail was used to create purple dye, a dye that was so rare that its value was its own weight in gold. This is also why most country flags do not contain purple.
It may be preferable to skip this armor set and go for Meteor, Shadow, Crimson, Jungle, or Hellstone armors instead because of how expensive the Platinum armor is to craft.
While the Tin, Lead, and Tungsten armors closely resemble their ore counterparts, the Platinum Helmet is more similar in design to the Ancient Gold Helmet.
The Phoenix Blaster is useful into early-mid Hardmode, outclassing many early-Hardmode weapons.
The Phoenix Blaster is highly effective against the Wall of Flesh due to its high base damage and firepower.
The Phoenix Blaster is modeled after the Colt M1911 pistol.
It appears to have a flashlight/laser "under-barrel" attachment under its barrel, although it is unusable.
Although being made out of Hellstone, the Phoenix Blaster does not have any attacks or stats related to flames.
Although they spawn during the Blood Moon event, they cannot drop Bloody Tears.
The Bestiary entry for the Vicious Penguin: " During a Blood Moon, the normally docile penguins become infested with the contagious growth of the Crimson. "
The Cactus Pickaxe has the same pickaxe power as the Copper and Tin Pickaxes, but is slightly slower in terms of mining speed.
The Cactus Pickaxe does not require ores or an Anvil to craft, which means that it can be obtained even before venturing underground.
This set, paired with a Gi, does great damage for a set obtainable before defeating any bosses.
In the early-access release of Terraria 1.3, the armor's set bonus was 75% chance to not consume thrown items. It was reduced to 50% before the public release.

There seems to be an Amber on the front of the Helmet and in the middle of the Plate, although no Amber is used in the crafting recipe. This is likely because Amber is considered the gem associated with the Desert biome.

It has the exact same mining speed as the Pickaxe Axe with its only advantage being the +1 range. As Chlorophyte is a highly contested resource and the Chlorophyte pickaxe cannot be used as an axe, it is usually not worth crafting this item. As Chlorophyte is a highly contested resource and the Chlorophyte pickaxe cannot be used as an axe, it is usually not worth crafting this item.
This vanity set is most likely a reference to Grox The Great's mod GRealm, which contains a very similar set of armor called Grovite armor.
Crimson grass may also be obtained by planting regular grass and using Red Solution or Vicious Powder on it.
The Sonar Potion will detect if a Blood Moon enemy is about to be hooked.
Using the Chum Caster will greatly increase the chances of hooking Blood Moon enemies.

The Wandering Eye Fish has high health and defense, moves very quickly, and does not take knockback, making it a challenging enemy for underpowered characters. It is recommended to avoid fishing in a Blood Moon while inside an enclosed space (like a building), as this may make escape difficult if the player is caught off guard. It is recommended to avoid fishing in a Blood Moon while inside an enclosed space (like a building), as this may make escape difficult if the player is caught off guard.

One way to effectively fight the Wandering Eye Fish is to obtain a movement accessory such as a Cloud in a Bottle or Rocket Boots and make tight circles around the eye. Its top speed can easily outrun early-game players, but its turning radius is limited.
Unlike most flying enemies, the Wandering Eye Fish can enter water, though it will still be slowed down when submerged.
If the Wandering Eye Fish is afflicted with the Confused debuff, it may fly away far enough to despawn unless the player chases it.

A way to easily beat the Wandering Eye Fish relatively early in the game is to stomp it with a Slimy Saddle. Jumping on the Wandering Eye Fish with the saddle on will make it vertically lock on to the player, and it will quickly melt its own health bar by ramming itself into the mount. The player should take care to avoid falling to their death if they miss a stomp.

It has a similar appearance to Demon Eyes and Wandering Eyes, being named after and having similar stats to the latter. Rather than severed nerves and blood vessels trailing from its rear, it sports red fins. It closely resembles The Fish of Cthulhu.
Despite being a golden fish, they are used in neither the Golden Delight (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) nor any type of fishing food.
Its tooltip, ' If you like piña coladas and getting caught in the rain', is a lyric from the 1979 song " Escape " by Rupert Holmes.

This content is transcluded from NPCs/dropnote. Since town NPCs cannot be damaged by players normally, external damage sources must be used to obtain this item. The Flymeal (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is one of the easiest options; other effective options include traps, lava, drowning, Boulders or Rolling Cacti (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), enemies, Explosive Bunnies, Land Mines, or the Halloween -exclusive Rotten Eggs (in tandem with Frost armor ).
The Dye Trader will use this weapon when defending himself.
Formerly stronger than the Muramasa, it still functions as a decent sword pre- Dungeon.
A scimitar is a curved sword of Middle Eastern origin used for fighting. It was used as early as the 9th century and has become an important symbol in many Arab cultures.
This weapon looks very similar to the Cutlass.
It also resembles the crossed swords icon used to enable PvP in multiplayer.

Technically, the Enchanted Sundial's cooldown is set to 8 days right after activation, and is reduced by 1 day at 4:30 AM each day. [2] This means that: Since the Enchanted Sundial accelerates time to 4:30 AM the following day, this cooldown is reduced to 7 days after its effect ends. The cooldown can be sped up by time-accelerating methods. Since the Enchanted Sundial accelerates time to 4:30 AM the following day, this cooldown is reduced to 7 days after its effect ends. The cooldown can be sped up by time-accelerating methods.

The Enchanted Sundial has a few noteworthy uses: Skipping the daily cooldown for the Angler 's fishing quests. Skipping a Blood Moon or Solar Eclipse. Skipping a boss for one night after its announcement, such as the mechanical bosses. Changing moon phases in order to buy specific moon phase-exclusive items from NPCs. Skipping the daily cooldown for the Angler 's fishing quests. Skipping a Blood Moon or Solar Eclipse. Skipping a boss for one night after its announcement, such as the mechanical bosses. Changing moon phases in order to buy specific moon phase-exclusive items from NPCs.
Alternative methods to accelerate time are by sleeping in a bed and through the Power Menu in Journey Mode.
The Enchanted Sundial shares its color palette and architectural theme with much of the Skyware furniture set, though there is no direct correlation between the two.

Consumable ranged weapons deal ranged damage and receive bonuses from items and effects that improve ranged damage, though they do not count as any particular type of ammunition for Shroomite armor or similar effects.

All consumable ranged weapons are available before Hardmode. After this point, they are largely obsolete, though some are replaced by magic and melee weapons that operate in similar ways without being exhaustible.
Both Thrown Water and explosives are thrown consumable weapons. However, they neither inflict ranged damage nor are affected by buffs, accessories, or any other factors.

"Throwing" used to be a separate damage type, introduced in the 1.3.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) update but removed again in the 1.4.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) update. In addition to consumable ranged weapons, the Ale Tosser (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Bone Glove (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) also dealt throwing damage. The Ninja armor and Fossil armor (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) used to grant boosts to throwing weapons in particular. Although throwing weapons did not deal melee damage, they were affected by flasks. In addition to consumable ranged weapons, the Ale Tosser (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Bone Glove (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) also dealt throwing damage. The Ninja armor and Fossil armor (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) used to grant boosts to throwing weapons in particular. Although throwing weapons did not deal melee damage, they were affected by flasks.
In order to parry an attack, the enemy must collide with the shield before hitting the player.

The damage dealt by parrying an attack is decreased by banners (25% in Classic or lower, 50% in Expert or above), rerolled inversely by luck (having negative luck will give a chance to increase incoming damage, and increase reflected damage as a result) and is capped at 1,000 damage.

The Brand of the Inferno's parry ability can only be used to parry contact damage from enemies (including enemies that ignore dodges like the Dungeon Guardian ). Fall damage, lava damage, enemy projectiles, and traps will still harm the player. It can, however, reduce damage from these sources with the 20 defense gained while pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button. It can, however, reduce damage from these sources with the 20 defense gained while pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button.
Parrying in Journey Mode with Godmode enabled will do nothing.
The act of gaining the Striking Moment buff and switching to a more powerful weapon like the Psycho Knife or Meowmere has the potential to deal massive damage.

The Brand of the Inferno, the Sergeant United Shield, the Sky Dragon's Fury, and the Tome of Infinite Wisdom are the only weapons in Terraria to have two separate means of attack triggered by two different buttons.
Like the other Old One's Army weapons, the Brand of the Inferno is a direct reference to the weapon of the same name in Dungeon Defenders 2, due to its implementation as part of a crossover event.
In the inventory, the sword's loops appear hollow. However, while being used, the loops are filled with flames. This is purely a graphical difference.
The Brand of the Inferno has similarities to the Tizona (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) in regard to blade design and name ( Tizona means firebrand ).
On the Nintendo 3DS version, the music for invasions is played throughout the entire world, regardless of if there are any enemies until it has been cleared.
This set is a reference to the character Toad from the Mario franchise.
Amber is strangely absent from the Sandgun 's crafting recipe, instead using Topaz. This is likely because the Sandgun was introduced before Amber was.
In real life, amber is fossilized tree resin, making it different from other gems' real-life counterparts in the fact that it is much younger and made of organic material. Such resin is called copal.
While the Presents are able to be opened, it is recommended to store them, since they are unique and unobtainable.

It appears the Present (furniture type described on this page) is a Present meant to simulate that of Desktop, Console, Old-gen console, and Mobile, since it shares those versions' tooltip rather than the old Present tooltip. It also has no distinct color in its name and is blue, like on the aforementioned platforms. It also has no distinct color in its name and is blue, like on the aforementioned platforms.

It also seems to be intended to be placeable (like on Desktop), but some bug or limitation in the game code makes the Present place a blank object (rather than the placed Present) and drops the normal Present loot. Due to its method of opening, it opens extremely fast compared to all other loot bags in Terraria.
All four sets of Fragment Brick furniture have identical shapes and thus only differ in color.
The Flask of Cursed Flames can prove to be very useful when mining, as it gives more light than torches, and both pickaxes and drills are affected by the buff.
The Resplendent Dessert is the only Master Mode -exclusive item to not be directly dropped by a boss or mini-boss. It is crafted with two such items instead.
When the Resplendent Dessert is equipped, only the Slime Prince will be shown besides the player in the character selection menu, instead of both.
The Resplendent Dessert and the Pair of Eyeballs are the only pet-summoning items that spawn two pets instead of one.
Unlike King and Queen Slime, the pet slimes have visible faces, similar to the Town Slimes.
The Fish is significantly less rare in Boreal Crates than in Frozen Chests, where it can only be found at a 1 in 50 rate.
Despite being called Boreal Crate, the crate is less similar to Boreal Wood than the Frozen Crate.
Equipping Acid Dye, Red Acid Dye, or Blue Acid Dye on the Shadow Orb can make parts of it or the whole orb invisible.
The effect of this dye appears very similar to the Gel Dye 's effect, as they are both blue and have wavy visuals.

The Yellow Horseshoe Balloon is the best single-balloon double-jump item in the game. The Bundle of Balloons provides a Cloud, Blizzard, and Sandstorm jump, all in one accessory, but it does not grant immunity to fall damage.
None of the Horseshoe Balloons can be crafted with an Obsidian Horseshoe. The original Lucky Horseshoe must be used.

The double jump is more similar to the Rocket Boots in function than to the Cloud in a Bottle : the ↷ Jump button must be held down for maximum effect. However, letting go early will forfeit the rest of the jump's height instead of being able to use the full height in small bursts.
Unlike the Rocket Boots, the Sandstorm jump provides a speed boost when used, which can be used to quickly turn around while retaining some speed.
The mango is a fruit that originated from South and Southeast Asia and is known worldwide for its sweet, soft, juicy, yellow flesh and warm, vivid coloration.
Sea Turtles and Dolphins cannot be captured because they are considered to be too big. [1]
The Water Candle can be placed underwater.
The Water Candle will not give off light underwater if held in one's hand.
The Water Candle's effects stack with those of the Battle Potion and the Blood Moon.

The Skull Lantern appears to be the "bone" version of the candle, and its most notable difference is its size. While candles measure 1×1, the Skull Lantern measures 2×2. The Skull Lantern cannot be toggled on and off with mechanisms.
The Large Dynasty Candle, despite its name, is not a candle but a candelabra.
The Cactus Candle somewhat resembles the Pink Prickly Pear.

If the First Fractal is added to a character's inventory / research menu using inventory editors or similar methods, it will disappear. This can be prevented by overriding Terraria's automatic removal of deprecated items, in which case it can be used normally on both single player and multiplayer. If then deposited into a storage item or thrown onto the ground, it disappears.

Like the Zenith, equipment and modifiers that increase melee speed change the number of projectiles that appear per use, but have no effect on the number of projectiles thrown per second, nor the swords' velocity. See Projectiles § Notes for more details.
The lack of dyes on the projectile character is a bug, which was not fixed before this item was scrapped.
The auto-target range of the First Fractal is 30 tiles.

According to Re-Logic, the First Fractal was not made obtainable because "it wasn't ready". [3] Yoraiz0r stated that "as a melee weapon it did not feel melee, endgame, or clean enough. The player silhouettes ended up being confusing to some because they're dependent on the player's looks, and there was not a good enough clear line of action." [2]
Its statistics are near-identical to Zenith, the only exception being use time : The Zenith has a use time of 30, while the First Fractal has a use time of 35.
The character does not swing the sword. Rather, the character's hand moves as if it were using a yoyo or similar animated projectile weapon.
The First Fractal's name is similar to one of the code names used for the Zenith during development, Final Fractal. [4]
It is one of the few unobtainable items that can be researched in Journey Mode, another being the Bone Block.
First Fractal was also a name for a discarded weapon concept that was developed for 1.3.0.1. The weapon would have been a sword counterpart to the Last Prism. [2]
The name of the weapon in-game is displayed as ItemName.FirstFractal.
One of the First Fractal's projectiles simply appears to be a Terra Blade with an elongated blade, using a slightly different color palette than the rest of the projectiles.
The Yellow Cockatiel, Gray Cockatiel, Blue Macaw, Owl, Scarlet Macaw, and Toucan are the only bird critters that cannot be cooked into food.
Real life cockatiels are species that are a branch of the cockatoo family endemic to Australia and are known for being widely prized and popular pets.
The tooltip is a reference to Wolfgang 's examination quote for the Monster Lasagna in Don't Starve.
The damage of projectiles that spawn upon hitting the enemy will be increased by the buff twice, except projectiles from the following weapons: [1]
When using the Sergeant United Shield, a shield accessory is not required to be able to block, as long as the shield is not being thrown. Otherwise, a shield accessory must be equipped.
The Bookcase actually shows 13 books stored, similar to how a placed book shows 2-3 books.

Although it is not required to make it, the Water Bolt 's unique sprite is visible in most bookcases (a blue book with a white/brown band). The Boreal Wood Bookcase appears to have two Water Bolts. The Boreal Wood Bookcase appears to have two Water Bolts.
The Boreal Wood Bookcase, the Slime Bookcase, and the Crystal Bookcase are the only three to have horizontally placed books, being the only display of books that way in the game.
The Sandstone Bookcase appears to contain scrolls rather than books, probably because it is ancient-themed.
Despite Cactus and Living Wood Bookcases having no visible top surfaces, objects can still be placed on top of them, in some cases appearing to float in midair.
The Shadewood, Martian, Slime, and Dynasty are the only bookcases to show more than two rows of books.

On the Nintendo 3DS version, the Bookcase Crafting Station icon appears to be just a white square, while everything else appears normal. This is most likely a bug, or was forgotten during development.

Despite real-world grapes being clearly a fruit, Grapes in Terraria do not fit into the Fruits category. They are not included in the group of Any Fruit and thus cannot be used to craft Fruit Juice, Fruit Salad, or Ambrosia. Furthermore, they are not dropped from shaking trees, and both they and their juice give better buffs than the members of that category.
It may be preferable to refrain from consuming Grapes directly and instead craft two of them into a Grape Juice, as it gives a better variation of the Well Fed buff.
The Grapes' tooltip is a reference to the 1939 novel The Grapes of Wrath by John Steinbeck.

Grapes dropping from Giant Flying Foxes is likely a reference to Aesop's fable The Fox and the Grapes, in which a fox attempts to reach some grapes on a vine but ultimately decides that they are undesirable.
In the real world, grapes originated from the Mediterranean and Central Asia and are a major ingredient in wine.

It is one of the (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) six / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) four components of the Ankh Shield that can be obtained in pre-Hardmode, the others being the Obsidian Skull, Cobalt Shield, Bezoar, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Adhesive Bandage, and (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Megaphone.

A nazar is an eye-shaped charm commonly found in the Middle East meant to ward away a superstitious curse called the Evil eye, believed to be cast by a malevolent, envious, or admiring gaze (depending on the culture), causing misfortune or injury (usually unintentionally) to the afflicted. The word nazar is derived from the Arabic نظر meaning sight or seeing ; in this case it means glare.
The Ironskin Potion is more effective than the Endurance Potion against attacks that deal less than 40 / 60 / 80 damage; however, it is most effective to use both at the same time.
The Ironskin Potion is a very useful asset during the game as it requires very cheap and easily farmable items, making it easy to craft a large number of them.

Although it can be made with Lead Ore, it still has Iron in the name. Lead in real life is generally toxic when inhaled or orally ingested. Lead in real life is generally toxic when inhaled or orally ingested.
Releasing a Seahorse outside of water will cause it to be immobile. However, it will not die from this.
Although technically a flail, the Golem Fist's projectile has no difficulty passing through terrain on its return trip.
The Golem Fist has a similar velocity as the Golem 's fist attack.

It has one of the highest knockback values of all weapons, beaten only by the Slap Hand (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and possibly (depending on the player's speed) the Jousting Lance (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and its upgrades.
Continuing with the Crimson 's blood and gore theme for its items, such as Bloody Spine and Tendon Bow, an Artery is a part of the body through which blood is pumped.
This item is not available on the Nintendo 3DS version due to the unavailability of pixel shaders.
Despite being only obtainable post- Plantera, its rarity is 00*.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Selling the ore rather than the bar yields 2 SC more per bar.
Like The Eye of Cthulhu, Code 2, Valkyrie Yoyo, Kraken, and Terrarian, Red's Throw can be held in the air indefinitely.
In real life, Redigit is a known yoyo enthusiast.
It shares the same stats as the Valkyrie Yoyo.
It shares the same color scheme as Red's set.
If a player travels faster than 95 mph over a Pressure Plate Track it is possible for it not to trigger.

Like gold, lead is quite heavy and soft in reality, which would render it useless for making tools and armor. However, lead (11.34g/cm³) is still far less dense than other metals found in the game, namely tungsten (19.25g/cm³), gold (19.3g/cm³) and platinum (21.45g/cm³).

In reality, lead is a neurotoxin with serious negative effects on the human body, up to and including death. This property does not seem to be shared by the in-game metal, as it is used in a variety of food-related items (e.g. Cooking Pots and Ironskin Potions ).
On the Old-gen console and 3DS versions, the Jungle Day music track is the only track that will play throughout the Jungle.
Avoid knocking Bee Hives off the ceiling, as doing so will release Bees that can easily disrupt exploring.
It is recommended newer players have at least Silver / Tungsten armor when visiting the Jungle.

The Jungle will always be on the side of the map opposite the Dungeon and the Snow biome, and on the same side as the Underground Desert (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). It is possible for it to spawn within view of the player's starting position, and, very rarely, in the center of the map, giving some indication of the layout of the rest of the world.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) To get some very good starter equipment without having to venture into the dangerous Underground Jungle to loot Ivy Chests, it may be worth it to fish in the Jungle at the very beginning of the game with a Reinforced Fishing Pole and Enchanted Nightcrawlers. Jungle Crates will drop the same loot as Ivy Chests, but are easy to obtain, as the Jungle often spawns with large pools of water, and it can be easy to avoid enemies by simply boxing oneself in. This way, the player can obtain very powerful starter equipment, such as the Anklet of the Wind and Boomstick, without even having to defeat a boss.

Originally, another biome, the Swamp, was planned. [1] It was intended to be an alternative to the Jungle, much like the Crimson is an alternate of the Corruption, but was scrapped due to the large amount of content added to the Jungle. [2]
Selling the Butterfly Wings instead of the individual components will be more profitable. The wings sell for 8 GC, whereas the components sell for a collective 2 GC 90 SC.
Turkor the Ungrateful drops the Horn o' plenty, an infinitely reusable and powerful healing item that is useful even throughout Hardmode.
The Roman candle and the Festive top hat were added to the Mobile Thanksgiving update before the Christmas update, but were unobtainable until the device's time was within December.
Multiple equipped counterweights do not stack. Only one will function at a time.
The particular color equipped will display on a character, unlike the Yoyo Bag, which shows a random color.
A counterweight does not stack with the Yoyo Bag.

Counterweights are real-world yo-yo accessories used to aid in tricks where the yo-yo is swung from the middle of the string rather than its end. Real-world counterweights are often patterned after (or made out of) polyhedral dice, and Terraria 's follow suit: the Blue and Red Counterweights are four-sided (tetrahedral) dice, the Purple and Green Counterweights are six-sided (cubic/hexahedral) dice, and the Black and Yellow Counterweights are twelve-sided (dodecahedral) dice.
The buff tooltip jokingly references the Baby Ogre's status as a pet, as opposed to a combat summon; he cannot fight because he does not know how to use his club.

In detail, the accessory has a twofold effect on mana regeneration: [1] It halves the regeneration delay after spending mana, e.g. using a magic weapon. If standing still or having the Mana Regeneration buff, it only reduces the delay by 1/3 (33.33%). It increases the regeneration rate by a certain value, which ranges from +2.875 mana/sec to +14.375 mana/sec, depending on how full the wearer's mana bar is. The exact value can be calculated by adding 2.875 to 11.5 * (cur/max), where cur is the current and max the maximum mana. The following table demonstrates this with some exemplary values: It halves the regeneration delay after spending mana, e.g. using a magic weapon. If standing still or having the Mana Regeneration buff, it only reduces the delay by 1/3 (33.33%). It increases the regeneration rate by a certain value, which ranges from +2.875 mana/sec to +14.375 mana/sec, depending on how full the wearer's mana bar is. The exact value can be calculated by adding 2.875 to 11.5 * (cur/max), where cur is the current and max the maximum mana. The following table demonstrates this with some exemplary values:

The Mana Regeneration Band requires a Band of Starpower to craft. This content is transcluded from Band of Starpower § Crimson worlds. Getting a Band of Starpower takes special measures in Crimson worlds, since it is normally dropped from Corruption -exclusive Shadow Orbs. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Band of Starpower can be crafted in the Graveyard, from a Panic Necklace and a Mana Crystal. It is also obtainable in Hardmode by fishing up Defiled Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) in an artificial Corruption biome, which can be made with Corrupt Seeds from the Dryad when in a Hardmode Graveyard. On the Nintendo 3DS version, the Band of Starpower can be found in Living Wood Chests. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Band of Starpower can be crafted in the Graveyard, from a Panic Necklace and a Mana Crystal. It is also obtainable in Hardmode by fishing up Defiled Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) in an artificial Corruption biome, which can be made with Corrupt Seeds from the Dryad when in a Hardmode Graveyard. On the Nintendo 3DS version, the Band of Starpower can be found in Living Wood Chests.
Its mana regeneration ability works in the same way the Band of Starpower did in the Pre-Release.
Despite the fact that it was called a Pot o' Gold, it had no sell value.

It was possible to farm his coins by making a room with a low ceiling, having o'Fyffe on one side of the door and the player on the other. He would try to jump out (probably because he thought it is simply an obstacle). If the player placed a block above his head, he would jump even faster as he could fit through a 2 block gap. Being too far away would cause him to fly through blocks toward the player.
Fyffe means money in Finnish slang.

A poltergeist is a type of ghost or spirit that is responsible for physical disturbances, such as loud noises and objects being moved or destroyed. Most claims about or fictional descriptions of poltergeists show them as capable of pinching, biting, hitting, and tripping people. They are also depicted as capable of the movement or levitation of objects such as furniture and cutlery, or noises such as knocking on doors. Poltergeists in Terraria appear to wield a blue Book, a wooden Table, and a wooden Chair. They cannot actually drop or throw them, however, or move any objects. Poltergeists in Terraria appear to wield a blue Book, a wooden Table, and a wooden Chair. They cannot actually drop or throw them, however, or move any objects.
Despite the similarities in name, it cannot be used to make the Banana Split.

The Banana's tooltip is a direct quote from " The Doctor Dances ", an episode of the British science fiction television series Doctor Who. Christopher Eccleston, playing the Ninth Doctor, tells Jack Harkness, his companion, not to drop a banana because it is a "good source of potassium!" [1]
The sprite of the Anti-Portal Block is a reference to the 2007 puzzle-platform video game Portal, where the darker-colored tiles disallow portal placing.
The Gravity Globe does not change gravity while grappled, not even while gravity is flipped.
If the Gravity Globe is unequipped while in inverted gravity, gravity will return to normal.
It is useful in the Dungeon for quick ascents up the zigzag corridors.
The Gravity Globe can be a useful accessory when fighting the Dungeon Guardian.
The Gravity Globe is one of three Expert Mode-exclusive items dropped by the Moon Lord, the others being the Celestial Starboard and the Suspicious Looking Tentacle.
Blackcurrant is a berry shrub that can be found in Central and Northern Europe, as well as Northern Asia.
The Purple Clubberfish is a very powerful melee weapon at the early stages of the game. It can be acquired as long as the player is capable of surviving long enough in the Corruption to obtain one.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The Purple Clubberfish is a decent catch, but it is outshone by the Rockfish, which deals the same amount of damage, attacks faster, and doubles as a Hammer. It also has the same catch rate as the Clubberfish but can be fished in the regular Underground area, making it a more viable option.

The Purple Clubberfish is one of the few fish that can be used as a weapon. Others include the Swordfish, Obsidian Swordfish, Frost Daggerfish, Bomb Fish, Bladetongue, Crystal Serpent, Toxikarp, Reaver Shark, Sawtooth Shark and Rockfish.
It looks like a corrupted version of a Rockfish, with the Clubberfish's head actually being a recolor of the Rockfish's head.
When any Gem Robe is equipped in an armor slot without a Wizard Hat, Tim 's spawn rate will be increased to 5 times.
This item is the armor analog to the Emerald Staff.
The Baby Slime minion applies 12 ticks of static immunity frames upon hitting an enemy, meaning it can hit up to five times per second [1].
Although it is extremely rare, it is possible to obtain the Slime Staff almost immediately after starting a new game.
In Celebrationmk10 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds, the Slime Staff can be purchased from the Princess for 10 GC.

An easy way to obtain the Slime Staff without much effort is to construct a statue farm with one or more Slime Statues, and lava just deep enough to not destroy any drops as it kills the slimes. Leave it alone for a while, and occasionally check if the staff has been dropped yet. Using advanced setups like engines and multiple statues can greatly accelerate the process. Note that as of version 1.3.0.1 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), there is a limit to how quickly statues can be triggered.
Another way to quickly kill a lot of slimes is to summon King Slime or to wait for a Slime Rain (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) An early way to get it would be to intentionally die several times, use all the Tombstones to make a Graveyard, and farm Slimed Zombies. Abigail's Flower (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) can also spawn in graveyards and is potentially easier to obtain. Abigail's Flower (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) can also spawn in graveyards and is potentially easier to obtain.
The Slime Staff when coupled with Lucky Coin and the Broken modifier is a great money maker since its attacks are fast but not strong.
It can be used to keep weak enemies like Meteor Heads away while focusing on other tasks like mining.
The summoned Baby Slime is summoned at the cursor, and therefore can be used to attack enemies on the other side of walls.
The Slime Staff has among the lowest drop rates of any enemy-dropped item.

Prior to 1.3.4 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the Slime Staff had the lowest base damage of any summon weapon. Since 1.3.4, the Lightning Aura Rod has lower base damage, though it also ignores defense.
The Baby Slime summoned by the Slime Staff appears to be a baby version of the Toxic Sludge slime, being similar in color, and having a face as well.
When the Baby Slime is moving to attack an enemy, it will destroy Pots, grass, and vines.
If the player is moving too fast, the Baby Slime will fly to the player with wings.
Despite resembling an ancient oil lamp, it does not produce light when placed, nor can it be used as a light source for a house.
Having the Wire Cutter equipped shows the location of Wires on-screen (including Wires in naturally occurring traps). Any mechanism, or a Wrench, will do the same.
When a tile contains multiple wires and/or an Actuator, the Wire Cutter will remove the Actuator first, then yellow, green, blue, and red wires, in that order.

Since Wires have a high unit cost ( 5 SC each) and are generally needed in large quantities, it is useful to take the Wire Cutter while exploring to harvest Wires from natural traps, especially to the Dungeon and Jungle Temple.

For cases where a zigzagging diagonal wire needs to be cut, the Wire Cutter could be a better choice than The Grand Design. Turning on Smart Cursor and holding ⚒ Use / Attack will allow the wires to be auto-cut.

The zoom function of the Sniper Scope only works with guns and tools that use bullets, Candy Corn, Gel, Stakes, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or solutions as ammo. [1] It works neither with other guns, e.g. the Dart Rifle (which uses darts ), nor with other weapons with "gun" in their name, e.g. Piranha Gun or Rainbow Gun (neither of which use ammo). Thus, the Sniper Scope does work with the Candy Corn Rifle, the Flamethrower, the Elf Melter, the Stake Launcher, the Clentaminator, and the Terraformer. The critical strike and damage bonuses are still applied to all ranged weapons. Thus, the Sniper Scope does work with the Candy Corn Rifle, the Flamethrower, the Elf Melter, the Stake Launcher, the Clentaminator, and the Terraformer. The critical strike and damage bonuses are still applied to all ranged weapons.

The zoom effect is identical to the that of the Binoculars or the Sniper Rifle, but the Sniper Scope can be used simultaneously with any applicable gun. The Sniper Scope's zoom slightly stacks with that of the Sniper Rifle. [2] The Sniper Scope's zoom slightly stacks with that of the Sniper Rifle. [2]

The Sniper Scope actually has a higher ranged critical hit bonus than the Destroyer Emblem. However, this benefit should be weighed against the limited nature of its damage buff: Even a ranged-specialized character could get more benefit from the base Destroyer Emblem, because the extra damage also applies to minions.
The zoom function works well with a Spelunker or Hunter Potion, as it allows to cover a greater area more quickly when searching for ore or bound NPCs.

If zoomed in on a biome with different music than the one the player is in, the music will change upon zooming. For instance, if the player is standing in a Forest biome and zooms in on a Glowing Mushroom biome, then the music will change to the Glowing Mushroom biome music. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) If zoomed into an area affected by an area-buff item, the player will receive the buff even if they are not inside the radius. If they are inside the radius, zooming outside of the radius will cause the player to lose the buff. This applies to a Campfire, Heart Lantern, Star in a Bottle, and even banners. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) If zoomed into an area affected by an area-buff item, the player will receive the buff even if they are not inside the radius. If they are inside the radius, zooming outside of the radius will cause the player to lose the buff. This applies to a Campfire, Heart Lantern, Star in a Bottle, and even banners.

Having a Sniper Scope equipped, even if not being zoomed out, drastically increases the enemy spawning rectangle. This can effectively break player-made farms that rely on knowledge of the normal spawning rectangle. For the exact size of the area, see NPC spawning § Spawn locations.

The Slice of Cake can be activated limitlessly with no cooldown period. It is never consumed, and all players may use it to give themselves the buff. Activating the Slice of Cake while the Sugar Rush buff is already active resets the 2-minute buff duration. Activating the Slice of Cake while the Sugar Rush buff is already active resets the 2-minute buff duration.
Unlike most furniture items, the Slice of Cake requires 3 units to research in Journey Mode.
It appears as an emote which can be seen during Parties:
The Slice of Cake and its Sugar Rush buff were introduced in 1.3.2, but remained unobtainable until 1.4.0.1.
The tooltip is a reference to Tumblr 's old terms of service, "Go nuts. Show nuts. Whatever."
The Cursed debuff does not prevent item usage not triggered by the above keys. For example, set bonuses from Forbidden armor and dash effects from items can still be used.
When cursed, minions created by summon weapons continue to fight as normal, though new ones cannot be summoned.
The Cursed debuff can be seen as an upgraded version of Silenced.
The debuff sprite contains a bag-like item which is a recolor of pre-1.2 Thrown Powder sprites.
Despite the fact that the egg hatches into a Lizard, it is still dropped by Flying Snakes.
The name being spelled as "Lizard" (like the real-world creature) could be referencing the strange spelling of "Lihzahrd".
The Pet Lizard's buff tooltip, "Chillin' like a reptilian", could be a combination of references to the phrase " chillin' like a villain " and the fact that lizards are reptiles.
The Pet Lizard appears to resemble a green iguana, a large, real-world lizard that is often kept as a pet due to its docile nature (see green iguana in captivity ).
As it drops the SWAT Helmet, the Tactical Skeleton seems to be modeled as an undead SWAT unit, which is reinforced by its Bestiary description.

The tooltip for the helmet is a reference to the multiplayer first-person shooter video game Destiny 2, as Ahamkara are a form of dragon in the game. It is also worth noting that an NPC from the game, the Drifter, often says "Trust!" at the end of sentences.

This is one of two sets added in the Journey's End Vanity Contest that is locked behind progression, since Skeletron needs to be defeated to access Bones. The other set is  the Timeless Traveler's set.
The Predictor will not attempt to attack the player if it does not have a direct line of sight to them, but will never cancel its attack, even once killed.
If the player hides behind solid blocks, the Predictor's projectiles will still "see" them.
The Predictor, Selenian, Stargazer, and Vortexian all share very similar sprites.

The name "Predictor" is likely a reference to the 1987 sci-fi action film Predator, which features a futuristic trophy hunter alien known as the " Predator ", who is the main antagonist of the film. Not only does the name resemble the Predator, but its design seems to draw inspiration from the Predator, being humanoid with a large, brain-shaped head.
The "fire rate" per second is calculated by dividing ticks per second (60) by the item's use time: [math]\displaystyle{ \mathit{fire\ rate} = \frac{60}{\mathit{use\ time}} }[/math]
Both genders can wear this vanity set and have their own variants, despite the name indicating that it is intended for female use.
The source code spells the name as "Mrs. Clause."
Using a Mushroom as a healing item is rather inefficient as it can be crafted into two Lesser Healing Potions which restore 50 health each.
This mushroom may resemble the Lactarius deliciosus. However, that mushroom's dots are significantly less apparent.

It is the weakest healing item that only heals in the game, restoring only 15 health with each Mushroom. While Life Fruits technically have the lowest healing, healing 5 health per use, they also increase maximum health by 5. While Life Fruits technically have the lowest healing, healing 5 health per use, they also increase maximum health by 5.
The Pirate Corsair's name and sprite suggests that it may be based on historical pirates from the Mediterranean, most notably the Barbary pirates.
Despite visibly wielding the Cutlass, it does not have a higher chance to drop it.
The blade's hitbox extends considerably beyond the blade sprite itself, barely beating out the Breaker Blade in horizontal range by about a pixel, but losing quite a bit in vertical range.
The Hearty Slash projectiles are not affected by melee speed bonuses.
Their projectile speed is 82 mph - 116 mph depending on how close they are fired diagonally.
Due to its light-emitting, wall-piercing beams, this sword is useful for exploring and finding caves, behaving as an upgrade to the Death Sickle and other weapons in this regard.
Aiming is slightly easier due to how wide the projectiles are, combining that with high melee speed, one can decimate multi-segment bosses such as The Destroyer easily.
It can be very useful for events due to its powerful attacks, projectiles, and crowd-controlling capabilities.
Like the other Old One's Army weapons, the Flying Dragon is a direct reference to the weapon of the same name in Dungeon Defenders 2, due to its implementation as part of a crossover event.
The Flying Dragon is one of the largest swords in the game, beaten only by the Breaker Blade.
Despite the tooltip and summoned pet's name, the Eater of Worms interacts with neither the critter nor item form of the Worm.
It acts similarly to The Deactivated Probe, which is the Master Mode pet of The Destroyer.
The buff tooltip "May ruin several backyards" could possibly be a reference to worms often digging holes in backyards.
The Pumpking begins to spawn during the Pumpkin Moon event at wave 10.

If not defeated before dawn (4:30 AM) or all players present in the current world are dead while the event is active, all active Pumpkings will retreat straight down through the ground and despawn. This trait is also shared by the Mourning Wood.
Stray Flaming Scythes thrown by a Pumpking can travel far outside enemy spawn boundaries, able to kill town NPCs in their houses.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Up to seven Pumpkings (more in multiplayer ) can attack simultaneously during the event's final, 15th wave.
The Flairon can be very effective against the Pumpking, who tends to float right above players (well within the range of the Flairon and its homing bubbles), causing very high damage per hit.

The Pumpking's contact damage is relatively lower than the damage inflicted by his projectiles, especially his Flaming Scythes. Using wings and other flight-based accessories like the Soaring Insignia (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) to fly closer towards his head while tanking his contact damage with high defense may help the player avoid taking excessive amounts of damage, especially in cases when they are being attacked by multiple Pumpkings at once.

High-mobility items, such as the Anti-Gravity Hook (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the Tabi and its upgrades, or the Shield of Cthulhu (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), allow for easier handling of the Pumpking.
Pumpking is a portmanteau of pumpkin and king.

The Pumpking's NPC ID image only contains his head, which is the only part of his main body that can take and deal damage. The cloak that is attached to the Pumpking head's sprite is stored separately as a harmless, non-damageable entity by the name of PumpkingCloak.xnb.
Strangely, The Horseman's Blade drops from the Pumpking and not from the Headless Horseman.
The Pumpking and the Poltergeist are the only two Pumpkin Moon enemies whose main bodies consistently travel through blocks.
The Pumpking Blades have health and defense values even though they cannot be damaged.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, a cloud in the shape of the Pumpking can occasionally be seen in the background.

Worms will become stuck in 1-tile holes in the ground, which can allow for easy collection during rain. However, this only works if both tiles adjacent to the worm are not hammered inclines (i.e. a full block instead of sloped).

When intending to sell Worms or use them for fishing, it may be worth upgrading them into Enchanted Nightcrawlers (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) first. These have 10% more bait power and sell for 15 SC more, and require only Fallen Stars, a relatively common crafting material.
The Bestiary entry for the Worm: " A slick, tubular invertebrate found hiding in rocks, dirt, and grass. Loves the rain. Fish are especially attracted to these. "
The screen effect produced does not display properly under Retro or Trippy lighting modes.

The tooltip is a reference to the Forbidden Knowledge animated short, the backstory of Wilson, the main character of Don't Starve. In the short, the main antagonist Maxwell sends out forbidden knowledge to Wilson through a radio and takes him to The Constant.

While the Radio Thing itself does not appear in Don't Starve, its appearance is based on the game's Divining Rod. It appears to be the PR-76 radio created by Wagstaff from Don't Starve. It appears to be the PR-76 radio created by Wagstaff from Don't Starve.

The Hallow and Corruption/Crimson variants inflict debuffs which can make exploring the Underground Desert dangerous even with pre- Plantera equipment, but can be easily avoided if approaching the enemy with care.

While a ghoul is a common enemy in many games, it is fitting that the Terraria version appears in Desert biomes. The ghoul's origin can be traced back to Arabic stories of monsters that feed on the flesh of desert travelers and desecrate the tombs of the buried.

It appears that the Corruption/Crimson and Hallowed versions have a liquid dripping down their chin while the normal version does not. This is confirmed by their Bestiary entries. This is confirmed by their Bestiary entries.
Oddly enough, the Ghouls are not immune to the debuffs they inflict, except the Dreamer Ghoul.
Coin Piles behave like Silt, Slush, and Sand and its variants; they will fall down instead of hovering in mid-air if whatever they are placed on is removed.
The appearance of Coin Piles changes after how they are placed to give impression of a flowing state.
Coin Piles look much more valuable than the coins they are made from. A single tile (1 coin) actually looks like 15 coins.
Coins will not balance out into a neat, orderly pyramid unless intentionally placed that way.
The Frame Skip setting can alter the output from the DPS Meter.

Prior to 1.2.3, going into the inventory with autopause on while using a weapon or tool and clicking an item would get it stuck and make it drop when exiting the inventory (unless the player right-clicked outside of their inventory to drop the item).
